questions.text:
A 40-year-old female patient had undergone a Pap smear test whose reports show LSIL (Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion). What would be the next step of management in the given scenario?

HPV- Human Papilloma Virus

LLETZ- Large loop excision of the transformation zone
questions.solution:
HPV testing is the next step of management in a woman aged ≥ 30 years whose Pap smear cytology report shows LSIL.

In women aged ≥ 30 years with cytology showing LSIL, HPV-testing is done. If HPV test comes positive, further management is with colposcopy with biopsy. If the HPV test comes negative, both the Pap smear test and HPV test (co-testing) are repeated after one year. 

If either the HPV test or the cytology report comes positive after one year, a colposcopy with biopsy will be done. Whereas a negative report warrants another co-testing at 3 years. Co-testing at 3 years will be followed by 5 yearly routine screening or colposcopy with biopsy based on the results.

However, LSIL in women < 30 years will be further proceeded by annual repeat cytology for two years.

questions.text: The test shown in the image is used to detect the abnormality of_____________.
questions.solution:
The test shown in the image is the Cottle test. It is used to detect abnormalities of the vestibular component of the nasal valve.

In this test, the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve. The nasal airway improves as the nasal valve opens upon performing this maneuver. This helps us in finding the site of obstruction.

The nasal valve area is the narrowest portion of the nasal passage. It is bounded medially by the nasal septum, superiorly and laterally by the caudal margin of the upper lateral cartilage, and inferiorly by the floor of the piriform aperture; the nasal valve is the specific slit-like segment between the caudal margin of the upper lateral cartilage and the septum.

Conditions with a positive Cottle test:

  • Deviated nasal septum
  • Collapsed nasal valve - causes snoring and sleep apnea
  • Valve stenosis

questions.text: An immunologist is conducting research studies with laboratory mice. He noticed a phenomenon known as Schultz-Dale phenomenon. Which type of hypersensitivity does this phenomenon follow?
questions.solution:
Schultz–Dale phenomenon or anaphylaxis in-vitro is a type I hypersensitivity reaction. 

The Schultz-Dale phenomenon refers to an in-vitro contraction of isolated intestinal muscle strips from a sensitized mouse that has been exposed to antigens, demonstrating an immediate hypersensitivity reaction. The reaction is specific and can be elicited only by the antigen to which the animal is sensitive. Tissues from normal animals can be passively sensitized by treatment with serum from sensitized animals.

Other types of tests for anaphylaxis:

Cutaneous anaphylaxis:

In this test, a small shocking dose of an antigen is administered intradermally to a sensitized host. A local wheal-and-flare response is observed. The central area of puffiness due to edema is called the wheal, while the surrounding hyperemia and erythema is the flare. The application of this procedure is used in testing for hypersensitivity and in identifying the allergen responsible for atopic diseases. 

Passive cutaneous anaphylaxis (PCA):

This test is an extremely sensitive in-vivo method for the detection of antibodies. A normal animal is injected with a small volume of the antibody intradermally. After 2-24 hours, the antigen is injected intravenously along with a dye such as Evans blue. Immediate blueing is observed at the site of intradermal injection due to vasodilatation and increased capillary permeability (wheal-and-flare reaction). The human IgG antibody (heterocytotropic) can be detected with this test but, not the human IgE antibody (homocytotropic).

  1. Saddle joint

Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson, Harris (EMJH) media is the culture medium used for leptospira.

The image below shows EMJH medium, with Dinger's ring/zone. The growth of the leptospires is at a maximum density at this zone. It is identified as an area of increased turbidity, beneath the surface of the semi-solid medium. It is the zone of optimum oxygen tension for the growth of the bacteria.

 

Buffered Charcoal, Yeast extract agar (BCYE) is the medium used for Legionella pneumophilia since it has fastidious growth requirements and grows on complex media containing with L-cysteine, alpha-ketoglutarate, iron, and antibiotic supplements. The colonies grow very slowly and vary in morphology from colorless to iridescent pink or blue and translucent to speckled.

The image below shows a growth of legionella on the BYCE medium.

 

Thiosulfate citrate bile salts sucrose agar (TCBS) is a selective and differential medium used for the culture of Vibrio species. Vibrio cholerae produces yellow-colored colonies. V. parahaemolyticus and V. vulnificus produce green colonies.

The following image shows Vibrio cholerae producing yellow-colored colonies against a green background on TCBS:

 

Cycloserine-cefoxitin fructose agar (CCFA) is both a selective and differential medium and has become a standard for the isolation of Clostridium difficile. C. difficile colonies appear as nonhemolytic, creamy yellow to gray-white in color, irregular, with a dull surface and a coarsely mottled structure.

questions.text: A young boy was rushed to the emergency room with complaints of respiratory distress and high-grade fever. The microscopy and culture of the sputum showed gram-positive cocci with α-hemolytic activity on blood agar. Which of the following antibiotics is the pathogen most likely susceptible to?
questions.solution:
Sputum showing gram-positive cocci with α-hemolytic activity in a patient with high-grade fever and respiratory distress is suggestive of pneumococcal pneumonia. Pneumococci show optochin susceptibility.

Both Streptococcus pneumoniae and Streptococcus viridans produce α-hemolysis on blood agar. The optochin sensitivity test is done to differentiate Streptococcus pneumoniae from commensal-like viridans Streptococci.

The image given below shows the classification of gram-positive bacteria.

Optochin sensitivity is observed using the disc diffusion method.

The image given below shows a sensitivity testing plate of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

questions.text: Which of the following is not required for calculation of creatinine clearance?

choices.text: Volume of serum passing through kidney in 24 hours

questions.solution:
The volume of plasma passing through the kidney in 24 hours is not used in the calculation of creatinine clearance.

The parameters used to calculate creatinine clearance (CCr) are:

  • Urine creatinine
  • Serum creatinine
  • 24hr urine output

The formula used to calculate creatinine clearance (CCr) is:

        UCr × V ⁄ PCr  where,

UCr - Urine creatinine(mg/dl)

PCr - Serum creatinine(mg/dl)

V - Urine volume(ml/24 hrs)

Creatinine is a metabolite of muscle metabolism and is cleared from the body mostly by glomerular filtration. Therefore, the clearance of creatinine is used to assess GFR.

Urine collection for the measurement of creatinine clearance may be subject to practical constraints. Therefore, approximate changes in GFR can be obtained by measuring the serum creatinine concentration, which is inversely proportional to GFR.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents to the fever clinic with a history of fever and breathlessness for the past 5 days. On examination, she is found to have a respiratory rate of 27 per minute and SpO2 of 90% on room air.  Her RT-PCR test was found to be positive for COVID-19 disease. According to the ministry of health and family welfare guidelines, this patient has:

choices.text: Severe COVID-19 infection with acute respiratory distress syndrome
Severe COVID-19 infection with septic shock

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has a respiratory rate of 27 per minute (≥ 24/minute) and SpO2 of 90% (90% to ≤93%), and a positive RT-PCR test for COVID 19 disease. Thus according to the ministry of health and family welfare guidelines, this patient has moderate COVID-19 infection.

According to the ministry of health and family welfare guidelines, COVID-19 infection can be classified as: 

Mild COVID-19 disease includes patients with uncomplicated upper respiratory tract infection and may have mild symptoms such as fever, cough, sore throat, nasal congestion, malaise, and headache. There is no shortness of breath or hypoxia.

Moderate COVID-19 disease includes patients with pneumonia but no signs of severe disease. Adults with the presence of clinical features of dyspnea and or hypoxia, fever, cough, including SpO2 90 to ≤93% on room air, respiratory rate ≥ 24 breaths/minute.

Severe COVID-19 disease includes adults with clinical signs of pneumonia plus one of the following- respiratory rate >30 breaths/min, severe respiratory distress, SpO2 <90% on room air. Severe infection further can have:

  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome - patients develop new or worsening respiratory symptoms within one week of onset of the symptoms. There are opacities in the chest radiographs which are not due to effusions, lobar or lung collapse, or nodules. The patients develop respiratory failure which is not due to cardiac failure or fluid overload. The PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 300 mmHg (with PEEP or CPAP ≥5 cm H2O)
  • Sepsis - life-threatening organ dysfunction caused due to an infection.
  • Septic shock - persisting hypotension despite fluid resuscitation. Patients require vasopressors to maintain MAP ≥65 mmHg and serum lactate level >2 mmol/L.

Mild cases can be home isolated. Moderate and severe cases will require hospitalisation in a dedicated COVID hospital.

questions.text: A child presents with chronic diarrhea,  weight loss, and fatigue. On examination, he was pale, with decreased height for age score. The life cycle of the causative organism is given in the image below. Which of the following is not a known complication of this disease?
questions.solution:
The life cycle given above denoting adult worms in the large intestine with them having a slender anterior end and a 'whip-like' thick posterior end is suggestive of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm). Focal seizures or cerebral involvement is not a known complication of trichuriasis. 

Trichuriasis is caused by T. trichiura (whipworm), which inhabits the cecum and ascending colon.

Clinical features include chronic dysentery, anemia, poor growth, and developmental defects. The disease may result either due to the mechanical effect of the worms or an allergic reaction to the parasite.

Trichuris trichiura causes rectal prolapse in children (characteristic feature) because the rectum loses its internal support as the worms bury their thin heads into the intestinal lining, loosening the elastic epithelium, and weakening the surrounding muscles; also, there is rectal edema because of the infection. All these factors finally lead to rectal prolapse. In heavy infection with T. trichiura, sigmoidoscopy may show white bodies of worms hanging from the inflamed mucosa, the so-called coconut cake rectum. 

Other complications include dysentery, diarrhea, tenesmus, iron deficiency anemia, and poor growth. The poor growth is typically secondary to poor nutrition and consequently causes cognitive delay.

Fecal smears show a barrel-shaped ovum of T. trichiura. The eggs of T. trichiura do not have a terminal spine. They are barrel-shaped and have mucus plugs at both ends. They get bile-stained and float in the saturated salt solution. An image showing the egg of trichuris is given below.

 

Albendazole 400 mg orally for 3 days is the drug of choice.

questions.text:
A patient presents with complaints of the room spinning when his head is in one particular position. His diagnosis was confirmed by performing the Hallpike maneuver. The physician performs another maneuver to relieve the patient's symptoms. Arrange the following in the proper sequence of the therapeutic maneuver.
  1. Affected ear is facing up at 90° rotation
  2. Head turned 45° to the affected side and head in hanging position
  3. Head turned forward and chin brought down to 20°
  4. Whole body and head rotated to a lateral recumbent position
  5. Sitting position with head turned to unaffected side by 45°
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). Epley's maneuver is performed, which follows the sequence b, a, d, e, c.

BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1 min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal. 

A positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis of BPPV. In this maneuver, the patient begins sitting up with their head turned 45 degrees toward the ear to be tested. Then the patient is made to lie down quickly with their head past the end of the bed. Then, the patient's neck is extended 20 degrees below the horizontal. The clinician then watches the patient's eyes for torsional and up-beating nystagmus, which should persist for no more than one minute. This would indicate a positive test.

The findings seen in the Dix-Hallpike maneuver are due to otoconial debris getting into the posterior semicircular canal from the utricle.

Epley's maneuver is performed to reposition the crystals into the macula from the posterior semicircular canals. This is only a temporary cure, and there is a high rate of recurrence.

Epley's maneuver consists of five positions:

 Step Maneuver
Position 1 Head turned 45°

Patient is to lie down in a head-hanging position
Position 2

The head is turned so that the affected ear is facing up at 90° rotation
Position 3 Whole-body and head rotated away from the affected ear in a 90° rotation face-down position
Position 4 Head still turned to unaffected side by 45°

Patient is brought to the sitting position
Position 5 Head turned forward with chin brought down 20°

questions.text: In a middle-aged diabetic patient with chronic kidney disease stage 5, which of the following drugs can be given safely without altering the dose?
questions.solution:
Linagliptin can be given safely without altering the dose for this patient.

Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl-peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor and is eliminated by the hepatobiliary route. Hence no dosage adjustment is needed in renal failure.

It is used in type 2 diabetes as monotherapy or as combination therapy with other drugs when metformin is not tolerated or contraindicated.

Other DPP-4 inhibitors like sitagliptin, vildagliptin, saxagliptin, alogliptin show renal elimination.

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company has set up a team of physicians to oversee the Phase IV clinical trial of a new drug for SARS-CoV2 infection to identify possible drug interactions. Which is the most appropriate statement about this phase of the clinical trial?

choices.text: Done in a group of 50-500 patients
Done after a drug is approved and marketed
Done for drugs used in rare diseases
Done for formulating guidelines for therapeutic use

questions.solution:
Phase IV study is conducted after the drug is approved and marketed by regulatory authorities.

Phase IV studies include post-marketing surveillance and other studies that complement the earlier findings of the drug. After the drug is marketed for general use, practicing physicians are identified through whom data about the efficacy, acceptability, and adverse effects of the drug are collected on a structured proforma. Patients treated in the real world with the approved drug are the study population. Therefore, the study population is much larger. Uncommon adverse effects or those that occur only after long-term use and unsuspected drug interactions are detected at this stage.

questions.text: Which of the following is true with respect to phase B of bacterial growth curve?

choices.text: Rapid increase in size of bacterial cell is seen
Viable and non culturable organisms can be seen
Steeper phase B can be possible with lesser generation time
Steeper phase B is seen with fastidious organisms

questions.solution:
In phase B (log phase) bacteria divide by multiplication. The time it takes to multiply is called generation time. With a lesser time taken to multiply, the division is faster, and therefore, phase B would be steeper.

Phases of bacterial growth: 

  • Lag phase (Marked as A): Occurs immediately after the seeding of a culture media. There is no increase in cell number but cell size increases and maximum cell size is obtained towards the end of this phase. This initial period is the time required for adaptation to a new environment, during which the necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication to proceed.
  • Log phase or exponential phase (Marked as B): In this phase, cells start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially or by geometric progression with time. Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. 
  • Stationary phase (Marked as C): Cell division stops due to depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products. Its a state of equilibrium, where the number of new cells forms equals the number of cells that die. Sporulation occurs during this phase. Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products such as exotoxins and antibiotics.
  • Phase of decline (Marked as D): In this phase, the population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation, and the action of autolytic enzymes. Involution forms are common.

Other options:

A rapid increase in bacterial cell size is a feature of the Lag phase (Phase A)

Viable and non-culturable cells are seen in stationary phase (phase C)

Fastidious organisms are difficult to grow because of their specific growth requirements, they are less likely to grow fast.

questions.text: An infant is brought to the casualty with the symptom given below. MRI revealed the agenesis of a crucial cranial structure. Which part of this structure give rise to tapetum?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing infantile spasms is suggestive of Aicardi syndrome, an X-linked dominant disorder associated with agenesis of the corpus callosum. The fibres of the tapetum originate from both the body and splenium of the corpus callosum.

Related Pearl: Corpus Callosum

Parts of the corpus callosum:

  • Rostrum: connects frontal lobes (eg: orbitofrontal cortex)
  • Genu: connects frontal lobes. It is the anterior-most part.
  • Trunk or Body: connects temporal lobes.
  • Splenium: connects the two occipital lobes. It is the thickest part.

Note: Isthmus is a part which separates the body from splenium, some books mention it as a part.

  • The fibers of the genu curve forward into frontal lobes and form forceps minor.
  • The fibers of the trunk extend laterally as radiation of corpus callosum.
  • The fibers from the trunk and the splenium which form the lateral wall of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle constitute the tapetum.
  • The fibers from the splenium arching backwards into the occipital lobe form forceps major.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about disulfiram?

choices.text: When used with alcohol, the patients feels drowsy, with chest discomfort and respiratory depression
It can be initiated even in minimally motivated person
Its action persists up to 2-3 days after stopping the drug

questions.solution:
Disulfiram is used in behavioural modification technique for alcohol de-addiction. The principle of action is aversive conditioning.

Disulfiram is an irreversible inhibitor of both cytosolic and mitochondrial forms of aldehyde dehydrogenase. Ethanol consumption during disulfiram therapy can lead to increased concentrations of acetaldehyde. Increased acetaldehyde levels can cause flushing, pulsating headache, throbbing pain in head and neck, nausea, vomiting, rashes, respiratory difficulties, chest pain, autonomic manifestations and other aversive reactions.

Disulfiram can only be given to highly motivated individuals. Disulfiram should not be administered until the person has abstained from alcohol for at least 12 hours. The disulfiram-alcohol reaction may occur as long as 14 days after the last dose of disulfiram.

Disulfiram like reaction with alcohol ingestion is also seen with the following drugs:

  • Metronidazole
  • Sulfonylureas like chlorpropamide
  • Cephalosporins like cefoperazone, cefamandole

Other modalities of treatment:

  • Pharmacotherapy: Typically 5-10 days, treatment for detoxification: Benzodiazepine and chlordiazepoxide are the drugs of choice.
  • Rehabilitation programs: Typically 28-day programs, learn about relapse prevention and identification of triggers.
  • Maintenance phase: Baclofen, Acamprosate, Naltrexone, Topiramate, SSRI, Ondansetron
  • Psychotherapy: Group therapy such as Alcoholics Anonymous

questions.text: A three-year-old boy was brought to the ENT outpatient department by his mother. She reports that for the past few days, the boy has had loud, raspy, and noisy breathing. She also says that his voice has become hoarse over the past 3-4 months. He was born at term through an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. Fibreoptic laryngoscopy findings are given below. Which of the following is not true about this condition?

choices.text: It is caused by HPV type 6 and 11
Most common benign neoplasm of larynx in children

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing a three-year-old child with stridor and hoarseness of voice and laryngoscopy showing a laryngeal papilloma is highly suggestive of respiratory papillomatosis/juvenile papillomatosis. It mostly affects the supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx. 

Respiratory papillomatosis / Juvenile papillomatosis:

  • It is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • It is caused by the human papilloma DNA virus types 6 and 11. 
  • Mothers with vaginal human papillomavirus are presumed to transmit the disease at birth to their children.
  • It most commonly involves the supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx. They can also appear in the subglottic, trachea and bronchi.
  • Clinical features:
    • Age 3–5 years
    • Hoarseness or aphonia
    • Respiratory difficulty
    • Stridor
  • Diagnosis is made by flexible fibreoptic laryngoscopy which shows characteristic warty growths and is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy.
  • Malignant change is rare but the recurrence rate is high.
  • DNA virus particles have been found in the cells of the basement membrane of the respiratory mucosa and may account for widespread involvement and recurrence.
  • Treatment consists of micro-laryngoscopy and CO2 laser Excision.
  • Tumour can be removed under a microscope with cup forceps or a debride similar to the one used in endoscopic nasal surgery in the absence of CO2 lasers.
  • Interferon-alpha-2α and 13-cis-retinoic acid have shown promising results but have several side effects.

questions.text:
Match the following hormones to their respective receptor's target of action.
Hormone Target
1. Thyroid hormone A. Receptor tyrosine kinase 
2. Insulin B. Adenylyl cyclase
3. Atrial natriuretic peptide C. Intracellular receptor
4. Norepinephrine D. Guanylyl cyclase
questions.solution:
The correct option is Option 3: 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

Thyroid hormones act on intracellular receptors (intracytoplasmic or intranuclear) to induce the transcription of selected mRNAs, thereby promoting protein synthesis. Other hormones with similar action include steroid hormones and retinoic acid.

Insulin activates the tyrosine kinase enzyme on the intracellular (cytoplasmic) portions of transmembrane receptors, thereby phosphorylating the receptor. Other hormones with similar action include EGF, PDGF, M-CSF

Atrial natriuretic peptide increases intracellular cGMP by activating the enzyme guanylyl cyclase. A similar mechanism of action is seen with nitric oxide (NO).

Norepinephrine acts on intracellular adenylyl cyclase enzyme via beta-1 (adenylyl cyclase activation to increase cAMP) and alpha-2 (adenylyl cyclase inhibition to decrease cAMP). It activates phospholipase C and increases the production of DAG, IP3, via alpha-1 receptors.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was brought to the emergency room with complaints of continuous watery diarrhea that started 20 hours ago. On examination, he is drowsy and unresponsive. questions.text: A 2-week-old girl born at 35 weeks of gestation presents with lethargy and bilious vomiting for the past one day. She has diffuse abdominal distension and a sunken anterior fontanelle. Bowel movements were normal prior to this but she now has bloody stool. Her plain abdominal X-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a premature infant presenting with lethargy, bilious vomiting, diffuse abdominal distension, dehydration, and bloody stool with an X-ray showing gas in the bowel wall is likely to have necrotizing enterocolitis.

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a rapidly progressing disease causing extensive bowel necrosis, infection, and perforation in newborns. Premature, low-birth-weight (LBW) infants are at an increased risk for developing this life-threatening emergency. 

Pathogenesis of this condition involves mucosal ischemia that progresses to necrosis. Subsequently, there is gaseous accumulation in the bowel submucosa termed as pneumatosis intestinalis that can be further complicated by perforation, peritonitis, sepsis, and eventual death. 

Patients have feeding intolerance, vomiting, and associated dehydration (sunken fontanelle), abdominal distension, occult/gross blood in stool, and temperature instability.

Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall). Gas may be sometimes visualized in the portal venous tree. NE cases complicated by perforation may show pneumoperitoneum (gas under diaphragm) on abdominal x-ray. 

Other options:

Option A- A duodenal atresia is a form of intestinal atresia that presents with symptoms of gastric outlet obstruction, bilious vomiting, and dehydration. Abdominal x-ray findings show a classic double-bubble sign due to duodenal and gastric distension with no air distal to the point of obstruction. 

Option B- Cystic fibrosis (CF) is associated with meconium ileus, wherein the meconium becomes impacted in the distal small bowel. There is a failure to pass meconium in the first 24 hours after birth. CF patients also present with abdominal distension and bilious emesis but abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

The below image shows a contrast enema image demonstrating a microcolon. 

Option D- Intussusception is characterized by the invagination of a proximal bowel segment (usually, the ileum) into the segment distal to it (ascending colon). It is commonly seen in children between the age of 6 to 9 months and presents with colicky abdominal pain and passage of red-currant-jelly stool. Barium enema findings include a classic claw sign or coiled spring sign that represents the telescoping intestinal segment. Ultrasound imaging demonstrates the target sign which shows the telescoping segment surrounded by the lumen of the adjacent intestinal segment. It is shown in the image below.

questions.text: An immunologist while conducting an experiment on anaphylaxis notices varied reactions with different routes of administration of the shocking dose. Identify the correct order of effectiveness of a shocking dose in causing anaphylaxis based on its route of administration?
questions.solution:
The shocking dose is most effective in Intravenous > Subcutaneous >intradermal routes (least) in causing anaphylaxis.

Anaphylaxis is a Type I hypersensitivity syndrome. There are 2 clinical syndromes which are:

  • Anaphylaxis is an acute, potentially fatal systemic form
  • Atopy is the chronic, recurrent, non-fatal, localized form

Priming dose - For induction of hypersensitivity reactions, the host should have contact with the antigen, leading to the priming of the appropriate B or T lymphocytes. 

Shocking dose - Subsequent contact with allergen causing manifestations of hypersensitivity. The shocking dose is most effective in Intravenous > intraperitoneally or Subcutaneously >intradermally (Least).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the structure marked below in the histological image of the cerebellum?

choices.text: Stellate cells form excitatory synapses on them
They are the only efferents of cerebellar cortex
They receive excitatory input from the climbing fibres

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is a Purkinje cell in the cerebellar cortex and the false statement is that stellate cells form excitatory synapses on them. Stellate cells form inhibitory synapses on Purkinje cells.

Purkinje cells are the flask-shaped cells present in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellum. They are evenly spaced and arranged in a single layer. A dendrite arises from each cell, which passes upward to enter the molecular layer, which then branches extensively to form a dendritic tree.

The axon of each cell passes downwards and crosses the granular cell layer to enter the white matter terminating on the deep cerebellar nuclei. They are inhibitory to these cerebellar nuclei. Axons of Purkinje cells are the only efferents of the cerebellar cortex.

They receive excitatory input from the climbing fibres from the inferior olivary nucleus. Purkinje cells are inhibitory and use GABA as their neurotransmitter.

Pathological significance:

  • Negri bodies in rabies are usually found as eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusions in the neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells.
  • Loss of Purkinje cells and granule cells is seen in ataxia-telangiectasia.
  • In patients with subacute cerebellar degeneration, there is the destruction of Purkinje cells. Some patients show circulating PCA­1 antibody (anti­Yo) against Purkinje cells.
  • Purkinje cells and neurons in pyramidal cell layers of the hippocampus and cerebral cortex are the most sensitive neurons to hypoxia and are likely to be damaged in cases of global cerebral ischemia.

Related Pearl: Layers of the cerebellar cortex

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contain flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the cerebellar nuclei.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches form the T and are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Neurotransmitters released:

  • Stellate, basket, Golgi and Purkinje cells- GABA
  • Granule cells - Glutamate

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the Purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: Diamox is given to a patient with glaucoma. It is a non-competitive inhibitor of the carbonic anhydrase enzyme. Which of the following would be the effect of this drug?

choices.text: Decrease in both Km and Vmax

questions.solution:
Non-competitive inhibitors cause a decrease in Vmax.

In non-competitive inhibition:

  • The inhibitor binds to the adjacent site and not the catalytic site of the enzyme
  • The catalytic property of the enzyme is reduced and hence Vmax is decreased
  • The affinity of the enzyme is not altered and hence Km is unaltered

questions.text: Which of the following is the dose of vitamin A prophylaxis given to children between the ages of 1-5 years under the vitamin A distribution scheme in India?
questions.solution:
Under the vitamin-A distribution scheme in India, 200000 IU of vitamin A are given orally at 6-monthly intervals between the ages 1-5 years.

Vitamin A deficiency is a major public health problem among the lower-income population in India. Thus, India has a national program for the prevention of nutritional blindness. The beneficiaries include all pre-school children between 1-5 years of age.

The program focuses on the following things:

  1. Promoting intake of vitamin A-rich foods among preschool children, pregnant, and lactating mothers. The program also promotes appropriate breastfeeding.
  2. Supplementation of vitamin A in preschool children. The first dose of 100000 IU is given at 9 months of age with MMR vaccine. Subsequent doses of 200000 IU are given every 6 months till the age of 5 years.
  3. Prompt treatment of xerophthalmia at health facilities. Locally trained primary health workers are trained to treat a wide range of eye conditions like acute conjunctivitis, ophthalmia neonatorum, trachoma, and superficial foreign bodies.
  4. Supplementation of vitamin A (one dose) in children suffering from measles or severe malnutrition

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes with complaints of fatigue and weight loss. An image of her thyroid scan is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the thyroid scan showing a diffusely increased uptake of radioactive iodine and an enlarged size of the gland is suggestive of Grave’s disease.

A thyroid scan helps to differentiate between a hot nodule and a cold nodule. Thyroid nodules that absorb radioiodine are called hot nodules. These nodules produce excess thyroid hormones. Whereas, the thyroid nodules that do not absorb radioiodine are called cold nodules and they indicate non-functional nodules.

Appearance of thyroid scan in other thyroid disorders:

Multinodular goiter demonstrates multiple areas of both increased and decreased uptake of radioiodine, indicating the presence of both functioning and nonfunctioning nodules.

Toxic adenoma demonstrates a focal area of increased uptake of radioiodine.

Thyroiditis shows a decreased uptake of radioiodine due to follicle damage.

Related Pearl: Radioiodine uptake of thyroid gland

Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scans are interpreted as follows:

  • High (or normal) radioiodine uptake indicates de-novo synthesis of the hormone. Therefore, there is increased hormone synthesis
  • Low (nearly absent) radioiodine uptake indicates:
    • Inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue with release of the preformed hormone into the circulation
    • Extrathyroidal source of thyroid hormone

  • Toxic multinodular goiter
  • Toxic adenoma

  • Hydatidiform mole
  • TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the pharmacological profile of nitrates?

choices.text: They act by increasing cGMP levels

questions.solution:
Nitrates are not safe to use in combination with sildenafil. Sildenafil increases cGMP levels by inhibiting phosphodiesterase- 5. Therefore combining nitrates with sildenafil has a risk of severe hypotension. 

Mechanism of action- Nitrates are denitrated to release nitric oxide (NO). This NO activates the enzyme guanylyl cyclase which increases intracellular cyclic GMP (cGMP) levels. cGMP causes dephosphorylation of myosin light-chain (MLC) which causes smooth muscle relaxation. Their therapeutic effects include venodilation (increased venous capacitance) and decreased platelet aggregation. They are used to treat angina. 

Adverse effects of nitrates-

Increased venous capacitance leads to orthostatic hypotension, reflex tachycardia, and headache. 

Tolerance develops with continuous nitrate exposure. This means that as the patient becomes more tolerant to the drug, they require increasing doses to maintain the same therapeutic effects. The property of tolerance is commonly seen with long-acting nitrate preparations (oral, transdermal) or with continuous nitrate infusions. 

Large doses of nitrates can cause methemoglobinemia. It is treated with intravenous methylene blue.

Note- Nitrates were initially also used in the treatment of cyanide poisoning. Nitrates convert hemoglobin to methemoglobin. These methemoglobin combine with cyanide ions to form cyanmethemoglobin. The cyanomethemoglobin produced can be further detoxified by the intravenous administration of sodium thiosulfate. Currently, hydroxocobalamin, a form of vitamin B12 is widely used in the treatment of cyanide poisoning.

questions.text: A middle-aged diabetic man who had undergone a tooth extraction presents with fever and trismus. On examination, his posterior pillar is pushed medially and there is a swelling in the neck at the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. What is the most likely diagnosis?

  1. Occlusion of the biliary tree with no leak
  2. Bile leak from the cystic duct
  3. Bile leak from main bile duct

questions.solution:
Option C is correctly matched.

The Strasberg classification of bile duct injury is a widely used system to anatomically define these injuries by location.

Classification

  • Type A: Bile leak from the cystic duct or from minor hepatic ducts draining the liver bed
  • Type B: Occlusion of the biliary tree with no leak. Commonly right aberrant hepatic ducts or right posterior sectoral duct.
  • Type C: Bile leak from right aberrant hepatic ducts or right posterior sectoral duct
  • Type D: Bile leak from main bile duct without major tissue loss.
  • Type E: Injury to the main hepatic duct; classified according to the level of injury
    • E1: Injury more than 2 cm from the confluence
    • E2: Injury less than 2 cm from the confluence
    • E3: Injury at the confluence; confluence intact
    • E4: Destruction of the biliary confluence
    • E5: Injury to the main bile duct and the aberrant right hepatic duct

questions.text:
A 19-year-old girl comes for treatment of hirsutism. She has irregular periods. She is obese and has facial acne as well. Androstenedione and testosterone levels are elevated. LH levels are raised and FSH is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for the condition?

LH- Luteinizing hormone 

FSH- Follicle-stimulating hormone

OCP- Oral contraceptive pills
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of hirsutism, irregular periods, acne, and obesity with elevated androgens, normal FSH, and raised LH are suggestive of polycystic ovary disease (PCOD). In PCOD, the drug used for hirsutism and acne is OCPs with cyproterone acetate. Cyproterone has an anti-androgenic effect.

Management of PCOD is individualized. Weight reduction and lifestyle changes are the first-line therapy for PCOD. In a woman who is not planning for pregnancy, the management mainly involves treatment of irregular periods and hirsutism. Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation pills with 30 mcg E2 and 2-3 mg drospirenone are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. Hirsutism and acne are managed with OCP with cyproterone acetate and topical agents such as eflornithine, clindamycin lotion 1%, erythromycin gel 2%, and isoretinoin. 

Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin and acarbose. Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Surgical management includes laparoscopic ovarian drilling (LOD)in resistant cases and bariatric surgery in morbidly obese patients.

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)/ Polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD): It is also known as Stein-Leventhal syndrome.

It is a multisystem, metabolic, endocrine dysfunction that commonly occurs among women in the reproductive age group. It has multifactorial causation, such as lifestyle changes, stress, diet, obesity, and hyperinsulinemic states.

Important clinical features of PCOS are:

  • Menstrual abnormalities (70%) - oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea, or dysfunctional uterine bleeding. Dysmenorrhoea is absent.
  • Obesity
  • Hirsutism, acne, and alopecia due to hyperandrogenism
  • Acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance
  • Infertility

Rotterdam criterion is used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Oligo/amenorrhoea, anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries (USG findings)

Investigations:

  2. USG is diagnostic of PCOS- It shows enlarged ovaries with multiple follicles in the periphery. It also rules out other pathologies like ovarian tumors, endometrial hyperplasia, etc.
  3. Laparoscopy (therapeutic). It reveals bilateral enlarged ovarian cysts.

Ultrasound image below shows an enlarged ovary with multiple follicles in the periphery.

Note:

PCOS in association with diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia and cardiovascular disease presenting in reproductive age group is known as "X syndrome".

HAIR-AN syndrome in patients with PCOS is characterized by HyperAndrogenism, Insulin Resistance and Acanthosis Nigricans.

questions.text: A thin, 34-year-old male, presents with sharp pain and sudden onset dyspnea. Chest X-ray was performed and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given chest radiograph clearly depicts the presence of pneumothorax, which represents air in the pleural space.

  • The right hemithorax shows blackening (depicts area of low density) due to the presence of air.
  • The visceral pleural line has separated from the chest wall by a transradiant zone devoid of vessels.
  • The collapsed lung can be seen with a clear border.
  • There is a mediastinal shift to the left side (contralateral), which is typically seen with cases of tension pneumothorax. 

All the above features are suggestive of pneumothorax.

Note: Pleural effusions signify the presence of fluid accumulation in the pleural space. The fluid may have varying degrees of mobility depending on the nature of effusion (free-flowing or loculated).

While a small amount of free fluid is usually hard to detect on an erect PA chest x-ray, a significant pleural effusion (200-500 mL) is represented by obscured lateral and posterior costophrenic angles and the hemidiaphragm affected. Subsequently, homogenous opacification of the lower lung field develops, associated with concave superior margin relative to the lung. This margin is higher laterally than medially. 

A massive pleural effusion cause dense opacification usually associated with a contralteral mediastinal shift. 

Here is an image of a left-sided pleural effusion representing the homogenous opacification of the left lower and middle lung fields. There is associated blunting of the left sided costophrenic angle. The superior border of the effusion is concave and is higher laterally than medially.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient becomes confused and drowsy and has one episode of vomiting post thyroidectomy surgery. On examination, she has a temperature of 100 degrees F along with tremors of the hand. Laboratory reports reveal elevated thyroid hormone levels. The best drug for the immediate management of this condition is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with features of fever, CNS depression, vomiting, and elevated thyroid hormones following surgery is suggestive of thyroid storm. Propylthiouracil, which inhibits thyroid synthesis and also inhibits peripheral conversion of T4 to T3, is the best drug for the immediate management of this case.

Thyroid storm/ Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is a rare but severe life-threatening complication of hyperthyroidism induced by the release of excessive thyroid hormones.

Causes:

  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Infection
  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy.
  • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
  • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Amiodarone administration
  • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
  • Following RAI (radioactive iodine) therapy

Features:

  • They present 12–24 hours after surgery with hyperpyrexia and severe dehydration
  • Cardiovascular: Circulatory collapse, hypotension, palpitations, tachycardia, cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac failure
  • GI symptoms: vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice.
  • Neurological symptoms: restlessness, irritability, delirium, tremor, convulsions, and coma 

Treatment:

  • Supportive measures – rehydration by proper fluid therapy, tepid sponging, cooling blankets
  • Thionamides like Propylthiouracil (PTU) or methimazole or carbimazole are used. They inhibit thyroid hormone synthesis. Propylthiouracil also inhibits the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. Hence, PTU is the preferred drug in thyroid storm. However, the risk for severe liver injury and acute liver failure associated with PTU therapy makes either carbimazole or methimazole first-choice thionamide in patients with deranged liver function tests.
  • Lugol’s iodide is given one hour after intake of thionamides. They inhibit thyroid hormone synthesis by Wolff- Chaikoff effect. Large doses of iodide inhibit organic binding of the iodide and hence decrease thyroid hormone synthesis.
  • Propranolol is used to reduce tachycardia and other adrenergic manifestations. It also reduces the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.
  • Glucocorticoids – reduce the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 and controls the shock. 
  • Digitoxin, cardiac monitoring is crucial.

As per the references, there are certain discrepancies over the drug of choice being an anti-thyroid drug (PTU) or a beta-blocker(Propranolol). However, as per the recent updates, PROPRANOLOL is primarily indicated in HYPERTHYROIDISM (not in thyroid crisis) because it has limited effect and slow onset for reducing serum T3 conversion. Additionally, in cases where deiodinase inhibition is significant (in cases of severe hyperthyroidism) like in THYROID CRISIS/ THYROTOXICOSIS an anti-thyroid drug is considered as the therapeutic drug (DOC), thus the answer to this MCQ is PTU and NOT PROPRANOLOL.

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient has undergone cataract surgery in his right eye 2 years back. Initially, after the surgery, his vision was good but started experiencing a progressive diminution in his vision for the past 3 months. Examination of his right eye is shown below. Which of the following laser is used in managing this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the image are suggestive of a posterior capsular opacification (PCO). It is managed by Nd: YAG laser capsulotomy.

PCO, also called 'after' or 'secondary' cataracts, is the opacification that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens. This happens because, some amount of lens particles are left in situ during surgery, which proliferates and gets opacified, resulting in the formation of an after-cataract. If the newly formed fibers are enclosed between the two layers of the lens, a dense ring is formed behind the iris. This is named 'the ring of Sommerring'.Instead, if the cells proliferate to form large-balloon-like cells, filling the pupillary aperture, they are called Elschnig pearls.

Management of after-cataract:

Management of an after-cataract depends upon its thickness. A thin one can be cleared by Nd: YAG capsulotomy. The thicker ones are managed by, cutting with a Ziegler knife and the cut fragments are aspirated by a vitreous cutter.

The given image below shows the presence of a white ring behind the iris with the likely diagnosis being Soemmering’s ring.

 

The below image shows Elschnig’s pearls which are vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells, clustered like soap bubbles along the posterior capsule of the lens.

questions.text: Human herpesvirus 8 is associated with all except ______.
questions.solution:
Adult T-cell leukemia is caused by HTLV-1 (and not HHV8).

Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV8), also known as Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV), is lymphotropic virus and is closely related to Ebstein–Barr virus (EBV).

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented with abdominal pain, bloody stools, and elevated blood pressure. He is a known case of chronic hepatitis B. The arterial biopsy finding of this patient is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the chronic hepatitis B infection and arterial biopsy findings of fibrinoid necrosis suggests a likely diagnosis of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). 

Polyarteritis nodosa is a vasculitis syndrome that causes segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation in small and medium-sized arteries. It is often superimposed with aneurysm or thrombosis. 

About one-third of the patients with PAN are noted to have chronic hepatitis B which causes the formation of HBsAg-HbsAb immune complexes being deposited in the vessel walls.

Histologically, during the acute phase, there is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall along with fibrinoid necrosis and luminal thrombosis. Fibrinoid necrosis is usually the result of the deposition of immune complexes and plasma proteins in the arterial wall. On biopsy, fibrinoid necrosis appears as bright pink and amorphous deposits in the vessel wall. 

Clinical features include rapidly accelerating hypertension caused by the involvement of renal arteries, abdominal pain, and bloody stools due to vascular gastrointestinal lesions. 

Other options:

Option A- Hyperplastic arteriosclerosis is a vascular pathology seen in severe hypertension. Arterial biopsy findings show an onion-skin appearance that consists of a concentric arrangement of smooth muscle cells with a thickened and re-duplicated basement membrane.

The image below shows the characteristic onion skin appearance of a renal arteriole.

Option C- Monckeberg medial sclerosis is a vascular pathology of aging characterized by calcifications accumulating in the medial layers of muscular arteries. Since there is no vascular compromise (no luminal narrowing), it is usually an accidental finding.

The image below shows calcific deposits (deep purple on H&E staining) in the arterial wall.

Option D- Giant cell arteritis/temporal arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis affecting large- to small-sized arteries of the head and is commonly seen in the elderly. Patients usually present with constitutional symptoms and symptoms specific to the artery involved:

  • cerebral artery, temporal artery- facial pain, headache
  • ophthalmic artery- sudden onset visual loss, diplopia

Arterial biopsy findings consist of granulomatous inflammation with internal elastic lamina fragmentation and T-cell infiltration. The image below shows internal elastic lamina fragmentation (black arrow) and giant cells (yellow arrow) in a cerebral artery.

questions.text: As part of a research program, a community is being tested by three screening tests for COVID-19. The patient is considered diseased if he/she tests positive in any one of the screening tests. Which of the following is false about this pattern of screening?
questions.solution:
The given scenario shows a number of screening tests being conducted in parallel, where the net specificity is low. 

The combination of two or more tests performed together can help to enhance the efficacy of detecting the presence or absence of disease. There are two principal forms of combination of tests:

Screening tests used in series:

  • If a patient is considered to have a disease when he is positive by every test conducted, then the tests are said to be in series.
  • If the patient tests negative in any one or more of the tests, they are classified as non-diseased.
  • It is thus difficult to classify a patient as diseased and easier to classify a patient as non-diseased.
  • This increases the number of false negatives.

Screening tests used in parallel:

  • Tests are said to be in parallel when a positive result on any one or more tests is considered sufficient to classify a patient into the diseased group.
  • A subject is considered nondiseased only when they test negative by all the tests.
  • Hence, some without disease are more likely to be wrongly classified into the diseased group, but many without disease are correctly excluded.
  Tests in Series Tests in parallel

Combined specificity Increases Decreases
Combined PPV Increases Decreases
Combined NPV Decreases Increases

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is emotionally cold, self-absorbed, and pre-occupied with fantasies. He often remains alone, detached from social relationships, and prefers solitary activities. Which cluster of personality disorders does this person belong to?
questions.solution:
An emotionally cold young man preferring loneliness is indicative of a schizoid personality.  Schizoid personality is classified as a Cluster A personality disorder.

Cluster A: Odd, aloof features. It includes three personality disorders:

  • Paranoid
  • Schizoid
  • Schizotypal

Schizoid personality :

A person who shows a lifelong pattern of being socially distant is said to have a schizoid personality. People with this personality disorder are often introverted, uncomfortable with interactions, and have a bland affect.

Diagnosis: The presence of four or more of the following features which are not attributed to a medical condition indicate schizoid personality:

  • Devoid of close relationships
  • An inclination towards solitary activities
  • Decreased if not any interest in sexual activities
  • Finds pleasure in very few activities
  • Small social circle limited to first degree relatives
  • Indifferent to praise/criticism
  • Blunt affect

Treatment:

  • Psychotherapy
  • Pharmacotherapy is administered in some patients when needed:
    • Low doses of antipsychotics or antidepressants 
    • Benzodiazepines can be used for anxiety

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presented with complaints of abdominal discomfort and dark-coloured stools for the past 2 months. Investigations revealed microcytic hypochromic anemia. A barium swallow radiograph revealed a leather bottle appearance on the stomach. Histopathological examination showed diffuse infiltration of the stomach wall and cells with a signet ring appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario with leather bottle appearance of the stomach in barium swallow and the signet ring cells in histopathology, the most likely diagnosis is diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma.

Gastric adenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumour and comprises more than 90% of all stomach malignancies.

Patients with gastric cancer present with unexplained weight loss, abdominal discomfort, upper GI bleeding (hematemesis and melena), anemia, early satiety and anorexia. Based on the gross appearance, it is classified into two types:

  • Diffuse: characterized by gastric wall thickening due to infiltrates
  • Intestinal: associated with malignant masses composed of glandular structures

Diffuse adenocarcinoma is characterised by a diffuse infiltrative growth pattern leading to the thickened stomach wall with diffuse rugal flattening. Barium studies reveal a leather bottle appearance as shown in the image below, also known as linitis plastica.

Most gastric cancers do not follow any pattern of hereditary inheritance. However, loss-of-function mutation of the CDH-1 gene results in the loss of E-cadherin which plays a vital role in the pathogenesis of diffuse gastric cancer. Mutation of TP53 is found in a majority of sporadic gastric cancers of both diffuse and intestinal types.

Histopathology shows diffuse infiltration of the gastric wall with signet ring-shaped cells. The cells are so named because intracellular mucin displaces the nuclei to the periphery of the tumour cells. 

The below H&E-stained image shows normal gastric mucosa (red arrow) and the characteristic signet cells (green arrows) in a patient with diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma.

The most effective predictors of the prognosis of gastric cancer are the depth of tumour invasion and metastasis.

Surgical resection and lymph node clearance is the mainstay treatment in early gastric cancers. When there is local invasion into the duodenum, pancreas, and retroperitoneum, treatment is focused on chemotherapy, radiotherapy and palliative care.

Other options:

Menetrier's disease is a hypertrophic gastropathy characterized by massive overgrowth of mucous cells (foveolar cells) lining the stomach, resulting in large gastric folds with antral sparing. It is associated with hypoproteinemia, weight loss and diarrhoea and an increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma.

Gastric leiomyosarcoma is a type of mesenchymal tumour commonly grouped under GIST(gastrointestinal stromal tumour) and is named according to its resemblance with smooth muscle tumours and usually positive for CD117(c-kit) in immunohistochemistry. The patients present with mucosal bleeding, anaemia and mass effects.

Gastric lymphomas are extranodal B cell lymphomas arising in cases of chronic gastritis and are positive for CD19, CD20 and CD43. Patients present with upper GI bleeding and dyspepsia due to H.pylori infection.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented with progressive muscular weakness showing the following finding. It was found that the child is unable to get up from a squatting position. He was diagnosed with a hereditary muscular disorder. What is the mode of inheritance in this disorder?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette includes an image of a child with pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles along with a history of inability to get up from a squatting position. This is characteristically seen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is an X-linked recessive disorder.

Salient features of Duchenne muscular dystrophy:

  • Most common hereditary neuromuscular disease.
  • X-linked recessive mutations of dystrophin gene on chromosome Xp21.

Clinical features:

  • Progressive weakness, developmental delay, and intellectual impairment
  • In toddlers: delayed walking, falling, toe walking, and trouble running or walking upstairs
  • Common sites of muscular hypertrophy: calf > tongue > forearm
  • Pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles due to fibrofatty replacement of muscle
  • Gower's sign: Patients use their arms and hands to walk up their own body from a squatting position due to the reduced strength in the proximal muscles(hip &thigh) of the lower limbs.
  • Trendelenburg gait/hip waddle
  • Inability to walk develops by the age of 10-14 years.
  • Complications: Contractures, scoliosis, cardiomyopathy, malignant hyperthermia after anaesthesia.
  • Death occurs by 3rd decade of life due to respiratory failure.

Note:

Becker's Muscular Dystrophy (BMD) vs. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD)

Mnemonic-

  • BMD: Badly makes dystrophin (defective)
  • DMD: Does not make dystrophin (absent)

questions.text: A patient is confused, opens his eyes to painful stimuli,  flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. The light reflex of the right and left eye are shown. His GCS-P score is ________
questions.solution:
The GCS-P (Glasgow Coma Scale with pupil reactivity score) score in this patient is 9.

In this case,

  • The score for verbal response: 4, because he is confused
  • The score for eye-opening: 2, because his eyes are opening to a painful stimulus only.
  • The motor score for flexing limbs in response to a painful stimulus is 4 and localising the pain stimulus is 5. However, only the highest score (i.e. score for the best performance elicited) will be taken into account. Therefore, the score for best motor response is 5.

Therefore, the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is (4+2+5) = 11.

The image demonstrates the absence of pupillary constriction on exposure to light and the inference is "both the pupils not reactive to light". So, the pupil reactivity score (P) is 2.

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value of GCS-P. Therefore, the GCS-P score is 11-2 = 9.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presented with a history of heartburn after heavy meals for the past 4 years. A biopsy of the lower esophageal mucosa is obtained by upper gastrointestinal endoscopy. The microscopic picture is shown below. What is the most likely cellular adaptation observed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing the replacement of stratified squamous epithelium with intestinal-type columnar epithelium with goblet cells is suggestive of Barret's esophagus. The most likely cellular adaptation observed is metaplasia. 

Metaplasia is a reversible cellular adaptation characterized by the replacement of one differentiated cell type (epithelial or mesenchymal) by another cell type. It usually represents an adaptive response in which one cell type is replaced by another more capable of handling the stressor. 

The various types of metaplasia are:

  • Squamous metaplasia - 
    • Airways - normal pseudostratified epithelium is replaced by the squamous epithelium. It may occur due to chronic smoking or a deficiency of retinoic acid
    • Urinary bladder - normal transitional epithelium is replaced by squamous epithelium. It may occur due to bladder stones 
  • Columnar metaplasia - 
    • Esophagus - normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by the glandular columnar epithelium (Barret's esophagus). It may occur in patients with chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease
  • Connective tissue metaplasia - 
    • Muscle - formation of bone in the muscle tissue; the condition is known as myositis ossificans. This may occur secondary to intramuscular hemorrhage

The images below show squamous and columnar metaplasia, respectively. 

Other options:

Option B: Hyperplasia is a cellular adaptation characterized by an increase in the number of cells, thereby, resulting in an increase in organ size. Such an example is the glandular hyperplasia of the female breast during puberty and pregnancy.

Option C: Atrophy is a decrease in the size of the tissue or organ due to the reduction in the cell number and size. Such an example is muscle atrophy after nerve injury.

Option D: Dysplasia is a cellular adaptation characterized by disordered cellular architecture (increased mitoses, increased nucleus: cytoplasm ratio) and growth that predisposes to malignancy.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with complaints of sudden jerky movements of his hands, which is present even when he is asleep. There is also a history of impaired memory. He underwent a corneal transplant 6 months ago. His electroencephalogram showed periodic sharp waves. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly man with a history of corneal transplant presenting with myoclonic jerks, signs of dementia (impaired memory), periodic sharp waves on the electroencephalogram is suggestive of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a prion disease that causes higher cortical function deficits. This infection can be acquired by corneal transplantation, contaminated electroencephalogram (EEG) electrode implantation, dura mater grafts, and contaminated human growth hormone (hGH) preparations.

Patients commonly present with myoclonus and dementia. EEG shows characteristic periodic bursts of diffuse, high-amplitude sharp waves (as shown below). 


MRI shows increased intensity in the basal ganglia and cortical ribboning (ribbon-like signal hyperintensity of cerebral cortical gyri). On light microscopy, the pathologic hallmarks of CJD are spongiform degeneration and astrocytic gliosis.

The given image shows the MRI findings in a CJD patient:


Other options:

Option A: Sturge Weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous syndrome characterized by angiomas of the leptomeninges and in the ophthalmic and maxillary nerve areas of distribution. Affected patients might have developmental delay, learning difficulties, and seizures. CT shows the presence of a tram-track appearance.

Option C: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a progressive demyelinating disease of the brain that occurs due to a previous infection with the measles virus. Most patients have a history of measles infection many years ago. SSPE presents with intellectual disability, poor school performance, and mood and personality changes. EEG shows high voltage slow sharp waves that occur every 3-8 seconds followed by a flat background.

Option D: Patients with tuberous sclerosis present with seizures, mental retardation, adenoma sebaceum (facial angiofibromas), shagreen patch, hypomelanotic macules, periungual fibromas, renal angiomyolipomas, and cardiac rhabdomyomas. Imaging may show the presence of subependymal nodules, cortical tubers, and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with widely distributed flaccid bullae. Histopathology shows a suprabasal acantholytic blister with superficial dermal infiltration by lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophils. Direct immunofluorescence for immunoglobulin IgG is as seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical finding of bullae and the given histological features with a characteristic fish-net appearance in the immunofluorescence assay seen in the image are highly suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris.

Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic autoimmune blistering disease characterized by the presence of antibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins (predominantly desmoglein 3). 

In pemphigus vulgaris, the location of the target antigen is intraepithelial. The bullae (blisters) of pemphigus vulgaris occur due to the destruction within the epidermis. Flaccid blisters are filled with clear fluid and may rupture, producing painful erosions.

This fish-net appearance of pemphigus vulgaris is due to anti-desmoglein IgG antibodies deposited on the desmosomes (Dsg3 > Dsg1), which are present intercellularly. Direct immunofluorescence of skin samples with anti-IgG shows intercellular IgG deposits in the epidermis.

It occurs most commonly in middle-aged women, and the most common presentation of pemphigus vulgaris is oral lesions. Cutaneous lesions develop later, with lesions occuring most commonly on the scalp, face, neck, upper chest and back. 

They also show a positive Nikolsky sign, which is peeling off of the epidermis even on slight rubbing of the skin.

questions.text: The excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) and inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) are respectively caused by:
questions.solution:
The excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) and inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) are caused by Na+ influx and Cl- influx, respectively.

EPSP is produced when the interior of the post-synaptic neuron is more positive than normal, which is excitatory. It occurs due to the opening of the sodium channels causing Na+ influx. When the EPSP reaches the threshold potential, an action potential is generated.

IPSP is produced when the interior of the post-synaptic neuron is more negative. It may occur due to:

  • Opening of chloride channels causing Cl- influx.
  • Increased outward conductance through potassium channels causing K+ efflux.

Related Pearl: Comparison between EPSP vs IPSP

EPSP is an electrical charge on the postsynaptic membrane, which is caused by the binding of excitatory neurotransmitters and makes the postsynaptic membrane more likely to generate an action potential. IPSP is an electric charge on the postsynaptic membrane, which is caused by the binding of inhibitory neurotransmitters and makes the postsynaptic membrane less likely to generate an action potential.
EPSP is caused by Influx of Na+ or Ca2+ ions IPSP is caused by Influx of Cl- ions mainly (also by efflux of K+ ions)

Increases the firing rate of action potential on postsynaptic membrane Decreases the firing rate of action potential on post synaptic membrane

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with a history of long-standing diarrhea. Serologic evaluation showed positive anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies. Duodenal biopsy showed crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in lamina propria. Which of the following HLA alleles is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of celiac disease or gluten-sensitive enteropathy. It is associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 alleles.

It is an immune-mediated enteropathy triggered by the ingestion of gluten-containing foods such as barley, rye, oats, and wheat (mnemonic: BROW) in genetically predisposed individuals.

In these individuals, digestion of the gluten-containing diet leads to the formation of gliadin peptides. These peptides result in the following immune reactions:

  • They can activate the epithelial cells to express certain cytokines (IL-15), which result in CD8+ T cell proliferation
  • They undergo deamidation and interact with HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 on the antigen-presenting cells. This leads to CD4+ T cell stimulation and further cytokine production

These mechanisms result in epithelial tissue damage.

Antibodies associated with celiac disease are: 

  • Anti-gliadin antibodies
  • Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (anti-ttG)
  • Anti-endomysial antibodies

Microscopic findings include:

  • Villi atrophy and flattening
  • Crypt hyperplasia
  • Increased intraepithelial T cells

questions.text: The government of India starts a new initiative where rehabilitation centers are opened across the country to support wounded army soldiers with medical and psychological aid. Which level of prevention does this initiative fall under?
questions.solution:
The rehabilitation of wounded soldiers with medical and psychological aid falls under the tertiary level of prevention.

The tertiary level of prevention signifies intervention in the late pathogenesis phase. Tertiary prevention can be defined as "all measures available to reduce or limit impairments and disabilities, minimize suffering caused by existing departures from good health, and promote the patient's adjustment to irremediable conditions."

Other levels of prevention are:

Primordial prevention involves the prevention of the emergence or development of risk factors in countries or population groups in which they have not yet appeared. This is employed for health problems like obesity and hypertension, which have an early onset due to the mode of lifestyle like smoking, unhealthy eating patterns, and sedentary life. These patterns are discouraged from early childhood. The main intervention in primordial prevention is through individual and mass education.

Primary prevention is defined as "action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur''. It signifies intervention in the pre-pathogenesis phase of a disease or health problem and is accomplished by measures promoting general health and the quality of life of people by specific protective measures. Examples include immunization, sanitation, and the protection of food. They include two strategies :

  • Population (mass) strategy: where the target group is the whole population
  • High-risk strategy: where the target group is limited to the people who are most at risk of developing a particular disease

Secondary prevention is defined as the "action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications."The specific interventions are early diagnostic tests like screening tests and adequate treatment. The main aim of secondary prevention is to arrest the disease process, and it is largely the domain of clinical medicine and health programs initiated by governments.

questions.text: An adult sustained a burn injury involving the bilateral lower limbs, genitalia, and one palm space burn area in the chest. What is the percentage of total burns surface area?
questions.solution:
The percentage of burns calculated in the given patient is 38% according to Wallace’s rule of nine.

In this case, the estimation of % total burns surface area is as follows.

  • Right lower limb (18%) + Left lower limb (18%) = 36%
  • Genitalia = 1%
  • One palm space are in the chest =1%

Therefore, the total percentage of burns in the given patient is 36 + 1 + 1 = 38%

 

Estimation of burns surface area:

Wallace’s rule of nine: It is used to calculate the percentage of burn.

It divides the body into segments that are approximately 9% or multiples of 9%, with the perineum forming the remaining 1%. The values are modified in the pediatric age group owing to the difference in the body surface area in adults and children.

For calculating the % surface area affected by small burns or patches of burns, a piece of clean paper is cut into the size of the patient's whole hand. This corresponds to 1% of total burns surface area (TBSA). The area affected by small burns is matched using this cut paper.

Note: Lund and Browder's chart is the most accurate in measuring the percentage of BSA affected.

Fluid resuscitation is done based on the estimated burns surface area using the Wallace rule. The fluid resuscitation formula for thermal burns is 4ml/kg/TBSA% given IV.

One-half of the calculated fluid need is given in the first 8 hours after the burn injury, and the remaining half is given over the subsequent 16 hours.

questions.text: Exhumation of a body is done as per the magistrate's order for a legal case requiring age estimation. The skeletal remains found out the skull shown below. The marked suture is fused completely. What was the likely age of the person when he died?
questions.solution:
In the given image of the skull, the suture highlighted in the red colour is a completely fused sagittal suture. So the likely age of the person when he died is 50-60 years.

Age estimation using skull suture closure is an unreliable method. However among all the sutures sagital suture is considered to be the most useful in estimating the age. This is followed by lambdoid and then the coronal suture in the decreasing order of reliablility.

questions.text: A psychologist gives the following card to a patient and asks him to describe what he sees. Which of the following is being assessed here?
questions.solution:
The picture given is of Rorschach's inkblot test, which is a projective personality test that focuses on the unconscious aspects of personality.

Projective tests are based on the principle that when presented with an ambiguous stimulus, such as an inkblot or an image, the patient's responses will reflect fundamental aspects of his or her personality. The ambiguous stimulus is a screen on which the individual projects his or her own needs, thoughts, or conflicts.

Commonly used projective tests are:

  • Thematic apperception test
  • Rorschach's inkblot test
  • Sentence completion test
  • Draw a person test

In Rorschach's inkblot test, 10 bilaterally symmetrical inkblots are shown to the participants. The test is administered in two phases:

  • Free association phase- participant's response to the cards is recorded
  • Inquiry phase- participants explain why they formed the impression.
