4. Tuberous Sclerosis D. Port-wine birthmark, glaucoma
questions.solution:
Option B is the correctly matched answer to this question. The following table represents each condition matched to its clinical spectrum.

Condition Clinical spectrum
1. Neurofibromatosis type 1 

C. Iris hamartoma/ Lisch nodules, optic glioma
2. Sturge-Weber syndrome D. Port-wine birthmark, glaucoma
3. Von Hippel Lindau disease B. Cerebellar haemangioblastoma, retinal angiomas
4. Tuberous sclerosis

A. Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, ash-leaf spots

Neurocutaneous disorders are conditions that affect ectodermal derivatives, most commonly the skin and the CNS. 

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is due to an autosomal dominant loss-of-function mutation in the NF1 gene. Other characteristic features of NF1 include cafe-au-lait macules, inguinal and axillary freckling, and neurofibromas.

The images below show Lisch nodules, cafe-au-lait macules, and axillary freckling respectively.

Sturge-Weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous disorder characterized by vascular malformations limited to segments. It usually results from a mosaic mutation in the GNAQ gene. Leptomeningeal angiomas are a common finding. Presenting complaints in patients range from developmental delay and headaches to seizures, hemiparesis, and stroke-like episodes. Port-wine marks and glaucoma are characteristic.

Von Hippel Lindau (VHL) is an autosomal dominant condition that arises from a mutation affecting the VHL tumor suppressor gene. Characteristic features of VHL include spinal hemangioblastomas, endolymphatic sac tumor, pheochromocytoma, and cystic lesions of the kidneys, pancreas, and liver.

Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) also follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. Other features of TSC also include shagreen patches, cardiac rhabdomyomas, renal angiomyolipoma, facial angiofibroma, and periungual fibromas which are shown in the images below. 

Related Pearl: Cutaneous lesions of Tuberous sclerosis

Tuberous sclerosis (TS) is also known as tuberous sclerosis complex or Bourneville disease. It is a neurocutaneous disorder (phakomatosis) characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors of the embryonic ectoderm (e.g. skin, eyes, and nervous system). It is an autosomal dominant condition.  The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Tuberous sclerosis presents in childhood with a triad (Vogt triad). The triad comprises of:

  • Seizures
  • Mental retardation
  • Adenoma sebaceum

Skin lesions in tuberous sclerosis:

Shagreen patch consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, located primarily in the lumbosacral region. Shagreen is shark skin used as a decorative material present in the right image given below.

The typical hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules on the trunk and extremities are seen in 90% of the patients. It is visualized by the use of a wood ultraviolet lamp.

Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) develop between 4 and 6 years of age; they appear as tiny red nodules over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. Later, they enlarge, coalesce, and assume a fleshy appearance.

Periungual fibroma are small fibromas or nodules of skin, which form around fingernails or toenails in some adolescent patients

Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: A 22 -year-old man comes to the emergency room with complaints of intermittent palpitations and 2 episodes of syncope since yesterday. An ECG is obtained and findings include a shortened PR interval and a wide QRS complex with a slurred upstroke. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with palpitations and history of syncopal episodes has ECG features of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW syndrome). It is a form of atrioventricular reentry phenomenon characterized by the presence of accessory conducting pathways between the atria and ventricles that are separate from the AV node and Purkinje tissue. 

This tachycardia is usually produced by the conduction of a normal impulse from the ventricles to the atria via the accessory pathway (bundle of Kent). This is the orthodromic pathway. Less often, a premature atrial beat travels down the accessory pathway (while AV Node is still in refractory period) leading to premature ventricular activation. This is the antidromic pathway.

Following ECG changes are seen in WPW syndrome- 

  • Shortened PR interval
  • Wide QRS complex with a slurred upstroke (known as a delta wave)

 

Other options:

Option 2 - First-degree AV block is due to a pathology affecting the conducting abilities of the AV Node. There is a resultant delay in the AV conduction of the electrical impulse leading to a prolonged PR interval. 

 

Option 3 - Atrial fibrillation is a type of sustained cardiac arrhythmia that can be triggered by beats from ectopic foci (pulmonary veins or diseased tissue) or reentry circuits within the atria. This leads to atrial contraction in an uncoordinated manner giving rise to the characteristic irregularly irregular pulse as seen on physical examination. ECG changes include irregular QRS complexes of normal morphology and absent P waves. 

 

Option 4 - Torsades de pointes is the term used to describe polymorphic ventricular tachycardia as triggered by conditions with prolonged ventricular repolarization (prolonged QT interval). It can be seen in electrolyte disturbances (hypokalemia hypomagnesemia), medication use (disopyramide, flecainide, Class III antiarrhythmics, TCAs, etc). ECG shows rapid irregular QRS complexes that appear to twist around the baseline. 

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with steatorrhea, hemolytic anemia, and ataxia. The peripheral blood smear picture is given below. Which vitamin can particularly prevent early death in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette mentioning steatorrhea, hemolytic anemia, and ataxia along with acanthocytes seen in the peripheral blood smear is suggestive of abetalipoproteinemia. Administration of large doses of particularly Vitamin E can prevent early death in this condition.

Abetalipoproteinemia is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to loss of function mutation in the gene encoding microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP). MTP transfers lipids to nascent chylomicrons in the intestine and VLDLs in the liver. Therefore, when the MTP gene is mutated, chylomicrons, VLDL, and LDL are not produced.

Vitamin E and retinyl esters are normally transported from enterocytes to the liver by chylomicrons. Vitamin E is also dependent on VLDL for transport out of the liver and into circulation. Because of the inability of these patients to secrete apoB-containing particles, patients with abetalipoproteinemia are markedly deficient in vitamin E. 

Features of abetalipoproteinemia include diarrhea, failure to thrive, neurological features like loss of deep tendon reflexes, dysmetria, ataxia, spastic gait, etc, hypolipidemia, and progressive pigmented retinopathy which may progress to near-blindness.

Treatment of this condition includes the administration of large doses of Vitamin E. They are also mild to moderately deficient in vitamins A and K, those vitamins need to be administrated as well.

Note: It is necessary to initiate Vitamin E therapy as early as possible to prevent the development of neurologic sequelae which may warrant even higher doses of vitamin E.

questions.text:
Match the following clinical images with the corresponding diagnoses.
  1. Nevus of Ito
  2. Congenital melanocytic nevus
  3. Nevus of Ota
  4. Becker nevus
questions.solution:
Option B has the correctly matched set of images and diagnoses.

1 Nevus of Ito
2 Congenital melanocytic nevus
3 Nevus of Ota
4 Becker nevus

Image 1- shows a unilateral blue-greyish hyperpigmented macule on the shoulder, which is suggestive of nevus of Ito. It affects the acromioclavicular region and upper chest. It is distinguished from the nevus of Ota by its location in the area innervated by the posterior supraclavicular and lateral cutaneous brachial nerves. 

Image 2 shows a dark blackish pigmented lesion over the back of an infant, which is suggestive of congenital melanocytic nevus. Congenital melanocytic nevi are benign, pigmented, melanocytic nevi present at birth. Lesions are dark at birth and are usually palpable with increased surface markings. It has a slightly higher predisposition in females.

Image 3 shows bluish-brown pigmentation around the eye. This is nevus of Ota. It is a dermal melanocytosis that mainly affects the sclera and skin around the eyes. They are generally distributed along with the ophthalmic and maxillary divisions of the trigeminal nerve. It is commonly seen in females. 

Image 4 shows a large, pigmented hairy patch on the shoulder, which is suggestive of Becker nevus. Becker nevus is an epidermal melanocytic nevus. It is classically seen as a hyperpigmented, brownish patch over the scapular area on the back, shoulders, outer arms, and chest. It is usually associated with hypertrichosis and sometimes with acne. It is more common among males. It has an onset around adolescence, when there is an increased sensitivity to androgens.

questions.text: An obstetrician performs an aspiration of the endometrial cavity in a woman with complaints of a missed period 2 weeks back. Identify the following instrument. What is the procedure it is used for?
questions.solution:
The instrument is Karman’s cannula and  syringe, which is also used for menstrual regulation.

Menstrual regulation is the aspiration of the endometrial cavity within 14 days of a missed period in a woman with a previous normal cycle.

Under aseptic precautions, the cervix may be gently dilated using 4-5 mm size dilators. Then 5-6mm Karman’s cannula is inserted and attached to a 50ml syringe for suction. The cannula is rotated, and pushed in and out with gentle strokes.

This procedure is contraindicated in advanced pregnancy and in the presence of local pelvic inflammation. The drawbacks of the procedure include a missed implanted zygote or an unrecognized ectopic pregnancy.

This procedure is not commonly done anymore.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented with excessive sweating, absent knee jerk on the right side, and anisocoria as shown in the below image. A senior resident advises you to perform a 0.1% pilocarpine test on her. On performing this pharmacological test you would notice
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young woman with diaphoresis (excessive sweating), absent deep tendon reflex (absent knee jerk), and the image showing tonically dilated right pupil (Adie's tonic pupil) is highly suggestive of Holmes - Adie Syndrome. Therefore, application of 0.1% pilocarpine results in constriction of the right pupil.

In Adie’s tonic pupil, the affected pupil is larger (right pupil is larger than the left in the given image). On applying a weak solution of pilocarpine (0.1%), the affected pupil becomes smaller than the other pupil due to denervation hypersensitivity, while the normal pupil remains unaffected.

Holmes - Adie Syndrome:

It is characterised by a classic triad of diaphoresis, absent deep tendon reflexes, and Adie's tonic pupil. It is usually unilateral and is more common in young women. 

In this condition, the reaction to light is absent and to near reflex is very slow and tonic. It is caused by damage to the postganglionic parasympathetic neurons supplying the pupillary sphincter.

questions.text: The gross specimen of the pancreas from a patient who died of acute pancreatitis is shown below. What is it suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The given specimen shows yellow nodules with areas of chalky-white deposits, which are suggestive of fat necrosis.

Fat necrosis results from the release of activated pancreatic lipases into the substance of the pancreas and the peritoneal cavity. These enzymes act on surrounding tissue to release fatty acids, which then combine with calcium to produce grossly visible chalky-white areas (fat saponification).

Histologic examination reveals foci of shadowy outlines of necrotic fat cells, with basophilic calcium deposits, surrounded by an inflammatory reaction.

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue,  breathlessness, paresthesias, and a  stomping gait. The peripheral blood smear shows a megaloblastic picture. The lifecycle of the causative organism is shown below. Which of the following can be responsible for this deficiency?
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture is suggestive of Vitamin B12 deficiency which can be caused by the broad or fish tapeworm - Diphyllobothrium latum.

Diphyllobothrium latum infection usually causes vitamin B12 deficiency by absorbing large quantities of vitamin B12 and interfering with the ileal absorption thereby making it unavailable to the host.

The first intermediate host is a freshwater crustacean, while the second intermediate host is freshwater fish. The definitive hosts are man, dog, and cat. The infective form to humans is the third stage plerocercoid larvae. It possesses a rudimentary scolex.

The adult worm lives inside the small intestine and lays operculated eggs. These freshly passed eggs contain an immature embryo surrounded by yolk granules. This hexacanth embryo with 6 hooklets inside the egg is called oncosphere.

The pernicious anaemia caused by the infection is called bothriocephalus anaemia.

Treatment is praziquantel in a single dose of 10 mg/kg. In severe B12 deficiency, parenteral vitamin B12 should be given. 

Other options:

Beef tapeworm (option A) is Taenia saginata and pork tapeworm (option B) is Taenia solium. Both of them live in the adult small intestine. Man is the definitive host for both species while cattle and pigs are the intermediate hosts for T. saginata and T. solium respectively. 

Manifestations include:

  • Intestinal taeniasis is characterised by vague abdominal discomfort, indigestion, nausea, diarrhoea and weight loss. 
  • Cysticercosis in subcutaneous tissues (nodules), muscles (acute myositis), and brain (neurocysticercosis)

The below image shows the life cycle of T. saginata and T. solium

 

Dwarf tapeworm (option C) is the common name for Hymenolepis Nana which manifests as nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and irritability in severe cases and the life cycle is shown in the image below.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-metabolites act as an antifungal agent?
questions.solution:
Flucytosine is an anti-metabolite that acts as an antifungal agent.

Fungal cytosine deaminase converts flucytosine to 5-fluorouracil, which is an anticancer drug. 5-fluorouracil is further converted into metabolites that inhibit thymidylate synthase, an enzyme that is necessary for DNA synthesis. Thus fungal DNA synthesis is inhibited. Mammalian cells are spared as it lacks cytosine deaminase enzyme.

Flucytosine has clinically useful activity (3C) against

  • Cryptococcus
  • Candida albicans
  • Chromoblastomycosis

The current pharmacological utility of flucytosine is in the treatment of HIV-associated cryptococcal meningitis (in combination with amphotericin B) and in chromoblastomycosis (in combination with itraconazole).

Other options:

Option A - Methotrexate is an antimetabolite that inhibits the enzymes dihydrofolate reductase and thymidylate synthase. It impairs de novo synthesis of purine nucleotides. It is used in the management of breast, head & neck, bladder cancers as well as lymphomas (primary central nervous system lymphoma, non-Hodgkin's).

Option B - Cladribine is an antimetabolite (purine nucleoside analog) that inhibits the enzyme ribonucleotide reductase (impaired formation of deoxyribonucleotides) and integrates cladribine triphosphate into DNA (renders DNA non-functional). It is used to treat hairy cell leukemia, CLL, and lymphoma.

Option C - Clofarabine is an antimetabolite (purine nucleoside analog) with action similar to that of cladribine. It is used in the treatment of pediatric ALL that is resistant to two prior chemotherapeutic treatments. It is also used in the treatment of pediatric and adult acute myeloid leukemias, and in myelodysplasia.

Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the superficial layers of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries. 

It is an early postmortem change that occurs due to engorged vessels showing through the skin seen on the dependent parts due to the pooling of blood under the effect of gravity. 

This staining starts as mottled patches 1-3 hours following death and develops to a uniform area of staining in 3-6 hours. Full development and fixation of hypostasis occur within 6-12 hours. This finding usually develops within 4 hours and persists until putrefaction. Fixation of hypostasis occurs earlier in summer. It is delayed in asphyxial deaths and in intracranial lesions.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy develops bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps. The bacteria isolated from the stool specimen fermented lactose and produced colorless colonies on sorbitol MacConkey agar. The most likely etiological agent in this case is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a boy with bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps with the isolated bacteria fermenting lactose and forming colorless colonies on sorbitol MacConkey agar is suggestive of infection by Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC) O157: H7, also known as Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC).

O157: H7 is the most common type of Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC). Unlike most other E. coli serotypes, the STEC O157: H7 does not use sorbitol and produces clear colonies on the Sorbitol MacConkey agar. The non-STEC produces pink colonies. All species of E. coli are lactose fermenters and produce pink colonies.

They produce two antigenic forms of the cytotoxic toxin known as Shiga-like toxin 1 and Shiga-like toxin 2. Shiga-like toxin 1 is identical to the Shiga toxin of Shigella dysenteriae type 1. E. coli O157:H7 has a small infective dose (around 100 bacilli) and spreads easily from child to child by the feco-oral route.

It can cause mild non-bloody diarrhea to hemorrhagic colitis, or a severe form of diarrhea, with hemolytic uremic syndrome, a disease resulting in acute renal failure, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia. The most common cause of hemolytic uremic syndrome in the world is E.coli O157:H7. The most common cause of hemolytic uremic syndrome in India is Shigella dysenteriae type I.

Other options:

Option A: Campylobacter is a slender, spirally curved, gram-negative bacillus. They grow at a slower rate and thus require selective media containing antibiotics like Skirrow's media for culture.

Option B: Yersinia enterocolitica causes diarrhea with symptoms resembling appendicitis (pseudoappendicitis). The patients present with abdominal pain which can be localized to the right iliac fossa, thus mimicking appendicitis. Additionally, it is a non-lactose fermenter.

Option D: Shigella dysenteriae type 1 can produce the Shiga toxin and result in a clinical profile similar to EHEC. But Shigella is a non-lactose fermenting organism, unlike E. coli, and will form pale colonies on MacConkey agar. 

Enterobacteriaceae family is classified based on their action on lactose present in MacConkey's medium as,

Lactose fermenters

Escherichia, Klebsiella,Enterobacter 

Late lactose fermenters

Shigella sonnei, Serratia, Citrobacter, Erwinia

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the casualty following a fall on his hand during a football match. He complains of pain and inability to move his right shoulder. On examination, flattening of the shoulder contour and inability to touch his opposite shoulder are noted. He was managed using the method shown below. Identify the procedure shown.
questions.solution:
The history of a fall on his hand, loss of shoulder contour, and a positive Dugas test (inability to touch the opposite shoulder) are all suggestive of anterior shoulder dislocation and the image shows Kocher's technique of reduction.

Kocher's technique- It is the most commonly used method for the reduction of anterior shoulder dislocation. It involves four steps: 

Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation (TEAM)

  • Steady traction is applied along the long axis of the humerus with the elbow flexed to a right angle
  • Then the arm is externally rotated
  • This is followed by the adduction of the externally rotated arm
  • Finally, internal rotation is done.

Anterior dislocation of the shoulder:

It is the most common type of shoulder dislocation which results due to a fall on an outstretched hand in an abducted and externally rotated shoulder. The patient usually presents with an abducted shoulder, with his elbow being supported by the opposite hand, and complains of pain and inability to move the affected shoulder.

The following findings are seen on examination:

  • Flattening of the normal shoulder contour.
  • A displaced head can be felt as a fullness below the clavicle.
  • Dugas test: Inability to touch the opposite shoulder
  • Hamilton ruler test: A ruler placed on the lateral side of the arm touches the acromion and lateral condyle of the humerus simultaneously due to the flattening of the shoulder.
  • Regiment badge sign: Area of anesthesia around the deltoid due to injury to the axillary nerve
  • Byrant's test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level.

Complications include injury to the axillary nerve and recurrent shoulder dislocation.

Other options:

Allis technique/maneuver is used for the reduction of posterior hip dislocation.

Related Pearl: Methods of reduction of shoulder dislocation

Kocher's technique - TEAM (Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation) 

Hippocratic method - The doctor applies a firm and steady pull on the semi-abducted arm of the patient by keeping his foot on the axilla against the chest wall. The foot is used as the fulcrum.

Stimson's gravity technique: Patient is left prone and weight is attached to the elbow or wrist on the affected side. Gravity stretches the muscle and reduction occurs in 15-20 minutes. 

Related Pearl: Tests for anterior shoulder dislocation

Bryant’s test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level on the dislocated side.

 

Dugas test: The patient is made to place the hand on the opposite shoulder. The examiner then applies gentle pressure on the flexed elbow to make it touch the chest. In shoulder dislocation, the elbow cannot be made to touch the chest. 

 

Hamilton ruler test: In a normal shoulder, a ruler (scale) placed on the lateral side of the arm will not touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion at the same time.

In anterior shoulder dislocation, the ruler will simultaneously touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion. 

 

 

Callway Test: The vertical circumference of the axilla is increased on the dislocated side as compared to the normal side.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with complaints of double vision, frequent falls, and numbness of both hands. On examination, the radial pulses were not palpable, but the femoral pulses were palpable. An aortic arch angiogram was done, which revealed the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the aortic angiogram showing areas of stenosis in multiple great vessels arising from the aortic arch is suggestive of Takayasu's arteritis, also known as the pulseless disease.

Takayasu's arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis affecting medium and large-sized arteries, in this case, the aortic arch and its branches. Clinical manifestations include vision disturbances and profound weakening of the pulses, especially in the upper extremities. 

Disease pathology is characterized by transmural fibrous thickening of the aorta. The branches of the aortic arch, when involved, are markedly narrowed or even obliterated, causing absent pulses in the upper extremities. 

In some cases, there may also be involvement of other vessels such as the pulmonary, coronary, and renal arteries.

Histopathology:

  • Irregular thickening of the vessel wall is seen with associated intimal hyperplasia. 
  • Characteristic granulomatous inflammation, with the presence of giant cells and patchy medial necrosis.
  • Disease progression is associated with collagenous scarring and chronic inflammatory infiltrates across all layers of the vessel wall.

Other options:

Option a- Polyarteritis Nodosa is a vasculitis affecting small or medium-sized muscular arteries. It is often seen in renal and visceral vessels, with exception of the pulmonary arteries. Clinical features result from ischemia and infarction of affected tissues and organs.

Option c- Aortic dissection occurs when blood separates the laminar planes of the medial layer to form a blood-filled channel within the aortic wall. The clinical features include sudden onset excruciating pain, which radiates to the back and moves downwards as the dissection progresses.

Shown below are the axial and coronal views of chest CT with IV contrast highlighting a descending aortic dissection:

 

Option d- Kawasaki Disease is an acute, febrile disease seen during infancy and childhood. It usually involves large to medium-sized vessels. Clinical features include conjunctival and oral erythema, blistering, edema of the hands and feet, erythema of the palms and soles, desquamative rash, and cervical lymph node enlargement. It is associated with many cardiovascular sequelae including coronary arteria ectasia and coronary artery aneurysms.

questions.text: The given image shows the synthesis and release of GABA at the nerve terminal. Identify the antiepileptic that mainly acts at site A.
questions.solution:
The structure marked as A is a GABA transporter. The drug that acts on GABA transporter is tiagabine. It inhibits the neuronal uptake of GABA and prolongs its time in the synaptic cleft, where the GABA molecules can activate GABA receptors.

questions.text:
You see an elderly man collapse in a shopping mall. He has no pulse. What is the correct sequence to be followed to provide cardio-pulmonary resuscitation to him?
  1. Call for the emergency response team
  2. Check scene safety
  3. Recheck pulse
  4. Chest compressions
questions.solution:
The correct sequence to be followed to provide cardio-pulmonary resuscitation (CPR) to the elderly man is 2-1-4-3.

For a patient in respiratory and cardiac distress, CAB-D (Circulation, Airway, Breathing, Defibrillate) must be assessed:

  1. Assess to make sure the scene is safe for you to attend to the patient.
  2. Assess responsiveness: Speak to the adult and ask if they are ok. Simultaneously look at the chest and abdomen for movement and normal breathing. 
  3. If the patient is unresponsive, call the emergency response team and bring an automatic external defibrillator (AED) to the patient or ask someone nearby to do so.
  4. Place the patient supine on a hard flat surface.
  5. Check for a carotid pulse for 5-10 sec.
  6. If the patient does not have a pulse, proceed with 5 cycles of CPR (lasting approximately 2 minutes).
    • Start with chest compressions:
      • Provide 100-120 compressions per min.
      • Place palms midline, one over the other, on the lower 1/3rd of the patient’s sternum between the nipples.
      • Press to a depth of 2-2.4 inches (5-6 cm) on the patient’s chest.
      • Press hard and fast.
      • Ensure full chest recoil with each compression.
    • Provide 2 rescue breaths for every 30 chest compressions (1 cycle of adult CPR is 30 chest compressions to 2 rescue breaths).
    • Recheck pulse every 2 min.
  7. If the patient has a pulse:
    • Provide 10 rescue breaths per min (1 breath every 6 sec).
    • Recheck pulse every 2 min.
  8. Once the AED arrives, analyze the rhythm for defibrillation:
    • If the rhythm is shockable, assure no one is near the patient, press the shock button, and resume 5 cycles of CPR.
    • If the rhythm is not shockable, initiate 5 cycles of CPR and recheck the rhythm.

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below. 

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

questions.text: A 24-year-old man in the ICU is suffering from acute respiratory distress syndrome. Which one of the following statements is true for the dead space volume as seen in this patient?

choices.text: Physiologic dead space = Anatomical dead space
Physiologic dead space > Anatomical dead space
Physiologic dead space < Anatomical dead space
Physiologic dead space < Alveolar dead space

questions.solution:
In the case of alveolar-capillary membrane compromise as seen in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), physiological dead space > anatomical dead space.

ARDS is characterized by damage to the alveolar-capillary interface in the lungs due to leakage of protein-rich inflammatory fluid from the capillaries. This promotes the formation of hyaline membranes that impair optimal gaseous exchange, thereby giving rise to significant alveolar dead space (sites of wasted ventilation). Since physiological dead space is the sum of alveolar dead space (virtually nil in healthy lungs) and anatomical dead space, in the case of ARDS, physiological dead space is greater than anatomical dead space. 

Dead space is the airway and lung volume that does not participate in gas exchange.

Types:

  • Anatomical dead space- the volume of the air-occupying conducting zone where no gaseous exchange takes place. It is about 150 mL in healthy individuals.
  • Alveolar dead space- the volume of gas not equilibrating with blood (present in cases of damaged alveolar diffusion membrane). 
  • Physiological dead space (Total dead space) = Anatomical + Alveolar dead space.

In healthy individuals with fully functional alveoli, the alveolar dead space is virtually nil. This makes physiological dead space = anatomical dead space. 

In pathological states, due to the presence of alveolar dead space in the form of nonfunctional alveoli, the following equation holds true.

Physiological dead space (alveolar + anatomic) > Anatomic dead space.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden onset neurological deficits. On examination, he is found to have a loss of pain and temperature sensations over the left side of the face and right side of the body. He also has dysphagia with a deviation of the uvula to the right. Which blood vessel is most likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of this patient are suggestive of lateral medullary syndrome due to the involvement of a left-sided artery. Hence, the blood vessel most likely to be affected in this patient is the left vertebral artery.

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, occurs most commonly due to the occlusion of the ipsilateral vertebral artery. Posterior inferior cerebellar artery occlusion is responsible for the remaining cases.

The structures affected in lateral medullary syndrome include:

  • Tract and nucleus of V cranial nerve: impaired sensation over the ipsilateral half of the face
  • IX and X cranial nerves: ipsilateral paralysis of the palate (dysphagia), vocal cord (hoarseness), diminished gag reflex
  • Nucleus of Tractus Solitarius: ipsilateral loss of taste
  • Vestibular nucleus: nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
  • Spinocerebellar tract: ipsilateral ataxia
  • Descending sympathetic tract: ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract: impaired pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body

questions.text: Which enzyme is involved in cataract formation in a patient with diabetes?
questions.solution:
Aldose reductase is the enzyme involved in cataract formation in a diabetic patient.

The polyol pathway has been implicated in the formation of diabetic cataracts. This pathway results in the production of fructose from glucose and, sorbitol is formed as an intermediate. Glucose is reduced to sorbitol by aldose reductase. Sorbitol does not diffuse through cell membranes, but accumulates, causing osmotic damage. 

Diabetics have increased glucose levels in the lens, peripheral nerves, and renal glomeruli which are not insulin sensitive. This increases the activity of aldose reductase in these tissues. The sorbitol so formed accumulates in the lens leading to cataract formation in diabetic patients.

Options B and C are enzymes of galactose metabolism. Classical galactosemia is caused by deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT).  Without GALT, the infant cannot metabolize galactose 1-phosphate, which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain. Galactokinase is the enzyme responsible for the conversion of galactose to galactose 1-phosphate. Only cataract is seen in the deficiency of this enzyme because galactose-1-phosphate is not formed. Hence no toxic effects of this compound are manifested. 

Option D:  Aldolase B is the enzyme that cleaves fructose-1-phosphate in fructose metabolism. A deficiency of this causes hereditary fructose intolerance.

questions.text: A young HIV-positive male presented with headache and nuchal rigidity to the emergency room. India ink preparation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is given below. Which of the following is false regarding the causative organism?

choices.text: Smooth, mucoid and creamy white colonies on culture
Infection is by inhalation of the yeast cells
Patients with sarcoidosis are immune to this infection.
Treated with amphotericin B with flucytosine

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the India ink preparation of CSF showing capsulated budding yeast cells are highly suggestive of cryptococcal meningitis, caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. The false statement is option C, as patients with sarcoidosis are at higher risk of getting the infection.

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that mainly affects patients suffering from AIDS, Sarcoidosis, and patients on glucocorticoid therapy. It is found as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings. Infection is by inhalation of the yeast cells(option B).

The image given below shows the life cycle of Cryptococcus neoformans.

The primary pulmonary infection may be asymptomatic or may mimic an influenza-like respiratory infection, often resolving spontaneously. Cutaneous infection results in ulcers, and granulomata.

In immunocompromised, the yeasts may multiply and disseminate to other parts of the body but preferentially to the central nervous system, causing cryptococcal meningoencephalitis presenting with headache and nuchal rigidity.

Diagnosis is established by microscopic examination of cerebrospinal fluid, BAL fluid or blood samples. India ink preparation reveals capsulated budding yeast cells.

Mucicarmine stain can also be used in the identification of cryptococcus. The image given below shows mucicarmine stained specimen of lung tissue containing cryptococci:

Culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) at 37'C appears as smooth, mucoid, and creamy white (option A). The cryptococcal antigen(in serum and CSF) is sensitive and specific and can be demonstrated by the latex agglutination test.

Treatment of cryptococcal meningitis involves combination therapy of amphotericin B with flucytosine (option D). Fluconazole can be added with these drugs in AIDS patients to prevent relapse.

questions.text: The image shows a graph plotted between the rate of reaction (on the y-axis) and substrate concentration (on the x-axis). Which of the following statements is not true regarding this plot?

choices.text: It is not seen with monomeric enzymes
The enzyme may have multiple binding sites

questions.solution:
Follows Michaelis Menten kinetics statement is not true regarding this plot. 

The given plot shows a sigmoid curve suggestive of cooperative binding of the enzymes to their substrates. This type of saturation kinetics is explained by Hill equation. 

Michaelis - Menten Kinetics:

The Michaelis - Menten equation gives the mathematical relationship between initial reaction velocity, v, and substrate concentration [S] which is as given below.

v = Vmax[S]/Km+[S]

where Km is the substrate concentration at which vi is half the maximal velocity (Vmax/2) which is reached at a particular concentration of the enzyme.

A graph showing a hyperbola is suggestive of Michaelis - Menten kinetics of the enzyme which is as follows.

For enzymes showing Michaelis - Menten kinetics, there is an increase in the rate of reaction, V, with an increase in substrate concentration till a point Vmax is reached beyond which rate of reaction shows saturation.

Hill equation:

Allosteric enzymes are those for which catalysis at the active site may be modulated by the presence of effectors at an allosteric site.

This is the exclusive property of multimeric enzymes, which have multiple binding sites for enzymes. This property is analogous to oxygen binding by haemoglobin. This is not seen in monomeric enzymes.

As Michaelis Menten equations cannot be used, the Hill equation is used to describe the kinetics of positive cooperative binding.

Allosteric enzymes have one catalytic site where the substrate binds and another separate allosteric site where the modifier binds.

questions.text: A 28-year-old lady develops pulmonary tuberculosis and is started on antitubercular therapy. She returns 2 months later for a repeat check-up during which her urine pregnancy test turns out to be positive. She regularly takes oral contraceptive pills. Which of the following drugs might be implicated in contraception failure?
questions.solution:
Rifampicin is likely implicated in the contraception failure of this patient. It might have increased the metabolism of OCPs and decreased its concentration needed for maintaining contraception.

Rifampicin is a potent inducer of cytochrome enzymes CYP3A4, CYP1A2, CYP2C9, CYP2C19. As a result, it hastens the metabolism of its own and multiple other drugs including OCPs, steroids, HIV protease inhibitors, phenytoin which are metabolized by this microsomal enzyme.

A strategy to prevent failure of contraception in this case is, either to use higher estrogen-containing pills or to use other method of contraception.

Amongst rifamycins, the order of drug interactions is given as rifampicin> rifapentine> rifabutin. Hence, rifabutin is used when other drugs are used to decrease the likelihood of drug interactions.

questions.text: The use of barium sulfate as a contrast agent is contraindicated in:
questions.solution:
Tracheoesophageal fistula is a contraindication for the use of barium sulfate as a contrast agent. An isotonic, non-ionic iodinated contrast agent can be used instead.

Barium sulfate is not absorbed as it passes through the gastrointestinal tract. However when the integrity of the gut wall is compromised (perforation) or when there is an abnormal communication between the esophagus and trachea, it can overflow and leak into the lungs, mediastinum, intraperitoneal cavity, and tissue around the rectum and causing widespread granuloma formation and anaphylactic reactions. 

Contraindications to Barium

  1. Esophageal perforation
  2. Perforation peritonitis
  3. Tracheoesophageal fistula

Iohexol is the contrast medium used for the diagnostic workup for a suspected case of esophageal perforation instead of barium contrast to prevent barium-related inflammation of the mediastinum.

Note: Although Gastrograffin (water-soluble) was used previously as an alternative to barium contrast, it has a high chance of causing aspiration pneumonitis and pulmonary edema consequently. Hence, it is not preferred nowadays.

questions.text: In a patient with non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), all the following can be used for treatment except?
questions.solution:
Streptokinase is not used in the management of non-ST segment elevation MI (NSTEMI). It is a fibrin non-specific plasminogen activator used as a fibrinolytic agent in the treatment of ST-segment elevation MI (STEMI). Aspirin, clopidogrel, and prasugrel are antiplatelet drugs commonly used in the management of NSTEMI.

Fibrinolytic therapy is not indicated in patients with unstable angina or NSTEMI, unlike in STEMI. This is because STEMI is almost always caused by plaque rupture leading to the formation of an occluding thrombus, whereas, NSTEMI can be caused by a stable non-occluding plaque with some amount of lumen still patent. Fibrinolytic therapy may lead to the rupture of the stable plaque causing more damage.

Acute coronary syndrome is classified into 2 groups:

  • ST-segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI)
  • NSTE-ACS

NSTE-ACS further includes:

  • NSTEMI (myocyte necrosis present and cardiac troponins elevated)
  • Unstable Angina (myocyte necrosis absent and cardiac troponins not elevated)

The treatment of NSTEMI is as follows:

  • Admission to a specialized cardiac unit
  • Inhaled oxygen
  • Bed rest with continuous ECG monitoring
  • Monitoring cardiac biomarkers
  • Morphine or opioid analgesics
  • Nitrates
  • Beta-blockers
  • Antiplatelet drugs like aspirin, clopidogrel, prasugrel

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly used in the treatment of overactive urinary bladder?
questions.solution:
Tolterodine is commonly used in the treatment of the overactive urinary bladder. It is a muscarinic receptor antagonist. 

In an overactive bladder, there is an overactivity of the detrusor muscle due to the up-regulation of M3 receptors. Drugs that block these receptors such as tolterodine act by improving bladder capacity, reducing the frequency of bladder contractions, and lowering intravesicular pressure.

Anticholinergics are muscarinic receptor antagonists and parasympatholytics. The important uses of various anticholinergics are as follows:

  • Atropine - for AV block, organophosphorus poisoning, and refractive error testing in children (produces cycloplegic mydriasis)
  • Scopolamine/ hyoscine (transdermal patch) - for motion sickness
  • Ipratropium - for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and rhinorrhea 
  • Tolterodine - for childhood enuresis, overactive and neurogenic bladder
  • Pirenzepine (selective M1 receptor antagonist) - for peptic ulcer disease 
  • Benzhexol/ Trihexyphenidyl - for Parkinson's disease and drug-induced extrapyramidal symptoms
  • Dicyclomine (direct spasmolytic effect on GI smooth muscle) - for diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome
  • Glycopyrrolate (reduces secretions) - as a pre-anesthetic medication

Adverse effects of muscarinic antagonists include dryness of mouth, decreased sweating, thirst, mydriasis and blurring of vision, palpitations, and urinary retention. CNS effects include restlessness, hallucinations, and delirium.

questions.text: A neonate has a cardiac murmur and the eye finding shown in the image below. Investigations revealed bilateral hearing defect. The mother gives a history of viral exanthem during the first trimester of the pregnancy. The most common cardiac defect seen in such neonates is:
questions.solution:
Maternal history of viral exanthem in the first trimester and the image showing the presence of bilateral congenital cataract and hearing defect is suggestive of congenital rubella syndrome. Patent ductus arteriosus is the most common cardiac defect associated with this condition.

Congenital rubella syndrome is associated with rubella infection in mothers in early pregnancy. The classic triad of congenital rubella syndrome includes:

  • Sensorineural hearing loss
  • Congenital cataract
  • Congenital heart disease (most commonly: patent ductus arteriosus)

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: The operating surgeon performed the following suture technique on the skin after appendicectomy surgery. This is called_______.
questions.solution:
This suture technique is called mattress suture.

The type of mattress suture performed is horizontal mattress suture. It is performed by inserting a needle perpendicular to the incision and then crossing both the edge of the wound and moving horizontally and traverse once again both the edge of the wound and tie the knot.

Other options :

B) The subcuticular suture technique is performed by taking a bite alternatively on either side of the wound and gently pulling simultaneously until the end.

C) Continuous suture technique is performed by inserting a needle perpendicular to the incision and then crossing both the edges of the wound, this is performed continuously till the end is reached.

D) Interrupted suture technique is performed inserting a needle perpendicular to the incision and crossing both the edge of the wound and the knot is tied.

2. Golden-brown fusiform rods  B. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
3. Non-necrotizing granulomas  C. Anthracosis
4. Nodules of whorled collagen fibers D. Asbestosis
questions.solution:
The correct match is Option 2: 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A.

Anthracosis/ coal workers' pneumoconiosis is a pulmonary condition seen in coal miners. It is caused due to the phagocytosis of the inhaled carbonaceous pigment by the alveolar or interstitial macrophages and its subsequent accumulation in the connective tissue spaces. With continued exposure, lung tissue undergoes progressive massive fibrosis. The upper lobes and upper zones of the lower lobes of the lungs are commonly involved.

Microscopic features consist of coal-laden macrophages, black pigment, and dense collagenous interstitial fibrosis (in advanced stages), as shown in the image below.

 

Asbestosis occurs due to the inhalation of crystalline hydrated silicates (asbestos). It is characterized by diffuse parenchymal interstitial fibrosis. It usually begins in the lower lobes of the lungs. Other asbestos-related diseases include pleural plaques, recurrent pleural effusions, lung carcinoma, and mesothelioma.

Hallmark microscopic findings are golden brown, fusiform or beaded rods called asbestos bodies, as shown in the image below. These are formed when the asbestos fibers phagocytosed by the macrophages are coated by iron-containing proteinaceous material derived from phagocyte ferritin. Pleural plaques of dense collagen that may be calcified are the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure. They involve the anterior and posterolateral aspects of the parietal pleura and the diaphragmatic domes.

 

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is an immunologically mediated granulomatous disease that occurs in response to continuous exposure to inhaled organic antigens (mold, hay dust, bird proteins, thermophilic bacteria in air-conditioning units). Pathological changes in response to such exposures are mediated by the CD4+ and CD8+ T-lymphocytes (type IV hypersensitivity reactions) and proinflammatory chemokines.

Microscopic findings include interstitial pneumonitis (lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages) and non-necrotizing granulomas, as shown in the image below. Chronic disease gives rise to obliterative bronchiolitis and honeycombing.

 

Silicosis occurs due to inhalation of crystalline silicon dioxide (silica) as seen in individuals employed in concrete work and sandblasting. Macrophages incorporate inhaled silica particles, thereby activating and releasing inflammatory mediators (IL-1, IL-8) that cause fibroblast recruitment. Subsequently, collagen is deposited in the interstitium. Upper lung zones and hilar lymph nodes are commonly involved.

Microscopy reveals coalescent nodules of whorled collagen fibers surrounded by a peripheral zone of silica-laden macrophages, as shown in the image below. As the disease progresses, these nodules coalesce into scars. Sometimes, thin sheets of calcification can occur in hilar lymph nodes, giving an eggshell appearance.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presenting with blood in stool has the following examination findings. Her father had similar complaints at the age of 10 and was recently diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. The patient's biopsy samples are obtained after a colonoscopy. What are the most likely histological changes to be seen?
questions.solution:
A young child with blood in stools, positive family history, and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation as shown in the image is suggestive of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Hamartomous polyps with normal epithelium are seen in this condition.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition that is characterized by the formation of multiple hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract (small intestine, colon, and stomach) and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation. The hyperpigmentation typically appears as dark blue to brown macules on the lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, palmar surfaces of the hands, genitalia, and perianal region. This rare syndrome presents at a median age of 11 years. This condition is associated with an increased risk of malignancies which include cancers of the stomach and small intestines, colon, pancreas, breast, and lungs.

The histopathological findings of the polyps reveal an arborizing network (freely branching) of glands that are lined by the normal intestinal epithelium, as seen in the image below: 


Other options:

Both ulcerative colitis (option A) and Crohn's disease (option C) can present with blood in stools, however, they have a bimodal median age of presentation (2nd-4th decades of life and 7th-9th decades of life). 

Option A - Pseudopolyps with submucosal crypt abscesses are the histopathological findings seen in ulcerative colitis. It is a form of inflammatory bowel disease. It involves the entirety of the colon (pancolitis) and presents with bloody mucoid diarrhea and cramping abdominal pain.

Here is an image showing crypt abscesses limited to the mucosa and submucosa as seen in ulcerative colitis:


Option C - Noncaseating granulomas with transmural ulcers and skip lesions are histopathological findings as seen in Crohn's disease. 

It is also a form of inflammatory bowel disease that commonly involves the terminal ileum but can affect any portion of the GI tract. Patients usually present with iron deficiency anemia and sporadic attacks of mild diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain.

Here is an image showing noncaseating granulomas as seen in Crohn's disease:


Option D - Adenomatous polyps with epithelial dysplasia are seen in neoplastic polyps. The patients usually present in adulthood.

These can range from small and pedunculated to large and sessile. It is a premalignant pathology that has a high risk of progression to colonic adenocarcinoma. Types of neoplastic/adenomatous polyps include tubular, tubulovillous, and villous polyps. Common histological findings include markers of epithelial dysplasia such as nuclear hyperchromasia, elongation, and stratification. 

The image below shows tubular and villous adenomas seen in neoplastic polyps:

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

questions.text: Which is the most commonly used confirmatory test for HIV?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used confirmatory test for HIV is the Western blot. 

Western blot demonstrating antibodies to products of all three of the major genes of HIV (gag, pol, and env) is conclusive evidence of infection with HIV. It is considered positive if it shows antibodies against at least two of the following gene products: p24, gp41, gp120/ 160. 

Other options:

Option A: ELISA (Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) is the most commonly used screening test for HIV. It is a simple, relatively inexpensive screening test for HIV.

Option C: DNA PCR (Polymerase chain reaction) is a specific test for the detection of HIV infection where proviral DNA from the peripheral lymphocytes of the patient's samples is amplified and identified. When performed correctly, this test has a high specificity and sensitivity.

Option D: p24 which is the core antigen of the virus is the earliest to occur and is employed for early diagnosis. A p24 antigen capture assay where anti-p24 antibodies bound with p24 is used with ELISA to demonstrate HIV. This test is useful in the following scenarios - 

  • Newly exposed to the risk of infection
  • People who test negative for the antibody
  • The terminal phase of infection

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding insulin physiology?

choices.text: Growth effects are mediated by phosphatidlyinositol-3 kinase
Insulin and C-peptide are released in equal amounts
Insulin secretion is independent of intracellular ATP

questions.solution:
Insulin secretion is dependent on intracellular ATP concentrations.

On food intake, there is subsequent uptake of glucose by the pancreatic beta islet cells. The glucose molecules undergo cytoplasmic glycolysis (glucokinase-mediated) and mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation to generate ATP. This ATP reenters the cytoplasm where it inhibits the ATP-sensitive K+ channels.

Reduction of K+ influx leads to retention of intracellular positive charge and consequent beta-cell membrane depolarization. This results in Ca2+ entry (via voltage-gated Ca2+ channels) that promotes exocytosis of secretory granules containing the insulin hormone. 

Other options:

Option A: Insulin promotes intracellular movement of potassium. This is believed to be due to a mechanism that involves insulin-mediated activation of Na+/K+ ATPase that promotes K+ influx into the cell, resulting in hypokalemia. Potassium plays an important role in insulin secretion from beta cells in the pancreatic islets as well. 

Option B: Insulin binds to transmembrane receptors that have tyrosine kinase activity in their intracellular subunits. There is subsequent autophosphorylation of these subunits that mediate the biological effects of insulin. One of the consequences is the growth-promoting protein anabolic effects carried out by phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K).

Option C: C peptide is the peptide segment that connects the A and B chains of the insulin (proinsulin). Once hormone granules are exocytosed from the beta islet cells, proinsulin is cleaved so as to be released in equimolar concentrations of insulin and C peptide.

questions.text: A young female patient presents to the gynecologist with complaints of severe itching in the vulva and foul-smelling, thin, green-colored vaginal discharge. Examination of the cervix shows the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the image depicting colpitis macularis or strawberry cervix is seen in trichomoniasis.

Trichomoniasis is caused by the organism Trichomonas vaginalis. It characteristically causes a copious, frothy, offensive yellow-green discharge with vaginal soreness or irritation and urinary frequency. 

In women, diagnosis is usually confirmed by examination of wet mount microscopy and direct visualization. However, a culture, usually in Feinberg–Whittington medium, gives the most reliable results. 

Standard treatment is with a single oral dose of 2 grams of metronidazole or 2 grams of tinidazole. Metronidazole 500 mg given orally for seven days is also effective.

Colpitis Macularis or Strawberry Cervix(image below) appearance results from microscopic, punctate hemorrhages of the cervix. 

Other options:

Option 1: Chlamydial cervicitis is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. Patients present with mucopurulent discharge or endocervical secretions, urethritis, dysuria, etc. On examination, the cervix may appear edematous and hyperemic.

The image below shows an inflamed cervix from chlamydia infection characterized by mucopurulent cervical discharge and erythema.

Option 3: Gonorrhea is a suppurative bacterial infection caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.The patient usually presents with profuse, odorless, non-irritant, white, or yellow vaginal discharge. They also have dysuria, deep dyspareunia, postcoital bleeding, and intermenstrual bleeding. The patient might also present with proctitis.

Option D: Granuloma inguinale, a genital ulcer is caused by the intracellular gram-negative bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis. It is also known as donovanosis. It presents as painless nodules that develop into ulcerative lesions. The ulcer is highly vascular with a beefy red appearance and subcutaneous granulomas extend to form pseudobuboes.

questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery suddenly developed a temperature of 102 F and a pulse rate of 130 bpm. His capnograph shows the following finding. Your senior resident injects intravenous dantrolene immediately. All the following drugs can be used in the treatment of this patient, except ______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia managed with intravenous dantrolene. All the above-mentioned drugs can be used in the treatment of this patient, except calcium channel blockers as they may cause hyperkalemia when used in combination with dantrolene.

The capnograph shows a sudden and progressive increase in EtCO2 which is typical of malignant hyperthermia. 

Dantrolene sodium is the mainstay of therapy for malignant hyperthermia but it is to be reconstituted with sterile distilled water. It is given at a dose of 2.5 mg/kg intravenously and can be repeated every 5-10 minutes (up to 10 mg/kg) till the attack subsides.

Correction of Electrolyte Imbalances:

  • Administer bicarbonate for metabolic acidosis.
  • Hyperkalemia should be treated with insulin.
  • Furosemide may be used to induce diuresis and prevent acute kidney failure.

Other treatment options:

  • All anesthetic agents should be cut off.
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2.
  • If the body temperature is high, it should be brought down using cold intravenous fluids, cooling body cavities with sterile iced fluids, surface cooling with ice packs, and cooling blankets.

A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor

The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression.

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman was evaluated for uterine bleeding. The histopathological examination of the endometrium showed a swiss-cheese pattern. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Swiss-cheese pattern in histopathological examination of endometrium in a premenopausal woman is suggestive of metropathia haemorrhagica. It is characterized by massive painless vaginal bleeding.

Metropathia haemorrhagica/ Cystic glandular hyperplasia/ Schroeder's disease: It is a specialized type of anovulatory abnormal uterine bleeding, usually seen in premenopausal women (40 to 45 years). Typically patients complain of continuous painless vaginal bleeding. It can occur after 6-8 weeks of amenorrhea or can be preceded by a period of menorrhagia.

The uterus becomes bulky due to symmetrical enlargement. The endometrium is thickened, and thin polypi project into the uterine cavity. There is also mild degree of myohyperplasia of the uterine wall. Ovaries may contain cysts, but the corpus luteum is absent.

Microscopy reveals:

  • Swiss cheese pattern of cystic glandular hyperplasia.
  • Absence of secretory endometrium- since the bleeding is anovulatory, there is no progesterone and hence no secretory changes in the endometrium. so the cork-screw glands are not seen.
  • Endometrium shows superficial necrosis resembling that of the first day of menstruation.

If the patient has a preceding history of amenorrhea, it can be confused with ectopic pregnancy or abortion. However, painless vaginal bleeding is the clue to differentiation.

questions.text:
Laboratory reports of a patient revealed an elevated serum potassium level. What is the classical sequence of ECG changes seen in this patient?
  1. Tall peaked T wave
  2. Loss of P wave
  3. Widened QRS complex
  4. Sine wave pattern
questions.solution:
Elevated serum potassium level is called hyperkalemia. The classical sequence of ECG changes seen with increasing severity of hyperkalemia is option B - 1, 2, 3, 4.

Hyperkalemia is defined by serum K+ > 5.5mM. It usually manifests as a medical emergency with cardiac arrhythmias such as sinus bradycardia, sinus arrest, slow idioventricular rhythms, ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.

Note: These changes are particularly insensitive in patients with CKD.

Image showing different sequential changes at increasing levels of potassium.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the intrauterine device shown below?

choices.text: It has silver added to the copper wire
It can be used as an emergency contraceptive
It has a lifespan of 10 years

questions.solution:
The given image shows the intrauterine contraceptive device, multi-load copper 250. It can be used for emergency contraception.

Mechanism of action:

Once placed inside the uterine cavity, the multi-load copper 250 device acts as a foreign body and induces inflammatory changes in the endometrium. Copper released from the device cause enzymatic and metabolic changes in the endometrium. It increases uterine contractility leading to the expulsion of the fertilized egg from the fallopian tube into the endometrium before the development of chorionic villi and ultimately, causes failure of implantation. The fertilized egg is then engulfed by the macrophages recruited due to the inflammatory changes. In addition, the device hinders the migration of the sperm.

The lifespan of multi-load copper 250 is about 3-5 years.

Other options:

Option A: Nova T has silver added to the copper wire which prolongs its lifespan to 5 years. 

Option C: Copper T 380 A (Paraguard) is effective as a contraceptive for up to 10 years, and is shown in the image below.

 Option D: Mirena IUCD contains levonorgestrel 52 mg, and is shown below

Other important intrauterine devices are progestasert having 38 mg of progesterone and levonova containing 60mg of levonorgestrel (LNG).

The given MRI is a T1-weighted image as the CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white, and grey matter is dark.

questions.text:
A patient is brought to the emergency room with polytrauma. Which of the following is not considered as an adjunct to the primary survey?

AP- Anteroposterior

PA- Posteroanterior
questions.solution:
Chest X-ray PA view is not a part of a primary survey. Chest X-ray is done in AP view in primary survey of trauma care.

The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support):

  • Primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation – identify and treat life-threatening conditions.
  • Secondary survey – proceed to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care – develop a definitive management plan

ABCDE of trauma care:

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate). If airway obstruction is identified, jaw thrust in cervical injury patients or chin lift is performed.
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment (maintain adequate oxygenation)
  • Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage and maintain adequate end-organ perfusion). Two wide-bore (14G to 16G) cannulae are inserted for intravenous fluid resuscitation.
  • Disability assessment (perform basic neurologic evaluation). This is most commonly assessed by the Glasgow coma scale along with pupil reactivity score (GCS-P).
  • Exposure, with environmental control (undress patient and search everywhere for possible injury, while preventing hypothermia)

Adjuncts to the primary survey: These help in the evaluation of other life-threatening processes.

Monitoring- 

  • Electrocardiograph (ECG) is done to evaluate cardiac dysrhythmias, myocardial infarction, and cardiac tamponade.
  • Continuous cardiac monitoring to detect any changes in heart rate and rhythm.
  • Continuous oxygen monitoring via pulse oximetry.
  • Ventilation monitoring via capnography and arterial blood gas analysis.

Catheters-

  • Urinary catheters help in the evaluation of fluid status.
  • Gastric catheters decompress the stomach and reduces the risk of aspiration.

Imaging-

  • Trauma triple radiographs of the cervical spine, chest, and pelvis, even in pregnant women. 
    • Cervical spine lateral view to look for spinal injury.
    • Chest AP view is done to evaluate for pneumothorax, hemothorax, rib fractures, or aortic injury.
    • Pelvis AP view to evaluate for pelvic fractures.
  • Ultrasound FAST Examination is the "Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma". It is performed to detect pericardial and intraperitoneal blood. The Extended FAST (E-FAST) includes examination of the thoracic cavity.
  • Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) is done to detect intraperitoneal bleed.
  • Emergency computed tomography (CT)

These specialised forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerised tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey, and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

Laboratory studies-

  • Arterial blood gas (ABG) to assess oxygentaion, ventilation, and pH.
  • Blood typing and grouping for blood transfusion.
  • Complete blood count and coagulation studies in anemic patients or patients using anticoagulation drugs.
  • Pregnancy test in any woman of child-bearing age.
  • Urinalysis in pelvic or abdominal trauma.
  • Urea and electrolytes, blood glucose levels, and toxicology studies in patients with unexplained altered mental status.

questions.text: A middle-aged lady was referred to a dermatology clinic for a lesion on her left cheek as shown in the image below. On diascopy, apple jelly nodules were seen. Skin biopsy showed tubercles with absent central caseation surrounded by epithelioid histiocytes in the superficial dermis.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows numerous reddish-brown papules with an elevated scaly surface and scarring. These lesions, together with the features of apple jelly nodules on diascopy and tubercles with absent central caseation, point towards a diagnosis of lupus vulgaris.

Lupus vulgaris is a chronic, progressive, paucibacillary form of cutaneous tuberculosis which occurs in previously sensitized individuals. The characteristic lesion is a plaque, consisting of soft, reddish-brown papules. It grows by slow peripheral extension, becoming discoid in shape with areas of atrophy. The lesions are acquired either by hematogenous spread or by direct inoculation. 

There are five clinical variants of lupus vulgaris:

  • Plaque form
  • Ulcerative and mutilating forms
  • Vegetating form
  • Tumor-like forms
  • Papular and nodular form

On diascopy, characteristic 'apple jelly nodules' are seen. Histology shows tubercles with scanty or absent central caseation, surrounded by epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells, present in the superficial dermis. Usually, tubercle bacilli are scanty or absent. Treatment is by standard multidrug antituberculosis therapy.

Complications include scarring, contractures, and tissue destruction. Malignant changes (most commonly, squamous cell carcinomas) are known to arise in longstanding lupus vulgaris.

Other options:

Option A: Acne vulgaris- Lesions are due to inflammation of the pilosebaceous unit. It can present with open and closed comedones and/or papules, pustules, and nodules.

Option C: Tuberculoid leprosy- Typical lesions are erythematous, copper-colored, or purple plaques, with raised edges sloping towards a hypopigmented center.

Option D: Discoid lupus erythematosus: It is an inflammatory disorder of the skin. The lesions are characterized by well‐defined red, scaly patches of variable size.

questions.text: The structure that is related to the area marked 'A' in the given image is derived from:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the left lung and structure related to the marked area 'A' is the arch of the aorta which is derived from the left fourth aortic arch.

In the given image, the left lung is identified by the presence of the vertical sequence of structures at the left hilum - pulmonary artery, principal (hyparterial) bronchus, and inferior pulmonary vein. The image also shows an oblique fissure dividing the lung into superior and inferior lobes.

The aortic arches or pharyngeal arch arteries are a series of six paired embryological vascular structures. They give rise to the great arteries of the neck and head. They are ventral to the dorsal aorta and arise from the aortic sac.

The 4th aortic arch persists on both sides and forms different structures on either side:

  • Left side - part of the arch of the aorta between the left common carotid and the left subclavian arteries
  • Right side - proximal segment of the right subclavian artery

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.
