questions.text: In a statistical analysis, the following scatter plot is obtained. What is the inference about the correlation coefficient according to the plot?

choices.text: There is a linear negative correlation with correlation coefficient equal to -1
There is a linear positive correlation with correlation coefficient equal to +1
There is a linear positive correlation with correlation coefficient equal to zero
There is a linear negative correlation with correlation coefficient equal to zero

questions.solution:
The above scatter plot shows a linear positive correlation, with the correlation coefficient +1 [rise in the value of (X) proportionately raises the value of (Y)]

The correlation coefficient can be determined using the appearance of the scatter plot. In the given scatter plot, all the plotted points can fit a straight line perfectly. Hence the correlation coefficient is +1. Conversely, if it is not possible to draw a straight line that would fit the plotted points, the correlation coefficient would be zero.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: A 3-year-old toxic child presents with tachypnea, high-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and developed difficulty in swallowing with drooling of saliva within 4-6 hours of fever. Along with airway management which of the following needs to be given?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of a toxic-looking child with high-grade fever, tachypnea, inspiratory stridor, dysphagia, and salivary drooling strongly suggests acute epiglottitis. Once the airway is secured, empirical antimicrobial therapy with intravenous ceftriaxone is recommended in the management of acute epiglottitis. 

The most common causative agents of epiglottitis in vaccinated children are Streptococcus pyogenes, Streptococcus pneumoniae, non-typeable Haemophilus influenzae, and Staphylococcus aureus. The incidence of Haemophilus influenzae type B has decreased significantly due to vaccination. 

The child presents with a high fever, sore throat, dyspnea, dysphagia, and progressive respiratory obstruction. The child may exhibit a toxic appearance, with salivary drooling and assuming a tripod position. The presence of stridor indicates near-complete obstruction of the airway.

Laryngoscopy should be promptly conducted in a controlled setting, such as an operating room or intensive care unit when the diagnosis of epiglottitis is certain or likely based on clinical evaluation. 

Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency due to unpredictable clinical course and sudden airway obstruction. Immediate airway management through endotracheal or nasotracheal intubation or tracheostomy is crucial, regardless of the severity of respiratory distress. Empiric treatment with antibiotics like ceftriaxone, cefepime, or meropenem is recommended until culture and susceptibility results are available. Dexamethasone may also be administered to reduce pharyngeal edema. 

Other options: 

Option A: Nebulisation with racemic adrenaline is given in moderate to severe croup. 

The image below shows the thumb sign in epiglottitis: 

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: Which of the following ultrasonographic findings is seen in a pregnant woman with dichorionic twins?
questions.solution:
Twin peak/Lambda sign is seen in dichorionic pregnancy.

The "twin peak sign" appears as a triangular projection of the chorion extending between the amnion layers. A thick dividing membrane consisting of two amnion and two chorion layers points towards the diagnosis of dichorionic pregnancy.

Note: T sign is the absence of a twin peak sign. There is a lack of chorion extending between the amnion layers and hence, suggestive of a monochorionic pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with COVID-19 infection develops shortness of breath and is brought to the hospital. His SpO2 increases from 81% to 83% on administering oxygen via facemask at 10 L/min. The decision to deliver oxygen using the device shown below is made. What is its oxygen delivery rate?
questions.solution:
The equipment shown in the image is high-flow nasal cannula. It delivers oxygen at 40-60 L/min. This patient has persistent hypoxia after an adequate trial of standard oxygen therapy and should be started on high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy. 

High flow nasal cannula is a mode of respiratory support used in the management of acute respiratory failure. It delivers humidified gas via the nasal cannula at high flow rates.

  • HFNC can deliver oxygen at 40 L/min, 37°C, and 99.9% relative humidity.
  • The high-flow oxygen is delivered directly to the nasopharynx. This produces FiO2 equal to that delivered by traditional mask devices.
  • The benefits of HFNC include reduced work of breathing, improved gas exchange by nasopharyngeal dead-space washout, and decreased energy required to humidify and heat respiratory gases.

The HFNC equipment shown in the image below uses a heated humidifier (named PMH200), a nasal cannula (No. 2), and a ventilator (brand: vivo30).

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with fissured tongue and peripheral neuropathy. Investigations showed reduced glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin deficiency is the likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from riboflavin/vitamin B2 deficiency.

Deficiency of riboflavin is characterized by cheilosis, desquamation, and inflammation of the tongue, seborrheic dermatitis, corneal vascularization, anemia, and personality changes.

Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

questions.text:
A male patient was diagnosed with primary open-angle glaucoma. Sequentially arrange the following visual field defects that would be seen in this patient starting from the earliest to appear.
  1. Ring scotoma
  2. Bjerrum's scotoma
  3. Seidel scotoma
  4. Paracentral scotoma
questions.solution:
Option D is correct. The correct sequence of visual defects in primary open-angle glaucoma is as follows:

  • Paracentral scotoma
  • Seidel scotoma
  • Bjerrum's Scotoma
  • Ring scotoma.

Related Pearl: Visual field Defects in Open-Angle Glaucoma

questions.text: A  primigravida patient was admitted with complaints of epigastric pain, headache, and visual symptoms. Her blood pressure was 170/100mm Hg, and proteinuria 3+ was present. Her gestational age is 36 weeks. It was decided to start Pritchard's regimen, What is the maintenance dose of magnesium sulfate?
questions.solution:
The woman has developed preeclampsia which is evident by the given clinical scenario and findings and according to Pritchard's regimen, the maintenance dose of magnesium sulfate is 5g intramuscularly, 4 hourly in alternate buttocks.

Preeclampsia is a multisystem disorder with unknown aetiology and characterised by blood pressure of >140/90 mm hg or proteinuria in a woman who was previous normotensive and non-proteinuric. 

Magnesium sulfate regimens in the management of pre-eclampsia:

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minute
followed by 10g (5O%), deep IM
(5 gm in each buttock)		 5g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttocks
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4-6 g IV slow over 15-20 minute 1-2g/h IV infusion

It is continued for 24 hours after the last seizure or delivery whichever is later.

Repeat injections of magnesium sulfate are given only if:

  • Knee jerks are present
  • Urine output > 30 mL/h
  • Respiratory rate > 12/minute
The therapeutic level of serum magnesium is 4–7 mEq/L.

 Magnesium toxicity can be suspected if there is 

  1. Loss of deep tendon reflexes at serum Mg > 7 mEq/L
  2. Respiratory depression at serum Mg > 10 mEq/L and 
  3. Cardiac arrest at serum Mg > 25 mEq/L.

Magnesium toxicity is managed by stopping magnesium therapy after which serum magnesium and creatinine levels are estimated. Then, intravenous calcium gluconate 10 ml is injected.

Magnesium sulfate is also used for the management of torsades de pointes in pregnancy.

questions.text: The function of the Golgi tendon organ is to _________

choices.text: Sense changes in position of the muscle
Sense changes in length of the muscle

questions.solution:
Golgi tendon organ sense changes in muscle tension.

Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex) is disynaptic, is the opposite of the stretch reflex.

When the tension in a contracted muscle is significantly elevated, the inhibitory effect from the Golgi tendon organ leads to instantaneous relaxation of the entire muscle. This effect is called the lengthening reaction.

It is a protective mechanism to prevent tearing of the muscle or avulsion of the tendon from its attachments to the bone.

Note: Muscle spindles senses changes in muscle length (stretch).

questions.text:
You are an intern posted in the labor ward. You see that a pregnant woman at her 32nd week of gestation has a BPP score of 2. Her BPP score remained the same when monitored for the next two hours. What is the next best step in this case?

BPP - biophysical profile
questions.solution:
A persistent biophysical profile (BPP) score of 2 for 2 hours points towards fetal asphyxia. Immediate delivery should be done regardless of the gestational age in this patient.

BPP is a multi-parametric screening test to assess uteroplacental insufficiency. It consists of five components (Mnemonic: BATMaN):

B - Breathing movements of the fetus
A - Amniotic fluid volume
T - Tone of the fetus
M - Movements of the fetus
N - Non-stress test (NST)

Parameters Minimal Normal Criteria
Fetal breathing movements ≥ 1 episode lasting over 30 seconds
Amniotic fluid volume (AFV) ≥ 1 pocket measuring 2 cm in two perpendicular planes (2 ×2 cm pocket)
Fetal muscle tone ≥ 1 episode of active limb or trunk extension with the return of flexion; Eg. opening and closing of the hand
Gross body movements   ≥ 3 body or limb movements
Non-stress Test (NST) Reactive

Each parameter has a maximum score of 2 and a minimum score of 0. So the total maximum score will be 10.

Interpretation of BPP scores:

BPP score Interpretation Management
8-10 Normal, nonasphyxiated fetus Repeat test weekly (or biweekly in diabetic mother or post-term pregnancy)
6 Possible fetal asphyxia

Deliver, if AFV is abnormal or >36weeks or if the repeat test score is ≤ 6

If the repeat score >6, observation and repeat test weekly
4 Probable fetal asphyxia

If >36 weeks then deliver

If <32 weeks - repeat testing the same day - if persistently low, then deliver
0-2 Almost certain fetal asphyxia Test for 2 hours - if persistent score of ≤ 4 - then deliver regardless of gestational age

questions.text: A child suffering from steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome is brought to the OPD for vaccination. Which of the following is true about vaccination in this child?

choices.text: All live vaccines under NIS can be given as per schedule
All killed vaccines under NIS can be given
Only pneumococcal vaccine should be given to the child in acute phase
Live vaccines are contraindicated in the child’s sibling

questions.solution:
In a child with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome, all killed vaccines can be given.

Option A: Live virus vaccines are administered with caution in children receiving corticosteroid therapy. They can be given to patients in whom the prednisone dose is below 1mg/kg daily or 2mg/kg on alternate days. If the patient is receiving corticosteroid-sparing agents (cyclophosphamide, cyclosporine), live virus vaccines are contraindicated. 

Option C: Only live vaccines are contraindicated in this child. Full pneumococcal vaccination (with the 13-valent conjugate vaccine and 23-valent polysaccharide vaccine) and influenza vaccination can be given annually to the child and their household contacts.

Option D: Immunization of siblings/healthy household contacts with live vaccines is necessary to reduce the risk of infection transmission to the immunosuppressed child. Direct exposure to the gastrointestinal/respiratory secretions of the household contacts is avoided for about 3-6 weeks after vaccination. 

Minimal change nephrotic syndrome is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. It is characterized by heavy proteinuria, edema, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. The diagnosis is confirmed by performing a urinalysis and urine protein: creatinine ratio. Nephrotic range proteinuria is proteinuria greater than 3.5 g per 24 hours (3+ or 4+) or a urine protein : creatinine ratio exceeding 2.

The recommended initial treatment for nephrotic syndrome is a daily dose of 2mg/kg (max 60mg) of prednisolone for 6 weeks followed by an alternate dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for the next 6-8 weeks. 

Definitions regarding the course of nephrotic syndrome: 

  • Frequently relapsing nephrotic syndrome: ≥2 relapses in 6 months or 3 or more relapses in 12 months.
  • Steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome: Relapse during steroid tapering or within 2 weeks of discontinuation.
  • Steroid resistance: Failure to achieve remission despite therapy with daily prednisolone for 6 weeks 

Alternative drugs used in steroid-dependent patients, frequent relapsers, steroid-resistant patients, and those with severe corticosteroid toxicity are cyclophosphamide, calcineurin inhibitors: cyclosporine and Tacrolimus, mycophenolate, levamisole, and rituximab (a chimeric monoclonal antibody against CD20).

questions.text: Which of the following histological features are seen in osteosarcoma?

choices.text: Pleomorphic cells and osteoid arranged in a fine, lacelike pattern
Mosaic pattern of lamellar bone with cement lines
Sheets of uniform small, round cells arranged in Homer-Wright rosettes
Osteoclast-type giant cells with multiple nuclei

questions.solution:
The histological features of osteosarcoma include pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and abundant mitoses. The diagnosis is definitive with the presence of malignant tumor cells producing unmineralized osteoid or mineralized bone arranged in a typical fine, lacelike pattern.

Histological appearance of osteosarcoma:

 

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor. Primary osteosarcomas present most commonly during adolescence whereas secondary osteosarcomas present during the 7th decade of life. They arise from the metaphysis of long bones, especially the distal femur or the proximal tibia (i.e. around the knee joint).

Other options:

Option B - Mosaic pattern of lamellar bone with cement lines is diagnostic of Paget disease. Paget disease is characterized by the formation of disordered and structurally unstable bone (osteolytic phase ---> mixed osteolytic-osteoblastic phase --->osteosclerotic phase). During the osteosclerotic phase, osteoblastic activity is predominant. This is reflected in the arrangement of lamellar bone units in a mosaic pattern by distinct cement lines, giving it a jigsaw puzzle-like appearance. 

Histological appearance of Paget disease:

 

Option C- Sheets of uniform, round cells arranged in Homer-Wright rosettes are characteristic of Ewing sarcoma. These cells are of neuroectodermal origin and have minimal cytoplasm and abundant glycogen. When they are arranged around a central fibrillary core in the form of clusters, the appearance is termed Homer-Wright rosettes. 

Histological appearance of Ewing sarcoma:

 

Option D- Osteoclast-type giant cells with multiple nuclei are characteristic of giant cell tumors/osteoclastoma. These cells are usually present against a backdrop of mononuclear stromal cells.

questions.text: The image below shows the dissection of the right side of the neck, and the red arrow denotes the right subclavian artery. What is not true about the structure labeled as A?

choices.text: It arises mainly from C4 spinal nerve.
The right side nerve is shorter than the left.
It is formed at the lateral border of scalenus anterior.
It is purely a motor nerve.

questions.solution:
The structure labeled as A is the right phrenic nerve, and it is a mixed nerve (sensory and motor nerve).

 It is derived mostly from the C4 ramus and also receives contributions from the C3 and C5 ventral rami. It is formed at the lateral border of scalenus anterior.

At the root of the neck, the right phrenic nerve runs anterior to the second part of the right subclavian artery from which it is seperated by scalenus anterior muscle. The phrenic nerve lies posterior to the right subclavian vein.

Right phrenic nerve is shorter and more vertical than the left.

Each phrenic nerve provides the sole motor supply to its hemidiaphragm. In its thoracic course, each phrenic nerve supplies sensory branches to the central parts of the diaphragm.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy comes to the emergency department after a fall. On physical examination, there is pain and swelling in the left wrist region. The X-ray of his wrist joint is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the X-ray showing compression on one side of the radius causing the other side to bend/ buckle suggests a torus fracture.

Torus fracture is also called a buckle fracture. It is caused due to an axial loading force acting along the long axis of a long bone. This results in compression on one side and bending of the other side of the trabecular part of the long bone.

It most commonly occurs at the transition between the metaphysis and diaphysis of the cortex. It is commonly seen occurring at the distal radius in young children. Management includes immobilization and splinting for 3-4 weeks.

The given image indicates the site of the torus fracture:

Greenstick fractures are commonly seen in children. These are incomplete fractures where one side of the cortex is broken but the other side remains intact.

The image given below shows a greenstick fracture:

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male patient is suggested to undergo surgery for shoulder dislocation. Which of the following nerve block is recommended?
questions.solution:
Interscalene block is recommended for the surgical procedures involving the shoulder.

In interscalene block, the blockade occurs at the level of the superior and middle trunks of brachial plexus. It is performed by injecting a local anesthetic to the nerves of the brachial plexus as it passes through the groove between the anterior and middle scalene muscles, at the level of the cricoid cartilage.

Advantages of this block include rapid blockade of the shoulder region, and relatively easily palpable anatomical landmarks.

Disadvantages of this block include inadequate anesthesia in the distribution of the ulnar nerve, which makes this an unreliable block for operations involving the forearm and hand.

Image below depicts an interscalene block.

Other options:

Option A: Indications for a supraclavicular block are operations on the elbow, forearm, and hand. Blockade occurs at the distal trunk-proximal division level.

Image below depicts a supraclavicular block.

Option B: Infraclavicular block provides anesthesia to the arm and hand. Blockade occurs at the level of the cords.

Image below shows an infraclavicular block.

Option D: Indications for axillary block include surgery to the forearm and hand. Elbow procedures are also performed. Blockade occurs at the level of the terminal nerves. Although blockade of the musculocutaneous nerve is not always produced with this approach, it can be supplemented at the level of the axilla or at the elbow.

Image below depicts an axillary block.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with fever, cough, dyspnea, arthralgia, and a painful rash on the lower limbs suggestive of erythema nodosum. A chest X-ray was taken and the findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The chest X-ray showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, together with the presence of erythema nodosum, suggests the diagnosis of sarcoidosis.

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disorder of unknown etiology that is characterized by the presence of non-caseating granulomas.

In acute cases, patients may typically present with Lofgren’s syndrome, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum (as shown below), uveitis, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, lethargy, and occasional fever. Patients may also present with insidious onset of cough, exertional breathlessness, and radiographic infiltrates.

 

Investigation findings in sarcoidosis are as follows:

  • Lymphopenia and deranged liver function tests 
  • Hypercalcemia (due to increased synthesis of calcitriol [1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D] by alveolar macrophages) and hypercalciuria (can lead to nephrocalcinosis)
  • Pulmonary function test - the most common abnormality is an isolated decrease in diffusion of carbon monoxide (DLCO). A restrictive pattern is seen in patients with more advanced pulmonary disease. Approximately 15-20% of patients have an obstructive pattern
  • Bronchoscopy shows a typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa. Bronchial and transbronchial biopsies reveal non-caseating granulomas. An increased CD4:CD8 T-cell ratio may be seen in bronchoalveolar lavage
  • Chest X-ray is useful for staging sarcoidosis
  • HRCT shows reticulonodular opacities that follow a perilymphatic distribution centered on broncho-vascular bundles and the subpleural areas

The presence of erythema nodosum with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray is sufficient to make the diagnosis of sarcoidosis. A tissue biopsy is not required in this case. A typical presentation with classical HRCT features may also indicate the diagnosis. In all other cases, the diagnosis should be confirmed by histological examination of the involved organ.

A chest X-ray showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy in sarcoidosis is shown below,

questions.text:
A 66-year-old male patient presented with complaints of fatiguability and chronic back pain. On evaluation, he was found to have anemia and hypercalcemia. The X-ray of his skull is given below. Which of the following is not seen in this patient?
  1. Plasma cells in 24-hr urine analysis
  2. Elevated Alkaline phosphatase
  3. Normocytic normochromic anemia 
  4. Osteolytic bone lesions
  5. Elevated ESR
questions.solution:
Statements 1 and 2 are incorrect/ not seen in this patient.

The given X-ray of the skull demonstrating the typical “punched out” lesions in an elderly male with chronic back pain, fatigue, anemia, and hypercalcemia are highly suggestive of multiple myeloma. It is characterized by normal serum alkaline phosphatase (due to the absence of osteoblastic activity), and plasma cells in bone marrow (not in urine).

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. It is associated with an increased osteoclast activity with suppression of osteoblast activity, causing punched-out lytic lesions in the bone and hypercalcemia.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Bone pain is the most common symptom
  • Pathologic fractures
  • Recurrent bacterial infections
  • Renal failure
  • Normocytic normochromic anemia, elevated ESR, hypercalcemia, normal ALP (ALP is a marker of bone growth and hence is not increased in multiple myeloma)
  • Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray
  • Electrophoresis: M spikes
  • Urinalysis: Bence Jones proteinuria
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Plasma cells

questions.text: A 24-year-old man met with an RTA and was brought to the casualty after 6 hours. His B.P. was 90/60 mm Hg, heart rate was 110/min, and SpO2 was 92%. A blood transfusion was done. After a few hours, the patient is febrile, tachypneic, and starts bleeding from the IV and NG tube sites. His SpO2 levels started falling. What could be the cause?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of this patient (bleeding from the IV catheter and nasogastric tube sites) are suggestive of DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation) within a few hours of blood transfusion. Hence, the most likely cause of this presentation is an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction.

These reactions are mediated by pre-existing IgM antibodies that act against the polysaccharide blood group antigens A or B. They bind to the red cells and cause complement-mediated lysis which further leads to intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria. Severe cases may present with DIC, which is a consumptive coagulopathy with bleeding manifestations. Other complications include shock, acute kidney injury, and sometimes, death.

 

The various blood transfusion reactions according to their time of occurrence are as follows:

  • Anaphylactic reaction - Within a few seconds to minutes of the transfusion
  • Allergic/Urticarial reactions - Within 2-3 hours of transfusion
  • Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) - Within 24 hours of transfusion
  • Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR) - Within 6 hours of transfusion
  • Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction (DHTR) - After 24 hours of transfusion

 

Other options:

Option b- Acute adrenal crisis usually presents as an unexplained shock that is refractory to fluids and vasopressors.

Option c- Fat embolism is associated with fractures of the long bones. It develops within 2-3 days of fracture/trauma. Moreover, a history of petechial rash is characteristic of fat embolism.

Option d- Hemorrhagic shock presents as tachypnea, tachycardia, narrow pulse pressure, and oliguria. Cold extremities and delayed capillary refill time are other features. In this case, hemorrhagic shock might occur as a consequence of bleeding due to DIC, but the cause of this presentation is transfusion reaction.

questions.text: During history-taking, a patient was responding to the questions with unnecessary and irrelevant responses. He gave excessive details before he finally answered the question.  Which of the following best describes the patient's thought disorder?
questions.solution:
The thought disorder known as circumstantiality best describes this patient's thought disorder.

Circumstantiality refers to a formal thought disorder in which a patient gives irrelevant and unnecessary details. This is before finally getting to the point or the correct answer. It may be seen in schizophrenia, obsessional distur­bances, and certain cases of dementia. An example is given below.

Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper, and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

A formal thought disorder is a disturbance in the formulation of thoughts and their expression. It is characterized by loosened associations, illogical constructs, and neologisms. Derailment, neologism, perseveration, and thought blocking are some examples.

Other options:

Option A: Clang association is a formal thought disorder where the thoughts are associated with the sound of words through rhyming, rather than the meaning of the words. It is usually seen in schizophrenia or mania. An example is "I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

Option B: Flight of ideas refers to a rapid succession of multiple associations, where the thoughts appear to abruptly shift from one idea to another. It is usually seen in mania. An example is "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

Option D: Tagentiality is a formal thought disorder where the patient says something that is related to the general topic. Although, the actual answer is not given. An example is as below.

Doctor: "How has your appetite been lately?"
Patient: "I usually have dinner with my wife, but now I eat alone"

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the clinic after he experienced palpitations. He has a history of ischemic heart disease.  His ECG findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is likely to be seen on physical examination of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows atrial fibrillation. On physical examination of his jugular venous pressure, absent 'a' waves will be noted. 

The following features in the ECG strip suggest the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation:

  • Presence of fibrillatory 'f' waves is indicative of uncoordinated atrial activation. Normal morphology P waves (indicative of normal atrial contraction) are absent
  • The QRS complex duration is <120 ms, which is normal. A narrow QRS complex indicates that the impulses are originating from the atria
  • R waves (QRS complex) occur irregularly, indicative of a variable RR interval. The rhythm is irregular (the pace is set by the refractory period of the AV node)

The 'a' wave is the first peak on a JVP tracing. It represents the atrial contraction (atrial systole). The rapid impulses of atrial fibrillation do not allow enough time for atrial filling and atrial contraction, leading to absent 'a' waves on JVP. 

In acute atrial fibrillation with hemodynamic instability, electrical or chemical cardioversion is the first step. The latter is done by intravenous administration of class III antiarrhythmic - ibutilide. In a stable patient, ventricular rate control is the primary aim. This is done by intravenous or oral administration of beta-blockers. Calcium channel blockers such as verapamil and diltiazem can also be used. 

If the current episode duration is >48 hours, cardioversion can precipitate thromboembolic complications. In such cases, cardioversion should be carried out only after 3 weeks of anticoagulation. It has to be continued for 4 weeks after cardioversion. Another option is to evaluate the presence of a thrombus in the left atrial appendage. This can be done either by transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) or high-resolution CT.

If the duration is <48 hours and there are no high-risk factors, cardioversion can be done. CHA2DS2-VASc scoring system is used to assess stroke risk. 

Warfarin is recommended in patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves who present with atrial fibrillation. In mitral stenosis, thrombi arise frequently from the dilated left atrium. Atrial fibrillation in the absence of mitral stenosis is known as nonvalvular atrial fibrillation. Oral factor Xa inhibitors such as apixaban, edoxaban, or rivaroxaban can be used in such cases.

questions.text: Which of the following WHO strategies to control trachoma is considered as primordial prevention?
questions.solution:
Environmental cleanliness is considered as primordial prevention in the WHO strategies to control trachoma.

WHO programme for prophylaxis against trachoma infection and prevention of blindness is SAFE strategy. It includes:

  • Surgery - Tertiary prevention.
  • Antibiotic use - Secondary prevention.
  • Facial hygiene - Primary prevention.
  • Environmental changes - Primordial prevention.

Trachoma is chronic keratoconjunctivitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis and is one of the leading causes of preventable blindness in the world. Features are foreign body sensation, lacrimation, mucoid discharge etc. On examination, conjunctival follicles resembling boiled sago grains are seen. The follicles if present on the bulbar conjunctiva, is pathognomic. Herbert's follicles may be seen at the limbus. The cornea may get infiltrated and vascularized leading to progressive pannus.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures 

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

Related Pearl: Trachoma Staging

The four stages of trachoma according to McCallan are as follows:

Stage 1: Incipient 

  • Immature follicles are present, but clinical symptoms are not obvious.

Stage 2: Established

  • Typical trachomatous lesions without scarring.

Stage 3: Cicatrising

  • Scarring along with active infection.

Stage 4: Healed

  • Only scarring, the disease is either cured or quiet.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presents with a history of easy bruisiability and hemarthrosis. Investigations revealed normal platelet count and bleeding time, normal PT, and prolonged PTT. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptom of hemarthrosis and the investigations are suggestive of a coagulation disorder. Among the given options, hemophilia A is a coagulation disorder, while all the other conditions are platelet disorders.

Bleeding into joints (hemarthrosis) and deep tissues is a feature of coagulation disorders, whereas platelet disorders usually present with mucocutaneous bleeding such as petechiae, purpura, epistaxis, or GI bleed. Prolonged PT/aPTT is a feature of coagulation disorders, while prolonged bleeding time is a feature of platelet disorders.

In the given scenario, normal platelet count and bleeding time exclude platelet disorders. Normal PT indicates normal functioning of the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, and prolonged PTT indicates a defect in the intrinsic pathway.

Hemophilia is an X-linked (recessive) coagulation disorder associated with mutations in factor VIII, affecting the intrinsic pathway. The patients present with easy bruising, significant hemorrhage following trauma and operative procedures, and hemarthroses, but no petechiae. The diagnosis is confirmed by carrying out factor VIII-specific assays. Infusions of recombinant factor VIII are used for treatment. 

Other options:

Option 1: Von Willebrand disease is an autosomal dominant disorder that is associated with qualitative/quantitative defects in the von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is a protein necessary for platelet adhesion, platelet aggregation, and stabilization of factor VIII.

Option 3: Bernard-Soulier disease is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIb receptor necessary for platelet adhesion to the subendothelial collagen. 

Option 4: Glanzmann's thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIIb/IIIa receptor necessary for platelet aggregation.

questions.text: A patient on chloroquine treatment for malaria suffers a category II dog bite. He approaches you for immunization. Which among the following would you consider as correct regarding the rabies vaccination in this case?

choices.text: Vaccination needs to be delayed till completion of chloroquine dose
Patient may receive the vaccine intradermally as usual
Patient should receive the vaccine intramuscularly

questions.solution:
The patient should receive the vaccine intramuscularly in this case.

People receiving chloroquine for malaria treatment or prophylaxis have a reduced response to intradermal rabies vaccination. Therefore, these patients should receive the vaccine intramuscularly.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text:
An HIV-positive female patient presents with fever and dry cough for 4 weeks. Her chest X-ray is given below and her CD4+ T cell count is 150 cells/ microliter. A lung biopsy was done that showed foamy alveolar infiltrates and mononuclear interstitial infiltrates on H & E staining. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?

H & E - hematoxylin and eosin
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, chest x-ray findings of diffuse interstitial infiltrate and H & E staining findings are suggestive of pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii and co-trimoxazole is the drug of choice for treatment as well as prophylaxis.

Pneumocystis jirovecii is an opportunistic fungus that is found in patients having a CD4+ T cell count <200/µL.

The clinical picture is non-specific with complaints of indolent course of fever, cough, pleuritic pain, and unexplained weight loss. Lab and radiographic findings are also non-specific and show an increase in lactate dehydrogenase levels and symmetric, perihilar, and diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates, respectively. 

Hematoxylin and eosin staining of lung tissue showing foamy alveolar infiltrates and a mononuclear interstitial infiltrate is pathognomonic for P. jirovecii pneumonia (PCP). Demonstration of the organism in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid is 100% specific and sensitive for PCP in patients with HIV. 

 

Methenamine silver stain showing black-colored cyst wall of Pneumocystis jirovecii

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole combination (commonly known as co-trimoxazole) is the treatment of choice for PCP, and it is administered for 21 days, followed by a course for secondary prophylaxis. Concomitantly, glucocorticoids should also be administered to reduce pulmonary inflammation.

Patients who are susceptible to PCP are also given co-trimoxazole as prophylaxis. For patients who are unable to tolerate co-trimoxazole, IV pentamidine is the drug of choice.

Prophylaxis is indicated for other opportunistic infections like Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection, if CD4 counts fall below 50 cells/µL; Coccidioides, if CD count is <250/µL; and Cryptococcus, when the CD count is <100/µL.

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

 

 

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-

    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-

    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)

Neoplasms:

questions.text:
During a central line insertion, the patient suffers a pleural puncture and develops breathing difficulty and sharp pain. There is an absence of breath sounds on the right side. A chest X-ray is done and appears as shown below. A needle is inserted in the 2nd intercostal space as an emergency measure. However, the breathing difficulty persists and a decision to insert an intercostal drain is taken. You would insert the chest drain into the triangle that lies _________.
  1. Posterior to the midaxillary line
  2. Anterior to the mid-axillary line
  3. Above the level of the nipple
  4. Below the level of the nipple
  5. Above and Medial to the pectoralis muscle
  6. Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. The safest site for insertion of a chest drain is the triangle of safety which lies:

  • Anterior to the mid-axillary line;
  • Above the level of the nipple;
  • Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

This will be present in the fifth intercostal space.

Pneumothorax refers to the collection of air between the lung and chest wall causing the lung to collapse. Tension pneumothorax develops when a "one-way valve" air leak occurs either from the lung or through the chest wall. Air is sucked into the thoracic cavity without any means of escape, completely collapsing and then compressing the affected lung.

Tension pneumothorax is characterized by chest pain, tachypnea, tachycardia, hypotension, tracheal deviation away from the side of injury, unilateral absence of breath sound, cyanosis, and neck vein distension.

Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed waiting for radiological confirmation.

Treatment consists of immediate decompression, initially by rapid insertion of a large-bore cannula on the affected side.

Due to the variable thickness of the chest wall, kinking of the catheter, and other technical or anatomic complications, needle decompression may not always be successful. In this case, finger thoracostomy is an alternative approach and is recommended as the next best step. 

Tube thoracostomy is mandatory after needle or finger decompression of the chest and is the definitive management.

The technique of drain insertion includes the following:

  • The area should be thoroughly sterilized before the procedure.
  • Adequate local anesthesia to include the pleura.
  • Sharp dissection should be done to cut only the skin.
  • Blunt dissection with artery forceps down through the muscle layers; which involve the serratus anterior and the intercostals.
  • An oblique tract is made so that the skin incision and the hole in the parietal pleura do not overlie each other and so that the drain is in a short tunnel, which reduces the chance of entraining air.
  • A drain for pneumothorax and haemothorax should aim towards the apex of the lung.
  • A drain for pleural effusion or empyema should be nearer the base.
  • The drain should pass over the upper edge of the rib to avoid injury to the neurovascular bundle that lies beneath the rib. 
  • A vertical mattress suture is inserted for later wound closure. This is important for pneumothorax management but not required if the drain is for empyema (provided there is the adherence of the pleura) because that tract should lie open.
  •  The drain should be connected to an underwater seal device which functions as a one-way valve.
  • Do not attach to a suction device at another end because it may worsen the air leak if the lung is fragile or might even cause a shift of mediastinum if the lung doesn't expand well
  • After completion, check the position of the drain by taking a chest radiograph.

questions.text: Identify the following.

choices.text: A- Cancellous screw; B - Malleolar screw; C - Cortical screw
A- Malleolar screw; B - Cancellous screw; C - Cortical screw
A- Malleolar screw; B - Cortical screw; C - Cancellous screw
A- Cancellous screw; B - Cortical screw; C - Malleolar screw

questions.solution:
In the given image: 

  • A represents a malleolar screw
  • B represents a cortical screw
  • C represents a cancellous screw

Identification features of the screws are as follows:

Malleolar screw: Modified cancellous screw with a sharp-pointed tip. It can be inserted without pre-drilling. These screws are used for internal fixation of malleolar fractures.

 

Cancellous screw: Larger thread, high pitch, compression by partial threading with a blunt tip. The larger threads provide for more purchase in the soft cancellous bone. 

 

Cortical screw: Smaller thread, low pitch, compression produced by over drilling proximal cortex. The whole length of these screws is threaded and has a diameter of 2–4.5 mm. It functions as a positional screw or a lag screw for interfragmentary compression.

 

Most orthopedic implants are made of titanium-based alloys because they are highly resistant to corrosion.

questions.text: A male patient was diagnosed with an aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery. He has ocular symptoms suggestive of third cranial nerve palsy. Which of the following muscle is not supplied by this nerve?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked as "3" in the image is superior oblique and is innervated by the trochlear nerve (4th cranial nerve). All the other muscles marked in the image are supplied by the oculomotor nerve (3rd cranial nerve).

1 Superior rectus
2 Levator palpebrae superioris 
3 Superior oblique
4 Inferior oblique

There are seven extraocular muscles present in the eye. They are:

  • Levator palpebrae superioris - Which elevates the upper eyelids
  • Four recti muscles - Superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti
  • Two obliques - Superior and inferior oblique

The four recti muscles originate from the back of the orbit in a common tendinous ring called the annulus of Zinn and are inserted into the sclera in the anterior half of the eyeball.

Levator palpebrae superioris originates from the lesser wing of the sphenoid anterior to the optic canal and inserts into the tarsal plate, superior conjunctival fornix, and skin. 

Superior oblique originates from the body of the sphenoid, superior and medial to optic canal. The Inferior oblique originates from the medial floor of the orbit and maxilla. They are inserted into the sclera of the outer posterior quadrant of the eyeball in the superior surface and inferior surface respectively.

All the extraocular muscles (including inferior oblique) are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

  • Lateral rectus which is supplied by abducens (VI) nerve
  • Superior oblique which is supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve

Related Pearl: Extraocular Muscles and Their Actions

questions.text:
Match the following triage tags with the example of the patient given.
Triage tag Patient
1. Black A. Tension pneumothorax
2. Red B. Degloving injury
3. Green C. Extensive third-degree burns
4. Yellow D. Fracture of the forearm
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

Triage tag Patient
1. Black C. Extensive third-degree burns
2. Red A. Tension pneumothorax
3. Green D. Fracture of the forearm
4. Yellow B. Degloving injury

Triage is used to classify the priority of treatment.

It is carried out at the site of the disaster to determine the priority for immediate medical attention, transportation, and admission to the hospital.

Triage includes rapid classification of the injured based on their injuries and the chances of survival with prompt medical intervention. It provides maximum benefit to the greatest number of injured in a disaster situation. Higher priority is given to victims whose prognosis would be good with simple medical care. Lower priority is given to moribund patients who would have questionable benefits even with medical attention.

The internationally accepted four-color coded system is used commonly. It includes:

  • Red - High priority attention or transfer; Critical, but likely to survive if treatment is given early
  • Yellow - Medium priority; Critical, likely to survive if treatment is given within hours
  • Green - Ambulatory patients; Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days
  • Black - Dead or moribund patients; Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: A patient presented with yawning, feeling of anxiety, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, increased sweating, and secretions from the eyes and nose were noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of opioid withdrawal. 

The features of opioid withdrawal are:

  • Feeling of anxiety
  • Yawning
  • Lacrimation, diaphoresis, rhinorrhea
  • Diffuse myalgias progressing to piloerection
  • Mydriasis
  • Nausea, profuse vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal cramping

Treatment of opioid withdrawal:

  • Symptoms can be rendered more tolerable by the administration of the central α2-agonist like clonidine
  • Antiemetics and antidiarrheal agents
  • Daily administration of a verified dose of methadone PO is recommended to inhibit withdrawal symptoms and reduce craving

questions.text: Which of the following proteins connects the lines marked as A and B (indicated by red arrows) in the following image?
questions.solution:
The above image is the electron microscope view of the muscle. Line A corresponds to the M line, and Line B corresponds to the Z line. The protein that connects the M line with the Z line is titin. 

Here is an image highlighting the various zones of a sarcomere.

The area between two Z-lines is called a sarcomere. 

Apart from proteins like actin, myosin, troponin, and tropomyosin, there are some additional structural proteins that are important for the function of the skeletal muscle:

  • Actinin - It binds actin to the Z lines.
  • Titin - It is the largest protein and connects the Z lines to the M lines.
  • Desmin - It connects Z lines to the plasma membrane.

Dystrophin connects actin filaments to the transmembrane protein β-dystroglycan in the sarcolemma by the smaller proteins syntrophins in the cytoplasm.

The troponin molecules are attached intermittently along the sides of the tropomyosin molecules. They have three loosely bound protein subunits:

  • Troponin I - It inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
  • Troponin T - It binds troponin components to tropomyosin.
  • Troponin C - It binds the calcium ions and initiates contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

Related Pearl: Sarcomere

questions.text: What level of structural organization of a protein is shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image represents a beta-sheet which is a secondary structure of proteins.

Proteins are arranged in the following four structures viz:

  • Primary
    • The sequence of amino acids in a protein is called a primary structure.
  • Secondary
    • The folding of short contiguous polypeptide sequences into geometrically ordered units.
    • Alpha helix and beta sheets are examples of secondary structure.
    • Hydrogen bonds play an important role in the maintenance of the secondary structure.
    • Of this, beta sheets are represented as broad arrows, with the carboxy-terminal of polypeptide chain at the tip of the arrow.
  •  Tertiary
    • This refers to the folding and final arrangement of domains in a polypeptide structure. In this, hydrophobic side chains are buried in the core whereas hydrophilic side chains are freely exposed.
    • Disulfide bonds, hydrophobic interactions, hydrogen bonds, and ionic interactions account for the stability of the structure.
  •  Quaternary
    • It is the arrangement of different polypeptide subunits in a protein.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of congestive heart failure is brought to casualty with complaints of sudden onset dyspnea. Bilateral fine basal crackles can be heard on auscultation. A bolus dose of injection furosemide was given.  Which of the following principles apply to the use of loop diuretics in this patient?
questions.solution:
Furosemide (which was given to the patient) acts on the principle of reduction of preload.

It comes under a class of drugs known as loop diuretics (high ceiling diuretics) and they are the diuretic of choice for reducing edema in heart failure. They act by inhibiting the Na+/K+/2Cl- symporter in the ascending limb of the loop of Henle.

This leads to a decrease in preload by increasing sodium and water excretion and improves ventricular function by reducing the circulatory volume. Intravenous furosemide also increases systemic venous capacitance.

The history of a patient who is known to have congestive heart failure being brought with complaints of sudden onset dyspnoea and bilateral fine basal crackles is suggestive of pulmonary edema. Heart failure is the inability of the heart to pump an adequate cardiac output for meeting physiological demands and can occur due to systolic/diastolic dysfunction. There is an elevation of filling pressure to compensate for the reduced cardiac output, but such an increase in stroke volume can produce congestive features similar to the scenario mentioned above. The main goal of drug therapy would be to relieve the congestive symptoms and restore cardiac function.

Other options:

Option B: In heart failure, low cardiac output causes activation of the neurohumoral regulation (renin-angiotensin-aldosterone-system and sympathetic nervous system) that leads to an increase in sodium and water reabsorption as well as elevation of blood pressure (causing an increase in afterload). Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists act by the principle of reducing neurohumoral modulation.

Option C: Hydralazine act on the principle of reducing afterload by dilating resistance vessels. Reduction of afterload is beneficial in heart failure as it allows the heart to pump out blood against a lower resistance. 

Option D: Positive inotropic agents such as cardiac glycosides (Na+/K+ATPase inhibition - digoxin) and cAMP-dependant drugs (epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dobutamine) act on the principle of increasing cardiac contractility. This is beneficial as it allows to produce enough force for adequate organ perfusion.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man has been diagnosed with advanced-stage testicular cancer with multiple metastatic sites. The oncologist informs him that his chances of survival are very poor. Which of the following is the right sequence of the stages that this patient will experience according to Elisabeth Kubler-Ross?
  1. Bargaining
  2. Acceptance
  3. Depression
  4. Anger
  5. Denial
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of the stages that this patient will experience according to Elisabeth Kubler-Ross is 5, 4, 1, 3, and 2.

A patient diagnosed with a terminal disease responds to impending death by the five stages proposed by Kubler-Ross which are in the order as follows :

  • Shock and Denial
  • Anger
  • Bargaining
  • Depression
  • Acceptance

Stage 1 is the stage of shock and denial. The individual initially reacts with shock when told that they are dying and may refuse to believe the diagnosis. A few may never pass this stage and may change doctors until they find one who supports their position.

Stage 2  is the stage of anger. The person becomes frustrated, irritable, and angry. At this stage, they commonly ask the question "Why me?". They may blame themselves or might displace their anger onto the hospital staff members and the doctor, whom they blame for the illness. Patients in the stage of anger are the ones difficult to treat.

Stage 3 is also known as the stage of bargaining. The patient may attempt to negotiate with physicians, friends, or even God in return for curing him or her. Treating such a patient involves reassurance that they will be looked after to the best of the doctor's abilities. 

Stage 4 is depression. In this stage, patients exhibit clinical signs of depression. These include withdrawal, psychomotor retardation, sleep disturbances, and hopelessness. These symptoms may be due to the effects of the illness on their lives or due to the anticipation of the eventual loss of life. This may require antidepressants or electroconvulsive therapy (ECT).

Stage 5 is the stage of acceptance. The patient eventually realizes that death is inevitable, and they accept the universality of the experience. The feelings of the patient can range from a neutral state to euphoria.

Related Pearl: The 5 stages of grief model by Kübler-Ross

  • Denial - Patients may become numb and dazed at the news of their own imminent death and refuse to accept the diagnosis. 
  • Anger - Patients may get angry towards God or themselves. 
  • Bargaining - Patients may start to bargain with God or friends and doctors for a cure to buy some more time.
  • Depression - Patients may go into depression.
  • Acceptance - Patients finally accept that their death is inevitable and make further preparations (eg., making a will, etc). 

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms that operate in various diseases

  • OCD - reaction formation, undoing
  • Phobia - displacement
  • Neurosis - repression
  • Grief - denial
  • Borderline personality - Splitting
  • Schizophrenia - projection
  • Enuresis - Regression

 

 

Related Pearl: Normal vs abnormal grief

questions.text: Which of the following techniques separates proteins on the basis of their stokes radii?
questions.solution:
Gel filtration chromatography, also known as size exclusion chromatography separates proteins on the basis of their stokes radii.

Stokes radius is a measure of the effective volume a protein occupies in a free solution. It accounts for both the mass and the shape of the protein. Proteins with large and small stokes radii are applied to the top of a gel filtration column. On entering the column, the small proteins enter pores in the stationary phase matrix (included proteins). During the mobile phase flowing down the column, the large molecules lag behind, which get excluded (excluded proteins). Proteins thus emerge from a gel filtration column in descending order of their stokes radii.

Ion exchange chromatography separates proteins in inverse order of the strength of their interactions with the stationary phase and is based on charge-charge interactions. Proteins with a net positive charge at a given pH will tightly adhere to negatively charged beads called cation exchangers. Proteins with a net negative charge will adhere to positively charged beads called anion exchangers. Nonadherent proteins flow through the matrix and are washed away. HbA1c (Glycated hemoglobin) is best measured using ion exchange chromatography.

Affinity chromatography is based on the high selectivity displayed by most proteins for their ligands. The high selectivity of affinity chromatography is caused by allowing the desired molecule to interact with the stationary phase and remain bound within the column in order to facilitate its separation from the undesired material, which will not interact and elute first.

Hydrophobic interaction Chromatography separates proteins based on their tendency to associate with a stationary phase matrix coated with hydrophobic groups. Proteins with exposed hydrophobic surfaces adhere to the matrix via hydrophobic bonds that are enhanced by employing a mobile phase of high ionic strength.

questions.text: A 23-year-old girl who is an alleged victim of rape is brought to the casualty. Samples are collected for the detection of semen. Which of the following tests is not useful in the detection of semen?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given tests, the Teichmann test is not used for semen detection. 

The Teichmann test or hemin crystal test is used to detect suspected bloodstains. It is performed by placing a small piece of suspected material on a glass slide. Then, 2-3 drops of glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride are added to the glass slide and covered with a coverslip. The slide is then heated.

If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of hemin or hematin chloride appear. When hydrogen peroxide is added, the hematin crystals produce bubbles of gas.

Other options:

Option B: P30 assay is a test to look for a glycoprotein produced by the prostate gland present in the semen (even of aspermic male), blood, and urine of a male. It may be found in the vagina up to 27 hours after intercourse. It is a reliable indicator of semen irrespective of acid phosphatase levels or the presence of sperm. 

Option C: Barberio test is used to detect seminal fluid and probably detect the presence of prostatic secretions. When a saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Option D: Acid phosphatase test detects the presence of high levels of acid phosphatase in seminal stains (low levels may be present in the vagina). Positive reactions are found till 36 hours, after which the levels fall and disappear within 72 hours.

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text:
A woman was drugged with ketamine which was slipped into her drink without her knowledge by a stranger, intending to harm her. Her friends noticed that she was drugged and other eyewitnesses in the bar helped in apprehending the perpetrator. The accused is punishable under which section of the BNS/IPC?

BNS- Bharatiya Nayaya Sanhita; IPC- Indian Penal Code
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a person poisoning another person with a stupefying drug is punishable under BNS Sec 123 (328 IPC).

BNS Sec 123 (328 IPC) states that whoever administers to or causes to be taken by any person, any poison or any stupefying, intoxicating or unwholesome drug, or any other thing with intent to cause hurt to such person, or with intent to commit or to facilitate the commission of an offense, shall be punished with imprisonment up to ten years and also fine.

Other options:

BNS Sec 118(1) (324 IPC) - Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous means. This section states that whoever volun­tarily causes hurt by means of any poison or any corrosive substance shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

BNS Sec 118(2) (326 IPC) - Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous means. Offenders who voluntarily cause grievous hurt by means of any poison or any corrosive substance shall be pun­ished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

BNS Sec 286 (284 IPC)- deals with 'Negligent conduct with respect to poisonous substance' - It states that whoever does, with any poisonous substance, any act in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life, or to be likely to cause hurt or injury to any person, or knowingly, shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.

Date rape:

Sexual intercourse with a woman after sedating her.

Common date rape drugs include:

  • Gamma-hydroxybutyrate (GHB)
  • Gamma-butyrolactone (GBL)
  • Rohypnol (flunitrazepam)
  • Ketamine

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the diagnostic criteria of adjustment disorder?

choices.text: The onset of symptoms occur after 3 months of the stressor
The symptoms do not persist if the stressor is removed
The symptoms of distress are clearly in excess of the normal
Both depressive and anxiety symptoms may be present

questions.solution:
Adjustment disorder is characterised by emotional or behavioural symptoms that develop within 3 months of exposure to an identifiable stressor and usually do not last more than 6 months after the stressor ends.

Common stressors leading to adjustment disorder are financial issues, illness & relationship problems.

Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice for adjustment disorder.
