questions.text: Which of the following indices is used to describe the percentage of nitrogen retained in the body with respect to nitrogen intake?
questions.solution:
Net protein utilization (NPU) is used to describe the percentage of nitrogen retained in the body with respect to nitrogen intake.

NPU is calculated as the percentage of protein retained by the body from the total protein intake. It is described as the product of the digestibility coefficient and the biological value multiplied by 100.

1 gram of protein is equivalent to 6.25 g of nitrogen. The NPU value of a dietary protein and the protein requirement of the individual are inversely related to each other. The NPU of the Indian diet is between 50 and 80.

Other options:

Option A: Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the ratio of milligrams of digestible dietary indispensable amino acid in 1 gram of the dietary protein to the milligrams of the same dietary indispensable amino acid in 1 gram of the reference protein. 

Option C: The biological value is calculated as the amount of nitrogen used for tissue formation divided by the nitrogen absorbed from food expressed in percentage. It is a reflection of essential amino acid supplied and a measure of protein quality. 

Option D: The amino acid score refers to the concentration of each essential amino acid in the test protein. It is calculated as the percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.

Related Pearl: Assessment of Protein

Protein quality: Assessed by comparing with reference protein i.e egg protein.

  • Amino acid score:
  • Net protein utilization

A) Amino acid score: It is a measure of the concentration of each essential amino acid in the protein to be tested, expressed as a percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.

 Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the best indicator of protein quality. It is defined as follows:

B) Net protein utilization: It is a product of digestibility coefficient and biological value divided by 100. 

Protein quantity: It is assessed by protein energy ratio.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented with pain, swelling, and redness in his right leg for the past 2 weeks. On examination, purulent discharge was observed exuding from the proximal end of the right tibia. There is no history of any chronic illness or trauma. What is the radiological investigation of choice for the early stage of this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with symptoms of pain, swelling, and redness of the lower limb which was later associated with the development of a discharging sinus is suffering from osteomyelitis. MRI is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of osteomyelitis. 

The characteristic early signs of osteomyelitis include bone marrow edema. This is seen as a low T1 signal in the bone marrow, along with a high signal on T2 MRI.

Abscesses are the walled pockets of infection serving as complications in both the early and late stages of osteomyelitis. They appear as well-demarcated low-signal collections on T1 and high signal collections similar to fluid on T2 images. Usual locations include the bone itself, adjacent soft tissue, and subperiosteal spaces.

X-rays are not useful in early acute osteomyelitis because of minimal findings. Exposure to ionizing radiation and limited soft-tissue contrast is the main disadvantage of CT that makes it less useful. 

Osteomyelitis is an acute or chronic inflammatory process involving the bone and its structures secondary to infection with pyogenic organisms, including bacteria, fungi, and mycobacteria. The bone becomes susceptible to disease due to large inoculation of microorganisms, from trauma, ischemia, or the presence of foreign bodies because bone sites to which microorganisms can bind are exposed.

The bone can get infected by a hematogenous route through bacteremia seeding of a bone infection from a distant source of infection, contiguous spread from surrounding tissue and joints, or direct inoculation of bone from trauma or surgery. The most common pathogen of acute and chronic hematogenous osteomyelitis in adults and children is Staphylococcus aureus. Other common pathogens are:

  • Coagulase-negative staphylococcus
  • Beta-hemolytic streptococcus
  • Enterococci
  • Aerobic gram-negative bacilli (including pseudomonas species, Enterobacter species, Escherichia coli)
  • Anaerobic gram-negative bacilli (such as peptostreptococcus, Clostridium species, Bacteroides)

Osteomyelitis can be classified as acute or chronic based on histopathological findings rather than the duration of illness. Infection occurring before the development of sequestra is referred to as acute osteomyelitis. It usually takes place within two weeks of disease onset. The infection is considered chronic following the development of necrotic bone and the formation of sequestra. Acute infections generally present with pain, swelling, and redness of the affected area associated with systemic illness while discharging sinuses may be present in chronic infections.

Surgical debridement of all diseased bone is required as antibiotics penetrate poorly into infected fluid collections such as abscesses and injured or necrotic bone. Thus, the removal of necrotic tissue and bone is usually indicated where feasible. The cornerstone of treatment for osteomyelitis is prolonged antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman with a history of major depressive disorder is brought to the emergency room. She is in a state of confusion and is found to have dilated pupils, a dry mouth, dry, warm skin, and hypotension. ECG shows prolonged QRS duration. Which of the following medications is responsible for these overdose symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of MDD (major depressive disorder) presents with a prolonged duration of QRS on ECG along with signs of anticholinergic toxicity like dry mouth, dry skin, mydriasis, and hypotension. The patient has most likely overdosed on imipramine, a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) used in MDD treatment.

Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant that antagonizes the serotonin and norepinephrine transporters responsible for the reuptake of these neurotransmitters in the neuron. They also block other receptors which is responsible for their adverse effects. When taken in sufficiently large quantities, TCAs exert their adverse effects by:

  • antimuscarinic actions- confusion, blurred vision, dry mouth, tachycardia, constipation, difficulty urinating
  • anti-alpha1 adrenergic actions- orthostatic hypotension
  • anti-histaminic actions- sedation

They also have effects similar to quinidine as reflected in the QRS prolongation of this patient's ECG. 

Other options:

Option A - Phenelzine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor that is used to treat MDD resistant to first and second-line antidepressants. It acts to prevent the degradation of serotonin and norepinephrine. The common adverse effect associated with this is a hypertensive crisis as seen with ingestion of tyramine-rich foods (cheeses). Inhibition of gastrointestinal MAO reduces the degradation of tyramine which then enters the systemic circulation and promotes catecholamine release. Other side effects are weight gain, sexual dysfunction, and suicidal thoughts.

Option B - Sertraline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor. The SSRIs generally do not have any anti-muscarinic adverse effects. They also don't block the alpha-adrenergic receptors. Adverse effects of SSRIs include gastrointestinal disturbances, sexual dysfunction, and serotonin syndrome. 

Option D - Aripiprazole is a second-generation antipsychotic drug. While antipsychotics are associated with antimuscarinic adverse effects, second-generation drugs have limited anticholinergic toxicity. Adverse effects include extrapyramidal symptoms and hypoprolactinemia.

questions.text: A patient presented with a swelling and chronic pus discharge from the mandibular region. The swelling developed a few days after undergoing a dental procedure 6 months ago. The discharge was foul-smelling with numerous yellow granules. Which of the following is false regarding the implicated pathogen?

choices.text: The causative organism is a gram-positive anaerobe
Sulfur granules are seen under microscopy
Treatment involves administration of penicillin for 2 weeks
Molar tooth colonies are seen when it is grown on brain-heart infusion agar

questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation, this is a case of cervicofacial actinomycosis caused by Actinomyces israeli. Infections caused by actinomyces should be treated by penicillin for about 6-12 months.

Actinomycosis is an indolent, slowly progressive suppurative and granulomatous infection that produces pyogenic lesions with interconnecting sinus tracts that contain sulfur granules. It is an anaerobic or microaerophilic bacteria. 

It presents as one of the following clinical types:

  • Cervicofacial actinomycosis- (most common site) fluctuant mass in the jaw area producing draining fistulas. (lumpy jaw)
  • Thoracic actinomycosis- pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. It usually occurs following aspiration or trauma leading to inoculation of the infective material.
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- following ruptured appendix or ulcer. It may involve multiple organs.
  • Pelvic actinomycosis- due to the colonization of intrauterine contraceptive devices.
  • Actinomycosis can spread to bones and surrounding tissue and produce multiple discharging sinuses.

Diagnosis is by Gram staining of sulfur granules that shows a dense network of thin gram-positive filaments, surrounded by club-shaped structures. (sunray appearance). Culture shows the "molar tooth" appearance of the colonies. On solid media, A. israeli produces spidery colonies. 

Treatment:

Penicillin G is the drug of choice and requires prolonged administration where the duration of therapy is between 6-12 months. The other drugs that can be used include amoxicillin, erythromycin, tetracycline, doxycycline, clindamycin, and minocycline. Surgical excision and drainage may be required.

Other options:

  • Molar tooth colonies are seen on brain-heart infusion agar.
  • Sulfur granules (unstained gross yellow color) are seen under microscopy.

Histological image showing Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon by actinomyces (eosinophilic rim at the periphery of the colony consists of immunoglobulin).

"Molar tooth" colonies shown on brain-heart infusion agar

questions.text:
The flow-volume curve after the spirometry of a patient is given below. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is:

The dotted curve indicates the normal pattern.
questions.solution:
The given image shows an obstructive pattern on the flow-volume curve. So the most likely diagnosis of this patient is bronchial asthma.

The flow-volume curve above shows a concave upward pattern in the expiratory limb. This is also called a scooped-out or coved pattern and is observed in conditions responsible for airflow obstruction like asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, etc. 

Other options: 

Option A: Myasthenia gravis shows a restrictive pattern on the flow-volume curve. It is characterized by decreased total lung capacity and vital capacity. Hence, the loop shrinks or narrows and shifts towards the right.

Option B: Tracheal stenosis shows a fixed upper airway obstruction pattern on the flow-volume curve. In this condition, there is obstruction and limitation of airflow during both inspiration and expiration. This leads to the flattening of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs of the flow-volume loop. 

Option C: Vocal cord paralysis shows a variable upper airway obstruction pattern on the flow-volume curve. It is characterized by flattening in the inspiratory limb of the loop.

questions.text: A patient with long-standing corticosteroid use was admitted for rhinocerebral mucormycosis. Which of the following is seen on microscopic examination?

choices.text: Broad hyphae with uneven thickness and irregular branching
Spherical budding yeast surrounded by a thick capsule

questions.solution:
Under the microscope, mucormycosis is seen as broad hyphae with uneven thickness and irregular branching.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic fungus that can be found in patients with acidosis, such as diabetes mellitus, leukemias, lymphomas, long-term corticosteroid use, severe burns, and immunodeficiencies. The most common agent is Rhizopus oryzae. The common clinical form is rhinocerebral mucormycosis, in which the blood vessels in the nasal cavity, the eyes, and the brain invade, causing thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. Treatment is by surgical debridement and amphotericin B administration.

Other options:

Option B: Long conidiophores with terminal vesicles: Aspergillus

Option C: Spherical budding yeast surrounded by a thick capsule: Cryptococcus neoformans

Option D: Oval, budding yeast cells: Candida

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A patient with chronic pain was prescribed a drug that inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine. Identify the prescribed drug.
questions.solution:
Tramadol is a synthetic codeine analog. Mechanism of action is a combination of effects as mentioned below-

  • Weak agonist action on the mu-opioid receptor
  • Inhibition of serotonin reuptake transporter (moderate action) and norepinephrine reuptake transporter (weak action). 

It is used to induce analgesia for moderate pain and can be used as an adjunct to opioid therapy in chronic pain conditions. 

Other options: They do not affect serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake

Option A: Hydromorphone is a phenanthrene drug with strong mu-opioid agonist action with a variable affinity for delta and kappa receptors. It is similar to morphine.  

Option C: Buprenorphine is also a phenanthrene derivative that has mixed opioid agonist-antagonist activity. It is a partial mu-agonist and has antagonist activity at delta and kappa receptors. While it can serve as an analgesic, it antagonizes the action of strong mu-agonists such as morphine. It is used to treat moderate pain and reduced cravings in patients recovering from alcoholism.

Option D: Hydrocodone is a phenanthrene drug with mild-moderate mu-opioid agonist action. It is less efficacious than morphine.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl was brought by her mother, who is concerned that her daughter has not achieved menarche so far. The history is otherwise unremarkable. You find that her breast development and other secondary sexual characteristics are normal. How will you proceed with this case?

choices.text: Delay investigations until 16 years of age

questions.solution:
This 14-year-old girl has amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characteristics. Hence, investigations may be delayed until the age of 16 years, and the patient can be reassured.

Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menstruation by 14 years without the development of secondary sexual characteristics or by 16 years regardless of the presence of secondary sexual characteristics.

Investigations may be delayed in girls of 14 years in the presence of secondary sexual characteristics since delayed puberty is a possibility in such cases. However, further investigations must be done if the patient presents with any other features suggestive of a specific cause (like short stature in Turner's syndrome) or if there is the absence of secondary sexual characteristics at 14 years, or if her age is 16 years or more.

Investigation algorithm for amenorrhea:

Causes of primary amenorrhea:

  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
    • Hypothalamic and pituitary dysfunction 
    • Kallmann's syndrome
    • CNS tumors - craniopharyngioma
    • Delayed puberty
  • Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism
    • Primary ovarian failure
    • Resistant ovarian failure
    • 17-alpha-hydroxylase deficiency
  • Chromosomal abnormalities
    • Turner's syndrome (45 X)
    • Pure gonadal dysgenesis (46 XX or 46 XY)
    • Androgen insensitivity syndrome (testicular feminization syndrome) (46 XY)
  • Developmental defect of the genital tract
    • Imperforate hymen
    • Transverse vaginal septum
    • Vaginal atresia/cervical atresia
    • Absent uterus in Mullerian agenesis (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome)
  • Others:
    • Uterine synechiae (congenital)
    • Adrenogenital syndrome
    • Cretinism
    • Juvenile diabetes
    • Malnutrition
    • Anemia
    • Weight loss
    • Tuberculosis

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male patient presented with a painless, hard testicular lump with a dragging sensation. The blood investigations showed raised AFP levels. Which of the following is least likely to be included in further management of this case?

AFP- Alpha Fetoprotein

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
The given clinical features of painless testicular swelling with raised AFP levels point towards the diagnosis of non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) of the testis. Orchidectomy via inguinal approach is done in this case rather than a scrotal approach due to fear of seeding the tumor in the scrotal skin. Hence, it is least likely to be the management of this case.

Management of testicular tumors:

  1. Ultrasound of the testis should be done in all suspected cases of testicular tumor.
  2. Tumor markers (AFP, hCG, LDH) are measured for the staging of cancer.
  3. CT - chest, abdomen, and pelvis is done to detect metastasis.
  4. Orchidectomy via an inguinal incision (high inguinal orchidectomy) is the best line of treatment in case of suspected testicular tumor.
  5. Further management is based on staging. The older staging is preferred over the TNM staging for treatment and is given below:
    • Stage I: Tumour is confined to testis and epididymis
    • Stage II: Nodal tissue is present but is confined to nodes below the diaphragm
    • Stage III: Nodal involvement above the diaphragm
    • Stage IV: Non-lymphatic metastatic spread (mostly in lungs)
  6. Stage I tumors:
    • Combination chemotherapy with bleomycin, etoposide, and cis-platinum (BEP chemotherapy) is given for NSGCTs, as they are radio-resistant.
    • Chemotherapy with cisplatinum and radiotherapy to para-aortic lymph nodes can be given in seminomas as they are radiosensitive.
  7. Stage II-IV tumors (seminomas and NSGCTs) are treated with BEP chemotherapy and retroperitoneal lymph node dissection if needed.

Note:

In case of suspected testicular tumors,

  • No scrotal approach.
  • No FNAC.
  • No incisional biopsy.

questions.text: An orthopedic resident prescribes pain relievers for a patient diagnosed with Kohler's disease. Which of the following bones is usually affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
Osteochondritis of the navicular bone is known as Kohler's disease.

Osteochondrosis and osteochondritis are conditions in which a small segment of articular bone or cartilage is demarcated or separated and necrosed. The affected part shows features of ischemic necrosis. This is widely seen in adolescents and young adults, with trauma and repetitive stress being the common causes. An example of this disorder is osteochondritis dissecans.

Commonly affected sites are slightly bulbous areas with convex articular surfaces: 

  • Inner (medial) surface of the medial femoral condyle in the knee
  • Anteromedial corner of the talus in the ankle
  • Superomedial part of the femoral head
  • Humeral capitulum
  • Head of the second metatarsal bone

Clinically, they present with intermittent pain over the mid-foot, which may be accompanied by swelling and a small effusion in the joint. It typically resolves over the years, as the child grows up.

X-ray imaging, MRI, and radionuclide scanning with 99mTc-HDP are the imaging modalities used for diagnosis.

Treatment includes symptomatic treatment of pain. Special supportive shoes may also be considered.

Other options:

Option A: Osteochondritis of the lunate is known as Kienbock's disease.

Option B: Osteochondritis of the capitulum is known as Panner's disease.

Option D: Osteochondritis of the calcaneum is known as Sever's disease.

questions.text: The image below shows finding seen on eliciting plantar reflex in a patient in the neurology ward. All of the following signs may be seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The image shows extensor plantar response (positive Babinski sign), suggestive of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Fasciculations are seen in lower motor neuron lesions (not UMN).
 
UMNs refer to corticospinal tract neurons and brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons. Injury to UMNs lead to:
  • Spasticity
  • Hypertonia 
  • Hyperreflexia
  • Abnormal plantar extensor reflex (positive Babinski sign).
Babinski sign refers to dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes when the lateral aspect of the sole of the foot is scratched. It is a sign of an upper motor neuron lesion. In normal adults, the response is plantar flexion of all the toes.
 

The image below shows a positive Babinski sign in an adult, which is abnormal and indicative of a UMN lesion. 

In infants whose corticospinal tracts are still underdeveloped, dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes is a normal response to scratching of the sole of the foot.

The image below shows an extensor response in an infant, which is normal.

questions.text:
An infant is brought with history of multiple episodes of seizures and fasting hypoglycemia. On examination, there is growth retardation, hepatomegaly, and hypotonia. Lipid profile, AST, and ALT are deranged. Liver biopsy shows hepatocytes with large glycogen stores. Biochemical analysis reveals glycogen with short outer chains. Which enzyme deficiency, as shown in the image, causes this condition?

AST: Aspartate aminotransferase

ALT: Alanine aminotransferase
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Cori's disease - Type III glycogen storage disease (GSD), due to the deficiency of glycogen debranching enzyme. This disease is also called Forbes disease or limit dextrinosis.

A deficiency of glycogen debranching enzyme results in the accumulation of glycogen with short outer chains in the liver and muscles called limit dextrans. On muscle biopsy, this is seen as vacuolation of muscle fibers.

 Other options:

Option B: Andersen disease (Glycogen storage disease type IV) is due to the deficiency of glycogen branching enzyme (enzyme 3 in the image). It presents with failure to thrive, hepatomegaly due to the accumulation of polysaccharides with  a few branching points, and the child usually dies by the age of 5 years

Option C: McArdle syndrome (Type V GSD) is due to the deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase (the enzyme 4 in the image). It presents with poor exercise tolerance, low lactate levels following exercise, and accumulation of glycogen in muscles.

Option D:  Pompe disease (glycogen storage disease type II) is due to the deficiency of the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase (enzyme 7 in the image). The affected child will have cardiomegaly, hypotonia, and hepatomegaly.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with compensated cirrhosis is being posted for a liver transplantation. As an anesthetist on duty, which of the following induction agents will you use?
questions.solution:
Sevoflurane and isoflurane are commonly used for induction in patients with liver disease.

Hepatic arterial blood flow is reduced in cirrhosis. Sevoflurane and isoflurane are known to maintain hepatic blood flow and improve oxygen delivery to the liver.

Sevoflurane due to its nonpungency and rapid onset makes it an excellent choice for smooth and rapid inhalation inductions in pediatric and adult patients.

Compound A is the nephrotoxic end product formed by the interaction of sevoflurane with CO2-absorbent soda lime. Accumulation of this product occurs on long-duration anesthesia, high sevoflurane concentrations, and dry barium hydroxide absorbent.

Other options-

Option (A): Methoxyflurane is a hepatotoxic and highly nephrotoxic drug. Its use gradually declined after the 1970s. 

Option (B): Thiopentone, also known as thiopental, is a barbiturate that is excreted primarily via the liver. Hence, it would lead to toxicity is used in patients with liver disease.

Option (D): Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic agent that accumulates in the liver and undergoes rapid metabolism. It is also known to cause hepatotoxicity which presents as an elevation in liver enzymes. These two reasons make ketamine unsuitable for use in patients with liver disease.

• Anti D-gammaglobulin is administered intramuscularly to the mother 300 mcg following delivery.

questions.text: What is the pathological mechanism responsible for the RBC shape shown in this peripheral smear?

choices.text: Mutations in genes encoding for ankyrin, spectrin, and band proteins
Acquired mutation in the PIGA gene
Point mutation in the beta-globin gene

questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows bite cells or degmacytes, characteristically associated with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD deficiency), an X-linked recessive condition.

Reduced glutathione is required to protect the cells against oxidant injury. This glutathione is kept in a reduced state by NADPH. Glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is required to generate NADPH while oxidizing glucose-6-phosphate. G6PD deficiency results in reduced levels of NADPH which subsequently reduces the level of reduced glutathione. Therefore, in conditions like infections, which increase the production of oxygen free radicals, the red blood cells are damaged. 

Other triggers that lead to oxidative stress are drugs like sulphonamides, antimalarials, and fava beans.

Increased oxidative damage to RBCs leads to the formation of denatured precipitates known as Heinz bodies. These bodies can damage the RBC membrane leading to intravascular hemolysis. Additionally, when such RBCs pass through the splenic cords, macrophages pluck out these precipitates, giving them the characteristic appearance of bite cells. 

Other features of the peripheral smear include anisocytes, polychromatic cells, and poikilocytes with unevenly distributed hemoglobin (hemighosts). 

Other options:

Option A: Mutations in the genes coding for ankyrin, spectrin, and band proteins are responsible for hereditary spherocytosis (HS). It is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by poor interaction between the mutated RBC membrane proteins. This leads to the loss of membrane fragments relative to the cytoplasm, thereby causing the RBC to assume the least possible diameter for a given volume. Peripheral smear shows characteristic spherocytes that appear dark, with no central pallor. Howell- Jolly bodies can also be seen.

A slide showing spherocytes in peripheral smear:

 

Option B: Acquired mutation of PIGA gene is responsible for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). This condition causes complement-mediated destruction of RBCs due to the absence/ impaired production of membrane-associated complement regulatory proteins CD59 and CD55. PNH is characterized by a triad of hemolysis, pancytopenia, and venous thrombosis. The peripheral smear reveals RBCs that are usually normo-macrocytic but may become microcytic due to chronic iron loss through hemoglobinuria. 

Option C: Point mutation in the beta-globin gene is responsible for sickle cell anemia. This autosomal recessive disorder is characterized by the polymerization of the abnormal HbS hemoglobin during conditions of low oxygen tension (acidosis, hypoxia) which leads to sickling of the red blood cell, hemolysis, and microvascular obstruction (may lead to vaso-occlusive crises and autosplenectomy). Peripheral smear findings reveal sickled RBCs, reticulocytosis, and Howell-Jolly bodies (small nuclear remnants in RBCs that are usually removed by a functional spleen). 

A slide showing sickled RBCs in a peripheral smear:

questions.text: Why is salbutamol preferred over adrenaline in the treatment of an asthmatic patient?
questions.solution:
Salbutamol is preferred over adrenaline in an asthmatic patient due to β2 selectivity.

This β2 selectivity is relative and lost at higher concentrations. Around 40% of the beta receptors are of β2 type and their activation won't cause cardiac stimulation.

Major adverse effects of non-selective β-agonists are attributed to the stimulation of β1 receptors in the heart which result in tachyarrhythmias. Selective β2 receptor agonists are introduced to overcome this major drawback.

questions.text: A young girl is being evaluated for truncal asymmetry.  An X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following braces is not used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The X-ray showing lateral curvature of the lower thoracic vertebrae is suggestive of scoliosis. The SOMI (Sternal Occipital Mandibular Immobilizer) brace is used in cases of cervical spine injury or for cervical pain due to a chronic condition, such as rheumatoid arthritis. 

Scoliosis is defined as the lateral curvature of the spine in the coronal plane when the patient is upright. A Cobbs angle of >10% is diagnostic of scoliosis.

Cobbs method consists of three steps:

  • Locating the superior-end vertebra of the curve
  • Locating the inferior-end vertebra of the curve
  • Drawing perpendicular lines from the superior surface of the superior-end vertebra and from the inferior surface of the inferior-end vertebra and making them intersect

The angle of deviation of these perpendiculars is the angle of the spinal curve known as Cobb's angle.

Nash and Moe's method and Perdriolle and Vidal method are tools for assessing the vertebral rotation in scoliosis. 

Management of scoliosis includes:

Observation- it is the primary treatment done in scoliosis cases especially when the curve is less than 20 degrees. Radiographic documentation is done for the size and progression of the curves.

Orthotic treatment- is used in skeletally immature patients for curves more than 25 degrees. The following are commonly used for orthotic treatment in scoliosis:

  • Boston brace- it is a type of thoracic-lumbar-sacral-orthosis (TLSO brace) and is commonly prescribed for scoliosis.
  • Milwaukee brace- it is the originally designed cervico-thoracic-lumbar-sacral orthosis (CTLSO). It is bulkier and older and is not commonly used nowadays.
  • Charleston brace- it is prescribed for nighttime use and is only intended to be used while lying down.

Surgical correction- indications for surgery in scoliosis are:

  • Curves > 50 degrees in skeletally mature patients
  • Curves > 10 degrees with marked rotation
  • Double major curves > 30 degrees

The most common surgical intervention done in idiopathic scoliosis is segmental instrumentation with a multi-back system.

The SOMI (Sternal Occipital Mandibular Immobilizer) brace is a rigid cervical brace that positions the neck in alignment with the spine. It is used in cases of cervical spine injury or for cervical pain due to a chronic condition, such as rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is used as an initial screening test in a suspected case of pulmonary arterial hypertension?
questions.solution:
An echocardiogram with bubble study is the most important initial screening test to diagnose pulmonary arterial hypertension.

Pulmonary hypertension (PH/PAH) is broadly classified into:

  • Pre-capillary PH or PAH
    • Involves the pulmonary arterial system
    • mPAP (Mean pulmonary arterial pressure) > 25mmHg (or >20 mmHg at rest)
    • PCWP (Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure) ≤ 15 mmHg
    • PVR (Pulmonary vascular resistance) ≥ 3 Wood units
  • Post-capillary PH
    • Involves the pulmonary venous system
    • mPAP > 25mmHg (or >20 mmHg at rest)
    • PCWP ≥ 15 mmHg 

Signs and symptoms of PAH:

  • Dyspnoea and/or fatigue
  • Elevated JVP
  • Loud P2
  • Right-sided S3 or S4
  • Murmurs in PAH-
    • Tricuspid regurgitation- Holosystolic murmur
    • Pulmonary regurgitation- End diastolic murmur in severe PAH
  • Right heart failure in severe PAH - Peripheral edema, ascites, hepatomegaly

Investigations in PAH:

  • Transthoracic echocardiogram with bubble study- initial screening test
    • hypertrophied and dilated right ventricle
    • elevated pulmonary artery systolic pressure
  • Chest X-ray
    • Enlargement of central pulmonary arteries
    • Rapid tapering of vessels known as 'vascular pruning'
    • Right ventricular enlargement.
  • Electrocardiogram (ECG)
    • Features of RV strain such as right axis deviation and right ventricular hypertrophy.
  • Pulmonary function tests
    • Reduction in DLCO
    • Normal FEV1 and FVC if no underlying lung disease.
  • Right heart catheterisation - Gold standard / Definitive diagnosis 
    • Mean pulmonary arterial pressure, mPAP > 25mmHg (or >20 mmHg at rest)
    • PVR ≥ 3 Wood units
    • PCWP ≤ 15 mmHg. 
  • Cardiopulmonary exercise test
    • Used if the patient has a reasonable functional capacity
    • Differentiates between cardiac and pulmonary causes of dyspnea.
  • High resolution computed tomography (HRCT) Chest
    • Enlarged pulmonary arteries
    • Peripheral pruning of small vessels
    • Enlarged right atrium and ventricle
    • Centrilobular ground-glass infiltrates
    • Thickened septal lines
  • CT angiograms, V/Q scanning- done in case of chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension

questions.text: In a nuclear family cycle, the phase from the 1st child leaving the parental house until the last child leaving the house of parents is termed as ________
questions.solution:
The phase of a nuclear family cycle starting from the first child leaving the house and ending with the last child leaving the house of parents is called Contraction.

questions.text: The body of a missing person was found tied up in a boat. During the autopsy, you notice the presence of the following organism in his brain tissue. Which of the following is not a possible cause for this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a diatom. Postmortem drowning does not show diatoms in the brain tissue.

Diatoms are microscopic unicellular or colonial algae present in water. As the diatoms are found in both seawater and freshwater, their presence cannot differentiate between freshwater and seawater drowning.

The presence of diatoms in the brain tissue is suggestive of antemortem drowning, as only a living person can transport diatoms from the lungs to the viscera via circulation.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is called the ovulation method?
questions.solution:
Billings method or cervical mucus method is called the ovulation method.

It is based on the observation of changes in the cervical mucus. At ovulation, the mucus is watery clear, smooth, and slippery and profuse After ovulation, it becomes thicker and scarce. To use this method, a woman must have high motivation and should know to notice the changes in the cervical mucus.

Other options :

Option B - The symptothermic method employs the combined use of the temperature, cervical mucus and calendar techniques for identifying the fertile period. The use of multiple methods makes it more reliable than using any one method and is hence more effective.

Option C - In Coitus interruptus, no costs or appliances are required and is practised by the withdrawal of the penis right before ejaculation.This prevents the deposition of semen in the vagina. This method of contraception has a high rate of failure (upto 25%) where the major drawbacks are that precoital secretions may contain sperm and that even a drop of semen might be adequate to cause conception. Poorly timed withdrawal might also lead to pregnancy.

Option D - Also known as the "calendar method", the rhythm method is based on calculating the fertile period of the female. The calculations are as follows :

  • First day of fertile peroid : Shortest cycle - 18 days
  • Last day of fertile period : Longest cycle - 10 days

Intercourse is then avoided during this fertile period.

Drawbacks :

  • Irregular menstrual cycles
  • Used only in educated couples who are motivated and cooperative.
  • Abstinence for half a month leading to "programmed sex"
  • Cannot be used in the postnatal period
  • High rate of failure (9 per 100 woman-years)

questions.text: A 58-year-old chronic alcoholic woman presented to the dermatology outpatient department with the following lesion over the extensor aspect of the arm. All the following are the histopathological features seen in this condition, except _______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical image is indicative of psoriasis. All the following histopathological features are seen in this condition except suprapapillary thickening, instead suprapapillary thinning is seen.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin with systemic manifestations. The sustained inflammation leads to uncontrolled proliferation of the epidermal keratinocytes.

In a normal individual, it takes approximately 30 days for basal epidermal keratinocytes to proliferate, differentiate, and ascend through the layers of the epidermis. However, this process takes only 4-5 days in a patient with psoriasis. 

It can be caused due to drugs (lithium, antimalarials, interferon-α), seasons (winter), infections (streptococcal), alcohol abuse, and smoking. 

Histopathological features of psoriasis include:

  • Acanthosis- Irregular epidermal thickening 
  • Hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis
  • Suprapapillary thinning
  • Clubbing or elongation of rete ridges at the base
  • Kogoj spongiform pustules- collection of neutrophils in the malpighian layer (stratum basale and stratum spinosum referred together)
  • Munro microabscesses- collection of neutrophils in stratum corneum
  • Dilated, tortuous blood vessels in the dermis

Psoriasis patient presents with skin involved in the form of red/ salmon pink, scaly, and well-demarcated lesions. A peripheral clearing (ring of Woronoff) may be present. It is usually seen on the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

The appearance of a smooth, glossy red membrane with small bleeding points on the removal of the scales by gentle scraping is known as Auspitz sign, which is characteristic. It is associated with Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon.

Topical application of steroids, retinoids, vitamin D, and emollients is the mainstay of management

The following is an image of psoriasis. Its epidermis shows markedly elongated rete ridges, with bulbous thickening. Also, it shows thin suprapapillary epidermal plates, edema, and dilated vessels in the dermal papillae.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and breathlessness. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His ECG is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical feature and the ECG are pointing towards the diagnosis of multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT).

Identifying features in ECG:

  • Heart rate >100 bpm
  • Irregular rhythm
  • Discrete P waves with >3 different morphologies (black arrows)
  • Variable PR interval
  • Narrow QRS complex

MAT is characterised by at least three distinct P-wave morphologies with rates typically between 100 and 150 beats/min.

It is the most common arrhythmia seen in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It is also seen in hypoxia and pulmonary hypertension.

Other options:

Option A: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia has a rate of 150-200 bpm. It also has a regular rhythm. P wave may be buried in the QRS complex. PR interval may not be possible to measure. Narrow QRS complex. It can occur in a normal heart. The drug of choice for PSVT is adenosine.

Option B: Atrial fibrillation has an irregularly irregular rhythm. The rate is >300 bpm. The 'P' wave is absent, these irregular waves are known as fibrillation waves, which are characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

Option C: Atrial flutter has a regular rhythm. The rate is 250-300 bpm. Normal P waves are replaced by saw-tooth-shaped waves known as flutter waves.

questions.text: Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to the plasma by binding to _____
questions.solution:
Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocytes into the plasma by binding to ferroportin, which is an iron efflux channel in the enterocyte.

Iron metabolism is regulated by hepcidin, a protein and acute phase reactant produced by the liver. It binds to ferroportin and degrades it. This inhibits the transfer of iron from the enterocyte to the plasma via ferroportin. As a result, iron becomes trapped within the duodenal cells (enterocytes) in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost in feces when these cells are shed off.

Transcription of hepcidin is increased by the following factors:

  • Increased levels of iron
  • Inflammatory cytokines

Transcription of hepcidin is decreased by the following factors:

  • Iron deficiency
  • Hypoxia
  • Ineffective erythropoiesis

Hepcidin is encoded by the HAMP gene and its mutations are associated with hereditary hemochromatosis.

2. Keratan sulfate B. Synovial fluid
3. Heparan sulfate C. Mast cell
4. Heparin D. Kidney
questions.solution:
The option showing 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C is correctly matched.

GAGs Location
1. Hyaluronic acid B. Synovial fluid
2. Keratan sulfate A. Cornea
3. Heparan sulfate D. Kidney

Glycosaminoglycans or mucopolysaccharides are complex carbohydrates made up of amino sugars and uronic acids. They may be attached to a protein molecule to form a proteoglycan. Proteoglycans are components of the ground substance of connective tissue. Proteoglycans have a bottle brush appearance.

Hyaluronic acid is the GAG present in synovial fluid. It is also found in skin, bone, cartilage, vitreous humor, and embryonic tissues. It contains repeating units of N Acetyl Glucosamine and Glucuronic acid. It plays a role in morphogenesis and wound repair. The high concentrations of hyaluronic acid along with chondroitin sulfates in cartilage contribute to its compressibility.

Keratan sulfate I and II are the GAGs in the cornea(KSI), cartilage, and loose connective tissue. It is the only GAG that does not contain any uronic acid. The repeating units are galactose and N-acetyl glucosamine in beta linkage.

Heparan Sulfate is found on many extracellular cell surfaces and contains GlcN with fewer N-sulfates than heparin. The predominant uronic acid is d-glucuronic acid Heparan sulfates are associated with the plasma membrane of cells where they act as receptors and may participate in the mediation of cell growth and cell-cell communication. It is also found in the basement membrane of the kidney along with type IV collagen and laminin, where it determines the charge selectiveness of glomerular filtration

Heparin is found in the granules of mast cells and also in the liver, lung, and skin and is an important anticoagulant. It is released into the blood from capillary walls by the action of lipoprotein lipase and it binds with factors IX and XI, but its most important interaction is with plasma antithrombin

questions.text: A nurse is found to be seropositive for both HBsAg and HBeAg. These findings denote which of the following?

choices.text: Concurrent hepatitis B and hepatitis E infection

questions.solution:
Seropositivity for both HBsAg and HBeAg indicates an acute hepatitis B infection.

Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is an objective marker of active HBV infection and is present for about 3-4 weeks. It may be present in a chronic carrier state (when it persists for longer than 6 months). Antibody to HBsAg (Anti-HBs) is detected 3-6 months after recovery from the initial infection or vaccination and confers immunity.

Hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) is a marker of active viral replication in the liver. The persistence of HBeAg is an indicator of chronic hepatitis B with active viral replication. Anti-HBeAg antibodies are produced against these antigens.

In high infectivity chronic HBV, both HBsAg and HBeAg will be present but in low infectivity chronic HBV only HBsAg will be present.

questions.text:
Which of the following lipoproteins have the highest cholesterol:triglyceride ratio?

VLDL- Very low-density lipoprotein

LDL- Low-density lipoprotein 

HDL- High-density lipoprotein 

IDL- Intermediate-density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
As cholesterol is the predominant lipid in LDL and HDL, they have a higher cholesterol: triglyceride ratio.

VLDL also has a significant amount of cholesterol but it predominantly comprises triglycerides (lower cholesterol: triglyceride ratio). Therefore LDL and HDL are considered the major carriers of cholesterol.

IDLs are formed by the removal of triglycerides from VLDL by muscle and adipose tissue and are hence enriched in cholesterol. LDLs are derived from VLDL and IDL particles and contain more cholesterol than IDLs.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman presented with complaints of fatigue. On imaging, she was found to have a scleroatrophic gall bladder with impacted stones in it. A large stone was also present in the common bile duct and the biliary tree is dilated. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy

questions.solution:
An 80-year-old woman with imaging showing a scleroatrophic gall bladder with impacted stones and a stone in the bile duct is suggestive of chronic cholelithiasis with choledocholithiasis. ERCP is the next line of management for this patient. 

Choledocholithiasis is the presence of stone in the common bile duct (CBD) or biliary tree. It can be primary or secondary:  

  • Primary stones are formed in the CBD or biliary tree itself and are rare.
  • Secondary stones are passed from the gallbladder to the CBD. They are easier to manage than primary stones.

It can be an asymptomatic and incidental finding or present with features such as jaundice (most common), abdominal pain, and fatigue. When there is inflammation of the biliary tree (cholangitis), the patient will have intermittent pain, fever, and jaundice (Charcot's triad). 

Investigations: 

  • Liver function tests will show elevated direct bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels. 
  • Abdominal ultrasound is the first imaging modality done and may show gallstones and dilated bile duct (>8 mm). 
  • CT is sensitive for CBD stones. It shows stones, location, ductal stricture or block, ductal dilatation, and intrahepatic biliary changes.
  • MRCP is highly sensitive and specific for CBD stones, but it is only diagnostic and intervention cannot be performed.

Management: 

  • ERCP with sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice, followed by the removal of stones using a dormia basket or placement of a stent.
  • Despite ERCP being an invasive procedure, it has the advantage of being both a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure and is more suited for elderly patients who cannot tolerate anesthesia and surgery.

Other options: 

Option A: Cholecystectomy is not recommended for elderly patients, owing to the risk of old age and associated anesthetic and surgical complications.

Option C: Wait and watch approach can be done for asymptomatic patients, and patients with smaller stones.

Option D: CT is sensitive for CBD stones, but it is only diagnostic and intervention cannot be performed.

 

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

  • Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction
  • CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS
  • MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts
  • ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract
    • Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done
  • PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract
    • Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed
  • EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text: As a public health officer, you are evaluating the implementation of the expanded program on immunization (EPI) covering 9 diseases. You assess the proportion of infants in the community who are fully immunized under this program. This is an example of:
questions.solution:
The proportion of fully immunized infants against the 9 Expanded Program on Immunization (EPI) diseases is an example of utilization rates.

Utilization of services is expressed as the proportion of people in need of a service who actually receive it in a given period. It gives an indication of the care needed and the health status of a population. The utilization rates are affected by the availability and accessibility of health services and public health awareness. 

The following are examples of utilization rates:

  • The proportion of infants immunized against 9 diseases in the expanded program on immunization (EPI)
  • The proportion of pregnant women receiving antenatal care and supervised delivery 
  • Percentage of population using family planning methods
  • Bed occupancy rate (average daily in-patient census) at a healthcare facility 
  • Average length of stay at a hospital
  • Bed turnover ratio (discharges/average beds) at a hospital

Other options:

Option A: Health care delivery indicators reflect the provision of health care and the equity of distribution of health resources in different parts of the country. Examples: Doctor- population ratio, Doctor-nurse ratio

Option B: Indicators of quality of life are difficult to define or measure. The physical quality of life index is an example that consolidates three indicators, i.e., infant mortality, life expectancy at age one, and literacy. 

Option D: Basic needs indicators are indicators involving "basic needs performance," i.e; calorie consumption, access to water, life expectancy, deaths due to disease, illiteracy, etc

questions.text: An elderly lady who is on bisphosphonate therapy for 4 years comes with complaints of hip pain. What is the next investigation to be done in this patient?
questions.solution:
The next investigation to be done in a patient with complaints of hip pain following prolonged bisphosphonate therapy is plain radiograph to rule out atypical femur fracture. 

Prolonged use of bisphosphonates is associated with two potential side effects:

  • Osteonecrosis of the jaw usually following a dental procedure
  • Atypical femur fracture - occurs in the subtrochanteric femoral region or along the shaft distal to the lesser trochanter

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following renal injuries from least severe to most severe -
  1. Laceration of the pelvic ureteric junction 
  2. Subcapsular, non-expanding hematoma 
  3. Laceration up to renal medulla
  4. Injury confined to Gerota’s fascia
  5. Avulsion of renal hilum
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of renal injuries from least to most severe is 2-4-3-1-5.

  • Subcapsul, non-expanding hematoma (Least severe)
  • Injury confined to Gerota’s fascia
  • Laceration up to renal medulla
  • Laceration of the pelvic ureteric junction
  • Avulsion of the renal hilum (Most severe)

Renal injuries are mostly seen as a result of blunt trauma. Kidneys are the second most common visceral organ to be injured due to blunt trauma after the spleen. 

The examination includes findings related to the location of impact, flank ecchymosis, and gross or microscopic hematuria. Close attention to the entry and exit points in penetrating injuries is also important to estimate the trajectory of the missile. 

Radiological investigations are indicated when there is gross haematuria, shock and microscopic haematuria, pediatric renal trauma, and penetrating injuries.

CECT is the investigation of choice. It assesses the extent of the injury, showing laceration, extravasation, surrounding haemorrhage, and vessel injury. It also shows non-renal injuries and effectively stages renal pedicle injuries. Arterial occlusion will manifest as rim enhancement of the normal renal contour. 

Blunt trauma is mostly treated conservatively. Most penetrating injuries require surgical renal exploration.

Absolute indications for surgical intervention in renal trauma are:

  • Massive haemorrhage
  • Renal pedicle avulsion (grade 5 injury)
  • Expanding, pulsatile, or uncontained retroperitoneal hematoma

Relative indications are:

  • Large laceration of the renal pelvis or avulsion of the ureteropelvic junction
  • Bowel or pancreatic injuries
  • Persistent urinary leakage, postinjury urinoma, or perinephric abscess 
  • Complete renal artery thrombosis of both kidneys 
  • Renal hypertension
The five grade-classification of renal injuries by "The Organ Injury Scaling system of the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST)" is explained in the pearl given below.

questions.text:
Match the following DNA polymerase enzymes with their functions :
DNA Polymerase Function
1. β A. Primase
2. γ B. DNA repair
3. α C. Processive, lagging strand synthesis
4. δ D. Mitochondrial DNA synthesis
questions.solution:
The option which is correctly matched is B with 1-B, 2-D, 3-A, 4-C

DNA Polymerase Function
1. β B. DNA repair
2. γ D. Mitochondrial DNA synthesis
3. α A. Primase
4. δ C. Processive, lagging strand synthesis

 

DNA polymerase engages in DNA replication and has 3 essential properties :

  • Chain elongation: It accounts for the rate at which DNA polymerization occurs. The rate is in nucleotides per second (nt/s)
  • Processivity: This is an expression of the number of nucleotides added to the nascent chain before the polymerase disengages from the template
  • Proofreading: The function where copying errors are identified and corrected

The prokaryotic DNA polymerases are DNA polymerases I, II, and III.

  • DNA polymerase I: Gap filling following DNA replication, repair, and recombination
  • DNA polymerase II: DNA proofreading and repair.
  • DNA polymerase III: The primary enzyme for the synthesis of the leading strand of DNA. 

Eukaryotic cells have a large number of DNA polymerases primarily involved in DNA repair

  • DNA Pol α synthesizes RNA primers which are responsible for the initiation of DNA synthesis.
  • DNA pol β has a primary role in DNA repair
  • DNA pol γ is responsible for mitochondrial DNA synthesis
  • DNA pol ε and pol δ catalyze leading and lagging strand synthesis.

questions.text: The incidence of bladder carcinoma in a population was found to be 5 times higher in smokers than in non-smokers. What is the attributable risk?
questions.solution:
The attributable risk, in this case, will be 80%.

Let the incidence of bladder carcinoma in non-smokers (non-exposed) be x. Therefore, the incidence in smokers (exposed) will be 5x.

According to the formula, attributable risk (AR) is given as follows:

AR (%) = [(IP exposed - IP non-exposed)/ IP exposed] x100, where IP = Incidence proportion

= [(5x - x)/5x] x 100

= 4x/5x x 100

= 80%

Thus, the attributable risk is 80%.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: During your labor room postings, you perform a cardiotocography (CTG) on a woman who is in labor at 38 weeks of gestation. The tracing that you obtain is as shown in the image below. Which among the following is commonly associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The given CTG shows late decelerations. The fetal heart rate begins to drop after the end of uterine contraction. It is mostly associated with uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

Causes of late decelerations:

  • Placental pathologies like - post-maturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption
  • Excessive uterine contractions
  • Excessive use of oxytocin
  • Epidural anesthesia

The CTG given below shows early decelerations. The deceleration coincides with the uterine contractions. It seen in fetal head compression.

The CTG given below shows variable decelerations as seen in umbilical cord compression.

The CTG given below shows a sinusoidal pattern. It resembles a sine wave. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician with the following finding. His mother says that he is otherwise healthy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The yellowish greasy scales on the scalp of an infant are characteristic of seborrheic dermatitis.

Seborrheic dermatitis is a common, inflammatory skin condition that causes the formation of flaky, white to yellowish greasy scales on oily areas such as the scalp, forehead, nose, or inside the ear. It is known as cradle cap when it affects the scalp of infants, as shown in the image below:

 

Other options:

Option A: Impetigo presents with shallow bullae. When ruptured, they result in erosions and discharge that forms honey-colored crusting.

 

Option C: Atopic dermatitis presents in infants as an itchy erythematous rash that affects the face and flexural areas such as elbows. The given image shows atopic dermatitis on the abdomen and thigh of an infant:

 

Option D: Tinea capitis is ringworm of the scalp. It is uncommon in infants. It is common in older children and presents as patches of alopecia associated with scaling or black dots (swollen hair shafts).

The given image shows severe tinea capitis infection with follicles discharging pus, this clinical variant is known as kerion:

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with a lump in her right breast, and she was advised to undergo a mammogram. The radiologist reported the mammographic lesion found as BIRADS grade 2. What will be the management plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
The management plan for this patient would be to undergo routine annual screening.

A Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BIRADS) score of 2 means that it is a benign lesion, and for these patients, annual screening is advised.

questions.text: A cranial ultrasound is routinely indicated in which of the following neonatal conditions?
questions.solution:
Prematurity is an important indication for neonatal evaluation with a cranial ultrasound. Neonates born at <32weeks gestation, are at the most risk for a condition known as Intraventricular Hemorrhage (IVH). Hence, they are routinely evaluated with a cranial ultrasound.

The germinal matrix is a highly vascular, subependymal structure present in the bilateral ventricles. They are responsible for the normal growth and development of neurons and supportive glial cells. As the baby approaches term, the integrity of blood vessels in the germinal matrix matures and it involutes. Premature neonates however are still highly prone to developing an intraventricular bleed.

Most cases do not have any initial signs, with clinical deterioration becoming evident only during the 2nd-3rd day of life. They present with apnea, stupor, coma, hypotonia, seizures, and sometimes, shock.

A cranial ultrasound is the recommended screening method for early detection and management of IVH. 

Indications for a neonatal head ultrasound include:

  • Routine head ultrasound for all premature neonates
  • Suspicion of brain anomalies on antenatal ultrasound
  • Any sick neonate in whom brain pathology is implicated
  • A neonate that had not been screened prenatally

Other options:

Options B, C: Macrosomia & Brachial plexus injury are not indications for a cranial ultrasound.

Option D: Cephalohematoma is a complication of operative (forceps, vacuum-assisted) vaginal delivery that manifests with a subperiosteal bleed. Most cephalohematomas have an uncomplicated clinical course and resolve within 2 weeks - 3 months depending on their dimensions. Monitoring for signs of hyperbilirubinemia is required. Screening cranial ultrasound or imaging of any kind is not indicated in this condition.

questions.text: A family physician noticed that the routine blood test results of his 59-year-old patient show a Hb level of 18 g/dL. He wants to differentiate between absolute polycythemia and relative polycythemia. Which of the following test should be done?
questions.solution:
An increase in the hemoglobin level above normal limits is called polycythemia. RBC mass is measured to differentiate between absolute and relative polycythemia.

Polycythemia is an increase in hemoglobin level > 17 g/dL in males and > 15 g/dL in females. An actual increase in the number of RBCs is seen in absolute polycythemia, whereas, an apparent increase due to decreased plasma volume is seen in relative polycythemia. These two conditions can be differentiated by measuring RBC mass, which is increased in absolute polycythemia and is normal in relative polycythemia. 

Once the diagnosis of absolute polycythemia is made, erythropoietin (EPO) levels are measured to differentiate between primary and secondary polycythemia. Primary polycythemia has low or normal EPO levels, whereas secondary polycythemia has elevated EPO levels.

Other options

Option A: Jak-2 mutation analysis is done if the EPO levels are low and polycythemia vera is suspected.

Option C: Arterial O2 saturation is measured if the EPO levels are elevated. If the O2 saturation is low, further evaluation for COPD, heart disease, or intracardiac shunt is necessary. 

Option D: Carboxy-hemoglobin levels are measured in smokers if O2 saturation is normal, whereas, O2 hemoglobin affinity is measured in non-smokers.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the triangle of doom?

choices.text: The apex is at the deep inguinal ring
Lateral border is formed by vas deferens
Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve is also a content

questions.solution:
Medial border of the triangle of doom is bounded by vas deferens.

The triangle of doom is bounded:

Myopectineal orifice is an Osseo-Myo-aponeurotic tunnel. It is through this tunnel all groin hernias occur.

It is bounded:

  • Medially by the lateral border of the rectus sheath.
  • Above by the arched fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscle.
  • Laterally by the iliopsoas muscle.

questions.text:
Match the given drugs to their corresponding mechanism of action.
Drug Mechanism of action

1. Etidronate

 A. High-affinity binding to RANKL

2. Cinacalcet

 B. Induces osteoclast apoptosis 

3. Denosumab

 C. Increased osteoblastic activity

4. Teriparatide

 D. Enhance sensitivity of CaSR to circulating Ca2+

 

CaSR: Calcium-sensing receptor.
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-B, 2-D, 3-A, 4-C. 

Etidronate belongs to the bisphosphonates class of drugs. It is a pyrophosphate analog that acts by directly inhibiting bone absorption. This is achieved by inducing osteoclast apoptosis as well as the prevention of hydroxyapatite dissolution. They also directly inhibit osteoclasts. It is used to treat Paget disease, tumor-associated osteolysis, and osteoporosis.

Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic that acts by increasing the sensitivity of the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR) to circulating Ca2+. It thereby inhibits the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands. It is used as a pharmacotherapeutic alternative to surgery in PTH hypersecretion disorders such as parathyroid carcinoma and secondary hyperparathyroidism due to chronic kidney. 

Denosumab is a human monoclonal antibody with a mechanism of action similar to that of osteoprotegerin (OPG). It binds to RANK Ligand (RANKL), thereby inhibiting its binding to the RANK receptor of the surface of osteoclasts. This prevents RANK receptor activation and subsequent bone resorption. It is used in the treatment of osteoporosis.

Teriparatide is a recombinant PTH analog that has an anabolic effect on bone homeostasis. It increases osteoblastic activity by increasing the expression of pro-osteoblastogenic growth factors (IGF1, FGF2) and transcriptional factors (Runx2). They promote osteoblast survival and differentiation. It is used in the treatment of postmenopausal and glucocorticoid-induced osteoporosis. 

Note: Some other drugs used in the management of osteoporosis

  • Calcitonin - It is an indigenous hormone secreted by the parafollicular cells of the thyroid gland. It prevents bone resorption by osteoclasts. WIth time it reduces both bone formation and resorption. The ultimate result is a modest increase in bone mass, especially in patients with increased rates of bone turnover.
  • Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) - Estrogen has a protective effect that prevents accelerated bone loss. This is carried out by reducing the bone resorption effects of parathyroid hormone (PTH). Keeping in line with these effects, osteoporosis prevention in postmenopausal women has been attributed to the use of SERMs such as raloxifene. It acts as a selective estrogen agonist on bone (with antiestrogen effects on breast- protective against CA breast).

questions.text: A biochemist is working on a study of enzyme activation in the fed and fasting state. He gives a dose of insulin to the study animal. Which of the following enzymes will be activated in response to this dose?
questions.solution:
Pyruvate dehydrogenase is highly active in the high insulin/well-fed/dephosphorylated state.

The rest of the enzymes are active in the phosphorylated state/low insulin/fasting state.

Fasting state / low insulin state :

Liver :

With a fall in the blood glucose levels, there is a fall in insulin levels with less uptake of glucose by muscle and adipose tissues. α-cells of the pancreas secrete glucagon which inhibits glycogen synthetase and in turn activates glycogen phosphorylase. This eventually releases glucose into the bloodstream intended for the use of the brain and RBCs. Glucagon stimulates the production of cAMP, activating cAMP-dependent protein kinase. This in turn inactivates phosphofructokinase-2 and activates fructose 2,6-bisphosphatase by phosphorylation.

Muscle: 

Acetyl-CoA formed by oxidation of fatty acids causes inhibition of pyruvate dehydrogenase consequently leading to an accumulation of pyruvate. It is then converted to alanine which is then transaminated back to pyruvate in the liver. This is used as a substrate for gluconeogenesis.

Adipose tissue:

A fall in insulin and an increase in glucagon leads to inhibition of lipogenesis and activation of hormone-sensitive lipase. This leads to a massive release of glycerol which serves as a substrate for gluconeogenesis in the liver. It is also utilised by the liver, heart, and skeletal muscle as metabolic fuel.

As fasting progresses, acetyl-CoA is used for the synthesis of ketone bodies which are utilised by skeletal and heart muscles and up to 20% of the brain's energy source. After 18 hours of fasting, amino acids from protein catabolism are utilized by the liver and kidneys for gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male patient underwent resection of the gastric antrum. A few weeks later, endoscopy revealed atrophy of the gastric mucosa. Serum levels of which of the following hormone is likely to be decreased?
questions.solution:
Serum levels of the gastrin are most likely to be reduced.

Gastrin is secreted by the G cells in the gastric antrum. Gastrin has two main actions:

  • Stimulates secretion of H+ by gastric parietal cells
  • Promotes growth of the gastric mucosa (trophic action)

Conditions associated with increased gastrin secretions (Ex: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome), will cause an increase in H+ secretion and hypertrophy of the gastric mucosa. Conditions associated with reduced gastrin secretion (Ex: Resection of the gastric antrum), will cause a decrease in H+ secretion and atrophy of the gastric mucosa.

Secretin, cholecystokinin, and motilin are released by various cells in different parts of the small intestine and remain unaffected by the atrophy of gastric mucosa.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an intermediate filament?
questions.solution:
Tubulin is a part of microtubules and is not an intermediate filament.

There are three major classes of cytoskeletal proteins: microfilaments, intermediate filaments, and microtubules.

1. Actin microfilaments:

These fibrils formed from the globular protein actin (G-actin) noncovalently polymerize into long filaments (F-actin) that intertwine to form double-stranded helices.

2. Intermediate filaments:

These rope-like intermediate filament fibers are found predominantly in a polymerized form within cells and do not possess the quality of active reorganization like actin and microtubules. They are responsible for cellular tensile strength, which allows the cells to bear mechanical stress.

Type of intermediate filament Description
Lamin A, B, and C These proteins are localized in the nuclear lamina of all cells. Mutations in lamin proteins are associated with certain disorders such as familial partial lipodystrophy type 2, Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome, and familial dilated cardiomyopathy.
Vimentin These are mainly found in mesenchymal cells (fibroblasts, endothelium).
Desmin Present in sarcomeres in muscle cells.
Neurofilament These are found in neuronal axons, imparting strength and rigidity.
Glial fibrillary acidic protein Present in glial cells around neurons.
Cytokeratins

These proteins are the most diverse among IFs and constitute type I (acidic) and type II (basic) IF proteins.

There are at least 30 isoforms of this protein divided into two groups: Epithelial keratins (found in epithelial cells) and trichocytic keratins (found in hair-keratin).

3. Microtubules:

These are formed by non-covalent polymerization of a dimer of two globular proteins, alpha-tubulin, and beta-tubulin. The microtubules in most cells extend outward from a microtubule-organizing center (MTOC), in which the minus ends of microtubules are anchored.

questions.text: As a surgeon, you plan to perform the following surgeries on four of your patients. In which of the following procedures will you be extra cautious due to the higher risk of surgical site infection (SSI)?
questions.solution:
Extra precautions should be taken while performing a colorectal surgery as it belongs to the category of clean-contaminated wound (class II) with an expected infection rate of 4-14%.

Elective cholecystectomy also belongs to the category of clean-contaminated wound (class II) but it is associated with a lesser infection rate of 2-9%

Class I: Clean wounds: Surgical site infection (SSI) rate is least in clean wounds, i.e. in operations where there is no inflammation and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered. Examples include:

  • Elective herniorrhaphy is a clean wound categorized as class I (as the prosthetic mesh is placed)
  • Breast biopsy 

Class II: Clean-contaminated wounds in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tract is entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination. Examples include:

  • Elective cholecystectomy
  • Elective gastrointestinal surgeries (eg: Fundoplication)
  • Colorectal surgery (higher infection rate)

Class III: Contaminated wounds include open, fresh, accidental wounds; operations with major breaks in sterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract; and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered.

Class IV: Dirty wounds include old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera.

Related Pearl: Surgical wound classifications as defined by ACS NSOP

  • Clean/Contaminated: Operative wounds in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tract is entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination
  • Contaminated: Open, fresh, accidental wounds; operations with major breaks insterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered
  • Dirty: Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient who is under the support of a mechanical ventilator in ICU is found to be improving and is planned to be weaned off from ventilatory support. As an anesthetist, you plan to give spontaneous breathing trials using a T-piece. All of the following is a pre-requisite for weaning off except

choices.text: Vital capacity >10 ml/ kg body weight

questions.solution:
Rapid shallow breathing index should be < 105 to wean off a patient from a mechanical ventilator.

Tidal volume is kept ideally at 4-6 ml/kg body weight. A value more than this will cause lung injury.

A patient on mechanical ventilation should be tried to wean off when he can breathe spontaneously and is hemodynamically stable with adequate arterial oxygen saturation.

Additional criteria include,

  • Inspiratory pressure: -20-30cm H2O
  • Tidal volume: 4-6ml/kg
  • Vital capacity: >10 mL/kg
  • Minute ventilation: <10 L/min
  • Rapid shallow breathing index(RSBI): <105

Note: Patients with an RSBI of less than 105 can be successfully extubated. Those with an RSBI greater than 120 should retain mechanical ventilator support.
