questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea is found to have a blind-ended vagina. Breast development is adequate and stature is normal while pubic and axillary hairs are sparse. USG reveals absent uterus and the karyotype is 46, XY. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history and the examination findings suggest a diagnosis of androgen insensitivity syndrome.

Androgen insensitivity syndrome, formerly called testicular feminization syndrome, is a condition in which the end organs are unable to respond to the androgen. There is either a mutation or lack of the androgen cytosol receptor 

They are phenotypically and psychosocially a female. 

They present with primary amenorrhea or infertility. The breast is well developed with absent or sparse axillary and pubic hair. The vagina is short and blind. The uterus is absent. It is due to the normal production of antimullerian hormone by the Sertoli cells. Testes may be in either the labia or inguinal canal or intrabdominal area. Karyotype is 46, XY.

Other options:

Options A and C: Mullerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome, has a karyotype of 46XX. Similar to androgen insensitivity syndrome, these females present with primary amenorrhea with normal breast development and an absent uterus. However, ovaries are present. 

Option D: In Turner syndrome, short stature with poor development of secondary sexual characters will be seen. It has a karyotype of 45 XO. Sex chromatin is negative. Female genital organs (vagina, uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries) are present.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old patient with a history of suicidal attempts is brought to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting, and tinnitus. He was prescribed aspirin 1 week back for a headache. His lab values are as follows:

Na= 140 mEq/L
K=3.5 mEq/L
Cl=104 mEq/L
HCO3=16 mEq/L
glucose= 100 mg/dL
pH: 7.50
pCO2: 20 mmHg
P02: 125 mmHg

What is the diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Respiratory alkalosis with compensatory metabolic acidosis
Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis
Mixed high anion gap metabolic acidosis with respiratory alkalosis
High anion gap metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis

questions.solution:
This patient has a mixed high anion gap metabolic acidosis with additional respiratory alkalosis.

Step 1: pH in this patient is 7.50 which is an alkalemia.

Step 2: Bicarbonate levels in this patient are 16 mEq/L which is reduced. This signifies the loss of base. Hence a metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: PCO2 levels in this patient are 20 mmHg, which is less than normal. This signifies a respiratory alkalosis.

Step 4: Assessing the anion gap:

AG=( Na+)- {(Cl-)+(HCO3-)}

= 20.

Hence the patient has a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. In addition, respiratory alkalosis is also present, whether it is a mixed disorder or compensatory can be determined by assessing the extent of compensatory response.

Step 5: Assessing the compensatory response:

In metabolic acidosis, appropriate respiratory compensation is to decrease PCO2, by excretion of volatile acid by hyperventilation. Expected PCO2 is calculated by the Winters formula:

PCO2=  [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2

= [1.5 X 16] + 8 ± 2

=30-34

During metabolic acidosis, there is respiratory compensation by hyperventilation resulting in loss of volatile acid causing a reduction in PCO2 levels. The expected PCO2 levels are 30-34 mEq/L in this patient. However, since PCO2 is 20 mEq/l in this patient, there is an additional respiratory alkalosis independent of the compensatory response.

An elevated anion gap even in the setting of a normal pH or alkalemia always indicates metabolic acidosis.

This patient's history of suicidal tendencies, aspirin use, and tinnitus points to aspirin toxicity as a cause of the disease. Aspirin overdose results in initial hyperventilation and respiratory alkalosis due to direct stimulation of respiratory centres. In addition, aspirin being a salicylate causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A young man who had fractured his left humerus previously now does not feel pain in his left little finger. On examination, the following deformity is observed. Which of the nerves is most likely to have been involved?
questions.solution:
The deformity shown is cubitus valgus. This, along with the patient’s history of previous humerus fracture followed by loss of sensation over the little finger, points to the involvement of the ulnar nerve.

Cubitus valgus can occur as a late complication of nonunion of fracture of the lateral condyle of the humerus. The cubitus valgus deformity leads to the stretching of the ulnar nerve, resulting in classic neuropathic symptoms, which is termed tardy ulnar nerve palsy. Paresthesia in the ulnar nerve distribution with atrophy of the intrinsic hand muscles can be seen. It can be treated with ulnar nerve transposition and cubitus valgus correction.

The ulnar nerve supplies the medial two lumbricals in the hand. The lumbricals have a combined action on metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint flexion and interphalangeal (IP) joint extension (glass holding posture). In ulnar nerve injury, since the medial lumbricals are not functional, the forearm muscles are unopposed. Hence, there is hyperextension at MCP joints and flexion at IP joints. This causes claw hand deformity. There is also numbness in the medial one-and-a-half fingers.

questions.text: A 7-month-old child is brought by his parents with the following lesions for one week. On examination, Darier's sign is positive. Lesions are not seen in the palms, soles and face. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows reddish‐brown maculopapular lesions on the trunk of a child with positive Darier's sign, which is suggestive of urticaria pigmentosa. 

Urticaria pigmentosa:

It is the commonest type of cutaneous mastocytosis. It occurs due to an increased number of mast cells in the skin. 

The mast cells accumulate in tissues due to a gain-of‐function mutation of KIT. The symptoms occur due to the release of mast cell-derived mediators. The age of onset is in the first year in the childhood type and 20-40 years in the adult type.

It presents with numerous reddish‐brown or pale monomorphic maculopapules, plaques, or nodules in a symmetrical distribution. Lesions can occur anywhere but are common over the trunk and thighs. The palms and soles are usually spared. Even though the neck and the hairline can be affected, the face is usually spared. It can also present with bullous lesions that heal without scarring.

Other features:

  • Flushing
  • Pruritus
  • Heat or cold intolerance
  • Recurrent diarrhea
  • Dyspepsia
  • Depression
  • Headache

Darier's sign is seen in urticaria pigmentosa. It refers to the development of urticaria and erythema around the lesions after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of the lesion. Darier's sign is not specific for mastocytosis as it is also rarely seen in juvenile xanthogranuloma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

 

Treatment of urticaria pigmentosa: 

  • Avoiding physical stimuli that trigger mast cell degranulation- temperature extremes, pressure, alcohol
  • Antihistamines
  • Mast cell stabilizers
  • Topical and oral corticosteroids
  • Psoralen + ultraviolet light A (PUVA) therapy
  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors like imatinib

Other options:

Option A: Café‐au‐lait macules (CALMs), also called as café‐au‐lait spots, present as well-circumscribed, hyperpigmented, light brown to dark brown macules and patches that range in size from 1 to 2 mm to greater than 20 cm in greatest diameter. They may appear at birth or at the first decade.

They may present on any body parts, but most commonly involves the trunk and the extremities. Darier's sign is not seen in CALMs.

They are associated with several genetic syndromes such as neurofibromatosis (NF1, NF2), McCune-Albright syndrome, and tuberous sclerosis.

Image below shows café‐au‐lait spots.

Option B: Juvenile xanthogranuloma is a benign proliferative disorder of histiocytes occurring in early infancy and childhood.

It presents as reddish yellow maculo-papular lesions which may evolve into yellow brown patches/plaques with surface telangiectasis.

They may be single or multiple. Single lesions are the most common. Lesions occur most commonly on the face, head and neck, followed by trunk and extremities.

Darier's sign is positive in juvenile xanthogranuloma.

Image below shows a yellow papule in the right inner arm of a child suggestive of juvenile xanthogranuloma.

Option D: Chronic bullous dermatosis (linear Ig A dermatosis) of childhood is an autoimmune blistering disease in infants and children. The disease can also be seen in adults and is known as linear IgA disease of adults or IgA bullous pemphigoid.

It present as tense blisters and vesicles, urticated plaques with erythema. They are arranged annularly in a “crown of jewels,” "cluster of jewels," or “string of pearls” formation, although this sign may also be seen in bullous pemphigoid. Varying degrees of pruritis may be present. The most common sites are the perioral area and perineum, followed by the trunk and limbs.

The image below shows linear IgA dermatosis at various sites.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man sustained a traumatic head injury. The following image was taken after he was asked to look straight. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is right 6th nerve palsy as the image shows esotropia and a limitation of abduction of the right eye. 

The 6th cranial nerve or abducens nerve supplies the lateral rectus muscle which is an abductor of the eye. Its lesion cause esotropia due to the unopposed action of the medial rectus.  The 3rd cranial nerve or oculomotor nerve supplies the medial rectus which is an adductor of the eye.

Note: If the same finding as shown in the image is seen when the patient is asked to look left, the lesion would be in the left eye. The left lateral rectus would be affected due to a left abducens nerve palsy.

Other options: 

Option A: 3rd or oculomotor nerve palsy causes ptosis due to weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris, abduction and depression in the primary position (due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique). Limited adduction, elevation and depression due to medial rectus, superior rectus and inferior oblique weakness. Pupil will be dilated pupil with defective accommodation due to parasympathetic palsy.

Option B: 4th or trochlear nerve supplies the superior oblique muscle and its palsy causes hypertropia, limited depression and extorsion of the affected eye. 

Option D: Horizontal gaze palsy occurs due to a lesion in the parapontine reticular formation. This leads to ipsilateral lateral rectus and contralateral medial rectus weakness. It is characterized by the inability to look in the direction of the lesion.

questions.text: Which of the following has no anti-factor IIa activity?
questions.solution:
Fondaparinux has no anti-factor IIa activity. It is a synthetic pentasaccharide that binds and activates antithrombin.

Activation of antithrombin causes the inactivation of factor Xa. Fondaparinux does not have any anti-factor IIa activity as it is not long enough to form a template for thrombin(IIa) and antithrombin binding and subsequent inhibition of thrombin.

For antithrombin activity, the heparin molecules should be of sufficient length (>18 polysaccharide units) to serve as a template for thrombin and antithrombin binding.

Other options:

Option A - Unfractionated heparin has sufficient length for inhibition of thrombin activity so that the factor Xa: IIa inhibition activity is 1:1.

Options B, D - Low molecular weight heparins (LMWH) - Enoxaparin and Dalteparin have sufficient length for inhibition of thrombin activity, but less compared to unfractionated heparin. The factor Xa: IIa inhibition activity ranges from 2:1 to 3:1 depending upon the preparation.

questions.text: Which of the following visual field defects is seen in an injury to Baum’s loop of the optic radiations?
questions.solution:
Inferior quadrantanopia (pie in the floor) is seen in patients who have an injury to the optic radiations which pass through the parietal lobe. They are also known as Baum’s loop.

Pie in the Sky defects:

  • Superior quadrantic hemianopia
  • Involvement of inferior fibres of Optic radiations – Meyer’s loop
  • Seen in Temporal lobe lesions

Pie in the Floor defects:

  • Inferior quadrantic hemianopia
  • Involvement of superior fibres of the Optic radiations – Baum’s loop
  • Seen in Parietal lobe lesions

Notable points :

  • Lesion in central chiasma – Bitemporal hemianopia
  • Lesion in anterior chiasma – Junctional scotoma
  • Lesion in optic tract – Wernicke’s hemianopic pupil
  • Radiational lesion and cortical blindness has normal pupillary reaction

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with infertility underwent semen analysis. Results show a sperm concentration of 18 million/ml, pH- 7.5, and volume- 2 ml. No agglutination is seen. Morphology shows 10% normal forms and 20% motile sperms. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given semen analysis point towards a diagnosis of asthenospermia as only 20% of the sperms are motile. Normally, 32% of sperm should be motile.

Other options:

Option A: Azoospermia - Absence of sperm in semen

Option C: Normospermia - Sperm concentration of > 15 million/ml

Option D: Oligospermia- Sperm concentration of < 15 million/ml

questions.text: A primigravida comes with complaints of absent fetal movements. On ultrasound, there is no cardiac activity in the fetus and a gas shadow is seen in the aorta of the fetus. According to the findings, a minimum of how many hours have passed after the death of the fetus.
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a primigravida with a history of absent fetal movements and USG showing absent cardiac activity and gas shadow in the aorta of the fetus indicate 12 hours have passed after intrauterine fetal death.

Robert's sign is a gas shadow in the great vessels like the aorta, seen in fetal demise in utero. The gas shadow in the chambers of the heart and great vessels may appear as early as 12 hours but it is difficult to interpret.

A process of aseptic autolysis that occurs after the intrauterine death of the fetus is known as maceration. This process occurs when the dead fetus remains in utero for 3-4 days and is surrounded by the liquor amnii. There is a risk of putrefaction occurring when air is allowed to enter the liquor amnii after the death of the fetus.

Signs of maceration - 

  • Earliest sign - reddening of the skin with peeling in 12 hours
  • Robert's sign - radiographic finding showing gas in the great vessels like the aorta in 12 hours
  • Large blebs containing a red serous or serosanguineous fluid appear at around 24 hours 
  • Serous cavities may contain a turbid reddish fluid after 48 hours
  • Spalding's sign -  due to shrinkage of the brain after death there is loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of the cranial vault. 
  • A sweetish and disagreeable odour
  • Distended abdomen and abnormally mobile or flexible joints
  • The body is soft and pliable and flattens out when placed on an even surface

Other signs of intrauterine death - 

  • Rigor mortis at delivery
  • Mummification - when intrauterine death occurs due to deficient blood supply. Scanty liquor amnii and the absence of air in the uterus favours mummification.

Related Pearl: Radiological features of Intrauterine Death

  • Robert's sign - The presence of a gas shadow within the chambers of the heart or the greater vessels like aorta, in cases of foetal death in utero
  • Spalding sign - Loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of cranial vault and overlapping of skull bones due to shrinkage of brain after death
  • Deuel’s halo sign – Increased pericranial fat
  • Hyperflexion of spine and crowding of ribs

questions.text:
Match the given images with their respective names.
  1. Velamentous placenta
  2. Succenturiate placenta
  3. Circumvallate placenta
  4. Battledore placenta
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-a, 2-d, 3-b, 4-c.

Image 1 shows a velamentous placenta in which the cord is attached to the membranes. The cord vessels travel between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta. If these vessels are present over the membranes lying near the internal os in front of the presenting part, it is called vasa previa. The rupture of the membranes involving the overlying these vessels leads to vaginal bleeding of the fetal blood.

 

Image 2 is a Battledore placenta, where the cord is attached to the margin of the placenta. When it is associated with a placenta previa or a low-lying placenta, there can be cord compression, fetal anoxia, and fetal death.

 

Image 3 shows a succenturiate placenta. It is characterized by the presence of one or more small lobes of the placenta placed at varying distances from the main placental margins. A leash of blood vessels connects these accessory cotyledons to the main placenta. If these vessels are absent, then it is called placenta spuria. If this lobe is retained postpartum, there can be primary or secondary postpartum hemorrhage, subinvolution of uterus, uterine sepsis, polyp formation.

 

Image 4 is a circumvallate placenta. It is a type of placenta extrachorialis. There is a smaller chorionic plate as compared to the basal plate. The amnion and chorion fold and roll back on themselves to form a ring on the fetal side.

There is an increased chance of abortions, hydrorrhea gravidarum (excessive watery discharge per vagina), antepartum hemorrhage, growth retardation of the fetus, preterm delivery, and retained placenta and membranes.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy presented with progressive swelling of the upper end of the humerus. The X-ray image is given below. CT scan of the chest reveals metastasis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows the sunburst appearance of the tumor at the metaphyseal end of a long bone, which is suggestive of osteosarcoma. 

Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the commonly involved sites.

In osteosarcoma, the tumor lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction is irregular and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on x-ray.

Other options:

Option A - Osteoclastoma or Giant cell tumor:

The commonly affected age group is 20-40 years with a slight female preponderance. The distal end of the femur is the most common location followed by the proximal tibia and distal radius. 

Radiographic findings: 

  • Eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis
  • Soap bubble appearance
  • Periosteal new bone formation is absent.

Option B - Ewing's sarcoma:

It is a primary malignant tumor of the bone commonly involving the age group of 4-25 years. It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus. 

Radiographic findings: Onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is the typical finding.

Option D - Secondary metastasis from the prostate is typically densely osteosclerotic, in contrast to osteolytic renal and thyroid lesions. Lung and breast metastases produce mixed osteoblastic/osteolytic lesions.

Local and distal staging includes X-rays and MRI of the whole affected bone, bone scintigraphy, and CT scan of the thorax, abdomen, and pelvis. The most sensitive imaging modality for identifying metastases is the whole-body MRI.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male with a history of myocardial infarction two months back has been planned for elective cholecystectomy because of cholelithiasis. During his preoperative evaluation, he has an ejection fraction of 40%. The following image shows an assessment of his airway. He would be classified as_________

ASA PS- American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status
questions.solution:
This patient, who is about to undergo an elective cholecystectomy can be classified as ASA PS 4 with an airway assessment grade 3 as per Mallampati classification.

He has a recent history of MI two months back and severe reduction in ejection fraction (40%), which together puts the patient under Physical Status 4 as per American Society of Anaesthesiologist classification of patients.

In the given image of airway assessment, only the base of the uvula, soft palate, and the hard palate can be seen. Hence, grade 3 as per the modified Mallampati classification given by Samsoon and Young.

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification is used to define relative risk before conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

II A patient with mild systemic disease Current smoker, well-controlled DM and HTN
III A patient with severe systemic disease Poorly controlled DM or HTN, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD or stents.
IV A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Recent (< 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: Overdose of which of the following anti-arrhythmic drugs is correctly paired with its ECG side effects?

choices.text: Diltiazem – Increased PR interval and QRS duration

questions.solution:
Flecainide causes increased QRS duration. All other drugs are matched incorrectly.

The effect of various prototype antiarrhythmic drugs on ECG are as follows:

Group 1 Drugs:

Procainamide, disopyramide, quinidine (Group 1A):

  • PR interval may decrease due to antimuscarinic action or increase due to channel-blocking action.
  • Increase in QRS duration and QT interval.

Lidocaine, mexiletine (Group 1B):

  • There is normally no change in PR interval, QRS duration or QT interval.
  • However, they can slow conduction through ischemic, depolarized ventricular cells.

Flecainide (Group 1C) causes a slight increase in PR interval, increased QRS duration, and no change in QT interval.

Group 2 drugs:

Propranolol and esmolol cause an increased PR interval.

Group 3 drugs:

  • Amiodarone is often classified as group 3 but also has some group 1A properties. It causes increased PR interval, QRS duration, and QT interval.
  • Ibutilide, dofetilide causes increased QT interval.
  • Sotalol causes an increase in PR interval and QT interval.

Group 4 drugs such as verapamil and diltiazem cause an increase in PR interval. The QRS duration and QT interval are unaffected.

questions.text: A patient suffering from severe depression with suicidal thoughts is refractory to pharmacotherapy. ECT (electroconvulsive therapy) sessions are being planned for this patient. What is the maximum number of ECT sessions that can be conducted in a week?
questions.solution:
A maximum of 3 ECT sessions per week can be administered to a patient undergoing electroconvulsive therapy.

Indications for ECT in depression:

  • Severe depression with risk of suicide
  • Severe depression with either stupor, psychomotor retardation, or somatic syndrome
  • Depression refractory to treatment
  • Intolerance or significant side effects to antidepressants.

Severe depression with suicidality is the first and foremost indication for the use of ECT. The response is usually rapid, resulting in a marked improvement.

ECT can be of 2 types:

  • Direct - without anesthesia and muscle relaxant (very infrequently used)
  • Modified - with anesthesia and muscle relaxant. Currently preferred and is given with adequate spacing i.e., no more than 3 ECT sessions per week.

Thiopentone and succinylcholine are given for anesthesia induction and muscle relaxation respectively. Thiopentone sodium is a barbiturate and acts by opening chloride channels, whilst succinylcholine is a depolarising muscle relaxant.

After adequate preparation, a current of 200-1600mA is given, resulting in an adequate seizure. Therapeutically adequate treatment will have a generalized tonic-clonic seizure lasting for not less than 25-30 seconds.

After 6 to 10 sessions, if no improvement is seen, bilateral placement and high-density treatment (three times the seizure threshold) should be attempted before ECT is abandoned.

However, antidepressants are often needed along with ECTs in order to maintain the improvement achieved.

Related Pearl: Key points on electroconvulsive therapy

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

  • Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.
  • Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

  • Treatment-resistant depression
  • Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)
  • Depression with psychotic features
  • Depressed suicidal pregnant women
  • Refusal to eat or drink
  • Imminent risk for suicide
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia
  • Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

  • Retrograde amnesia (most common)
  • Partial anterograde amnesia
  • Disorientation
  • Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

  • Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction
  • Space occupying brain lesion
  • Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

questions.text: Which of the following pathophysiological mechanisms is implicated in Goodpasture syndrome?
questions.solution:
The pathophysiological mechanism underlying Goodpasture syndrome, also known as anti-glomerular basement membrane (GBM) disease, is antibody-dependant cellular toxicity. This is an example of a type II hypersensitivity reaction.

Type II hypersensitivity is characterized by an antigen-antibody reaction on the cell surface or in the extracellular matrix, leading to the destruction of the cells and consequent inflammation. The antibody against a specific antigen can lead to cellular destruction by either opsonization and phagocytosis, complement activation, or antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC). In ADCC, cells coated with IgG antibodies are killed by effector cells like NK cells and macrophages. The antibody can also cause cellular dysfunction by inhibiting or excessively activating normal processes, such as in myasthenia gravis and Grave's disease respectively. 

In Goodpasture syndrome, antibodies that are directed against the GBM also cross-react with the basement membrane of the alveoli of the lung. This causes the characteristic clinical picture of pulmonary hemorrhage associated with renal failure. The antibodies are targetted against a peptide in the non-collagenous portion of the α3 chain of collagen type IV. In the kidney, anti-GBM antibodies lead to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, which is characterized by the formation of crescents. On immunofluorescence, deposition of IgG and C3 is seen in a linear pattern along the GBM. 

Other options:

Option B: Mutation of type IV (α5 chain) collagen is responsible for Alport syndrome, which presents with haematuria, ophthalmologic conditions (such as anterior lenticonus), and sensorineural hearing loss. This condition most commonly occurs as an X-linked dominant condition, and males express the full syndrome. Female heterozygotes typically present with just hematuria. Electron microscopy findings include a glomerular basement membrane with alternating portions of thickening and thinning associated with splitting the of lamina densa, known as basket-weave appearance.

Option C: Antigen-antibody immune complex deposition is responsible for immune-complex mediated (type III) hypersensitivity reaction. These complexes circulate in the body and deposit in various sites (vessel walls, renal glomeruli, joints) to cause inflammation.

Option D: CD4+T cell-mediated cytokine release is responsible for T cell-mediated (type IV) hypersensitivity reaction.

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft
